events.title: Legal Chess: The Count's Strategic Questions and Caged Correspondence
detailed_summary: On May 12th, the narrator decides to focus on verifiable facts in his diary.
The Count initiates a conversation about legal procedures and business transactions in England.
The narrator, having spent the day studying, discusses matters from his time at Lincoln's Inn.
The Count inquires methodically, first about the feasibility of having multiple solicitors.
He then asks about using different agents for banking and shipping, especially for goods sent to various English ports from a location far from the primary solicitor in London.
The Count explains his motive for choosing a solicitor from Exeter (far from London) was to avoid local London interests conflicting with his own.
The narrator explains the system of solicitor agencies for local tasks.
The Count confirms his desire to direct matters himself and asks about consignment processes and potential difficulties.
The narrator is impressed by the Count's sharp understanding and foresight for someone supposedly unfamiliar with England or extensive business.
After these inquiries, the Count asks if the narrator has written any letters since his arrival.
Hearing he hasn't, the Count commands him to write to his employer and others, instructing him to state he will stay for another month.
The narrator, feeling a chill, questions the long stay but feels compelled to agree due to his employer's interests and the Count's imposing demeanor, which reminds him of his captivity.
The Count, seeing his acquiescence, instructs him to write only about business and his well-being.
He provides thin foreign notepaper and envelopes, and his smile reveals his sharp canine teeth, making the narrator realize the Count will likely read the letters.
The narrator decides to write formal, brief notes publicly but plans to write fully to Mr. Hawkins and Mina in shorthand secretly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 12 May.—Let me begin with facts—bare, meagre facts, verified by books and figures, and of which there can be no doubt.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I determined to write only formal notes now, but to write fully to Mr. Hawkins in secret, and also to Mina, for to her I could write in shorthand, which would puzzle the Count, if he did see it.

events.text_segment:
12 May.—Let me begin with facts—bare, meagre facts, verified by books and figures, and of which there can be no doubt. I must not confuse them with experiences which will have to rest on my own observation, or my memory of them. Last evening when the Count came from his room he began by asking me questions on legal matters and on the doing of certain kinds of business. I had spent the day wearily over books, and, simply to keep my mind occupied, went over some of the matters I had been examining at Lincoln’s Inn. There was a certain method in the Count’s inquiries, so I shall try to put them down in sequence; the knowledge may somehow or some time be useful to me.
First, he asked if a man in England might have two solicitors or more. I told him he might have a dozen if he wished, but that it would not be wise to have more than one solicitor engaged in one transaction, as only one could act at a time, and that to change would be certain to militate against his interest. He seemed thoroughly to understand, and went on to ask if there would be any practical difficulty in having one man to attend, say, to banking, and another to look after shipping, in case local help were needed in a place far from the home of the banking solicitor. I asked him to explain more fully, so that I might not by any chance mislead him, so he said:—
“I shall illustrate. Your friend and mine, Mr. Peter Hawkins, from under the shadow of your beautiful cathedral at Exeter, which is far from London, buys for me through your good self my place at London. Good! Now here let me say frankly, lest you should think it strange that I have sought the services of one so far off from London instead of some one resident there, that my motive was that no local interest might be served save my wish only; and as one of London residence might, perhaps, have some purpose of himself or friend to serve, I went thus afield to seek my agent, whose labours should be only to my interest. Now, suppose I, who have much of affairs, wish to ship goods, say, to Newcastle, or Durham, or Harwich, or Dover, might it not be that it could with more ease be done by consigning to one in these ports?” I answered that certainly it would be most easy, but that we solicitors had a system of agency one for the other, so that local work could be done locally on instruction from any solicitor, so that the client, simply placing himself in the hands of one man, could have his wishes carried out by him without further trouble.
“But,” said he, “I could be at liberty to direct myself. Is it not so?”
“Of course,” I replied; and “such is often done by men of business, who do not like the whole of their affairs to be known by any one person.”
“Good!” he said, and then went on to ask about the means of making consignments and the forms to be gone through, and of all sorts of difficulties which might arise, but by forethought could be guarded against. I explained all these things to him to the best of my ability, and he certainly left me under the impression that he would have made a wonderful solicitor, for there was nothing that he did not think of or foresee. For a man who was never in the country, and who did not evidently do much in the way of business, his knowledge and acumen were wonderful. When he had satisfied himself on these points of which he had spoken, and I had verified all as well as I could by the books available, he suddenly stood up and said:—
“Have you written since your first letter to our friend Mr. Peter Hawkins, or to any other?” It was with some bitterness in my heart that I answered that I had not, that as yet I had not seen any opportunity of sending letters to anybody.
“Then write now, my young friend,” he said, laying a heavy hand on my shoulder: “write to our friend and to any other; and say, if it will please you, that you shall stay with me until a month from now.”
“Do you wish me to stay so long?” I asked, for my heart grew cold at the thought.
“I desire it much; nay, I will take no refusal. When your master, employer, what you will, engaged that someone should come on his behalf, it was understood that my needs only were to be consulted. I have not stinted. Is it not so?”
What could I do but bow acceptance? It was Mr. Hawkins’s interest, not mine, and I had to think of him, not myself; and besides, while Count Dracula was speaking, there was that in his eyes and in his bearing which made me remember that I was a prisoner, and that if I wished it I could have no choice. The Count saw his victory in my bow, and his mastery in the trouble of my face, for he began at once to use them, but in his own smooth, resistless way:—
“I pray you, my good young friend, that you will not discourse of things other than business in your letters. It will doubtless please your friends to know that you are well, and that you look forward to getting home to them. Is it not so?” As he spoke he handed me three sheets of note-paper and three envelopes. They were all of the thinnest foreign post, and looking at them, then at him, and noticing his quiet smile, with the sharp, canine teeth lying over the red underlip, I understood as well as if he had spoken that I should be careful what I wrote, for he would be able to read it. So I determined to write only formal notes now, but to write fully to Mr. Hawkins in secret, and also to Mina, for to her I could write in shorthand, which would puzzle the Count, if he did see it.

events.title: Intercepted Mail and a Chilling Admonition
detailed_summary: After writing his letters, the narrator observes the Count writing several notes.
When the Count leaves the room momentarily, the narrator, feeling justified in protecting himself, examines the letters left face down on the table.
He identifies letters addressed to Samuel F. Billington in Whitby, Herr Leutner in Varna, Coutts & Co. in London, and Herren Klopstock & Billreuth in Buda-Pesth. Two are unsealed.
He is about to inspect the unsealed letters when the Count returns.
The Count stamps his letters, then excuses himself for private work.
Before leaving, the Count delivers a grave warning to the narrator: he must not fall asleep in any part of the castle other than his own assigned rooms.
He explains the castle is old, filled with memories, and that unwise sleep can lead to "bad dreams," finishing with a gruesome hand-washing gesture.
The narrator understands the implied threat, doubting any dream could be worse than his current reality.

events.text_segment:
When I had written my two letters I sat quiet, reading a book whilst the Count wrote several notes, referring as he wrote them to some books on his table. Then he took up my two and placed them with his own, and put by his writing materials, after which, the instant the door had closed behind him, I leaned over and looked at the letters, which were face down on the table. I felt no compunction in doing so, for under the circumstances I felt that I should protect myself in every way I could.
One of the letters was directed to Samuel F. Billington, No. 7, The Crescent, Whitby, another to Herr Leutner, Varna; the third was to Coutts & Co., London, and the fourth to Herren Klopstock & Billreuth, bankers, Buda-Pesth. The second and fourth were unsealed. I was just about to look at them when I saw the door-handle move. I sank back in my seat, having just had time to replace the letters as they had been and to resume my book before the Count, holding still another letter in his hand, entered the room. He took up the letters on the table and stamped them carefully, and then turning to me, said:—
“I trust you will forgive me, but I have much work to do in private this evening. You will, I hope, find all things as you wish.” At the door he turned, and after a moment’s pause said:—
“Let me advise you, my dear young friend—nay, let me warn you with all seriousness, that should you leave these rooms you will not by any chance go to sleep in any other part of the castle. It is old, and has many memories, and there are bad dreams for those who sleep unwisely. Be warned! Should sleep now or ever overcome you, or be like to do, then haste to your own chamber or to these rooms, for your rest will then be safe. But if you be not careful in this respect, then”—He finished his speech in a gruesome way, for he motioned with his hands as if he were washing them. I quite understood; my only doubt was as to whether any dream could be more terrible than the unnatural, horrible net of gloom and mystery which seemed closing around me.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: When I had written my two letters I sat quiet, reading a book whilst the Count wrote several notes, referring as he wrote them to some books on his table. I observed that he was very careful in his writing, and that he used a peculiar hand, which I could not read. When he had finished, he laid them all face downwards on the table, and then, after a moment's hesitation, he left the room. I was left alone, and I felt that I was in a position of great responsibility. I had no right to pry into the Count's affairs, but I could not help feeling that there was something in the way he handled those letters that was not quite natural. I was about to leave the room when I saw that one of the letters was not quite closed. I hesitated for a moment, and then, with a feeling of guilt, I opened it. The address was in the same peculiar hand, and was to Samuel F. Billington, Esq., of Whitby. I was about to close it again when the Count returned. He looked at me for a moment with a strange expression, and then, as if nothing had happened, he took up the letters and stamped them. He then said, in a low voice, 'You will not sleep in any part of the castle except your own room.' I looked at him in surprise, and he continued, 'This is an old castle, full of memories. If you sleep in any other part, you may have bad dreams.' He said this in a tone that made me shudder, and then, with a gesture of the hand that was almost a menace, he left the room. I sat for a long time after he had gone, trying to think what it all meant. I could not help feeling that there was something in the Count's manner that was not quite right. I had no doubt that he was a man of great power and influence, but I could not help feeling that there was something in his nature that was not quite human.

I started up, and in the dim light I saw the Count standing by the window, his face turned towards me. He looked at me with a strange, searching gaze, and then he said in a low voice, “You are not afraid of the dark, are you, Jonathan?” I could not answer him, for I was too much startled, and I could not tell whether he was speaking to me in jest or in earnest. I could not help feeling that he was a man of great knowledge and of great caution, and that he was not to be taken at his word. events.title: The Lizard on the Wall: A Glimpse of the Unholy
detailed_summary: The narrator reaffirms his growing dread but resolves not to fear sleeping where the Count is absent.
He places the crucifix above his bed for protection and hopes for dreamless rest.
After the Count leaves him, he goes to his room and then explores, seeking a view towards the South.
He feels a sense of freedom from the vast expanse, contrasting with the courtyard's darkness, yet it reinforces his imprisonment.
The nocturnal existence is wearing him down, making him jumpy and filled with horrible imaginings.
Looking out at the moonlit landscape, he momentarily finds peace in its beauty.
His attention is caught by movement below; he sees the Count's head emerge from a window in what he believes is the Count's own room.

Initially curious, his amusement turns to repulsion and terror as he witnesses the Count crawl down the sheer castle wall, face down, his cloak spreading like wings, moving with the agility of a lizard.
He struggles to believe his eyes, initially thinking it's a trick of the moonlight, but the reality is undeniable.
He is overwhelmed by dread and the feeling of inescapable terror.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Later.—I endorse the last words written, but this time there is no doubt in question.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I feel the dread of this horrible place overpowering me; I am in fear—in awful fear—and there is no escape for me; I am encompassed about with terrors that I dare not think of....

events.text_segment:
Later.—I endorse the last words written, but this time there is no doubt in question. I shall not fear to sleep in any place where he is not. I have placed the crucifix over the head of my bed—I imagine that my rest is thus freer from dreams; and there it shall remain.
When he left me I went to my room. After a little while, not hearing any sound, I came out and went up the stone stair to where I could look out towards the South. There was some sense of freedom in the vast expanse, inaccessible though it was to me, as compared with the narrow darkness of the courtyard. Looking out on this, I felt that I was indeed in prison, and I seemed to want a breath of fresh air, though it were of the night. I am beginning to feel this nocturnal existence tell on me. It is destroying my nerve. I start at my own shadow, and am full of all sorts of horrible imaginings. God knows that there is ground for my terrible fear in this accursed place! I looked out over the beautiful expanse, bathed in soft yellow moonlight till it was almost as light as day. In the soft light the distant hills became melted, and the shadows in the valleys and gorges of velvety blackness. The mere beauty seemed to cheer me; there was peace and comfort in every breath I drew. As I leaned from the window my eye was caught by something moving a storey below me, and somewhat to my left, where I imagined, from the order of the rooms, that the windows of the Count’s own room would look out. The window at which I stood was tall and deep, stone-mullioned, and though weatherworn, was still complete; but it was evidently many a day since the case had been there. I drew back behind the stonework, and looked carefully out.
What I saw was the Count’s head coming out from the window. I did not see the face, but I knew the man by the neck and the movement of his back and arms. In any case I could not mistake the hands which I had had so many opportunities of studying. I was at first interested and somewhat amused, for it is wonderful how small a matter will interest and amuse a man when he is a prisoner. But my very feelings changed to repulsion and terror when I saw the whole man slowly emerge from the window and begin to crawl down the castle wall over that dreadful abyss, face down with his cloak spreading out around him like great wings. At first I could not believe my eyes. I thought it was some trick of the moonlight, some weird effect of shadow; but I kept looking, and it could be no delusion. I saw the fingers and toes grasp the corners of the stones, worn clear of the mortar by the stress of years, and by thus using every projection and inequality move downwards with considerable speed, just as a lizard moves along a wall.
What manner of man is this, or what manner of creature is it in the semblance of man? I feel the dread of this horrible place overpowering me; I am in fear—in awful fear—and there is no escape for me; I am encompassed about with terrors that I dare not think of....

The Count is not in the house, and I am determined that I will not fear to sleep where he is not. I have placed the crucifix above my bed, and I hope for a dreamless rest. I have gone to my room, and I have looked out from the window, and I have seen the great expanse of the Carpathians, and I have felt the breath of freedom. But it is a freedom that is but a mockery, for I am still a prisoner in this castle of horrors. The night is wearing me down, and I am becoming a nervous wreck, filled with horrible imaginings. I looked out at the moonlit landscape, and for a moment I felt a strange peace, a sense of beauty in the cold, pale light. But then I saw something that made my blood run cold. I saw the Count's head appear at the window of the room I believe to be his own. At first, I thought it was a trick of the moonlight, but then I saw him begin to crawl down the sheer face of the castle wall, face downward, his cloak spreading out like the wings of some great bat. He moved with the agility of a lizard, and I could not take my eyes from the sight. I was filled with a sense of dread, a feeling of inescapable terror. I could not believe what I was seeing, but it was real, and I was helpless to do anything but watch.

events.title: A Glimmer of Hope: Exploring the Castle's Forbidden Chambers
detailed_summary: On May 15th, the narrator again observes the Count departing in his lizard-like manner, vanishing into an opening far below.
Believing the Count has left the castle, he decides to explore more thoroughly.
He finds all doors locked with new locks. The main entrance door is also locked, and the key is missing, likely in the Count's room.
He resolves to watch for an opportunity to get the key and escape.
Continuing his search, he finds a door at the top of a stairway that yields to pressure, its hinges having fallen.
With considerable effort, he forces the door open, entering a previously unknown wing of the castle, a storey lower and to the south.
This wing, likely once occupied by the castle's ladies, has more comfortable furniture, though covered in dust.
The large windows, unreachable from outside, offer views of a great precipice and a valley to the west.
Despite the brilliant moonlight, he feels a dread loneliness in this new space.
He finds a small oak table and decides to write in his diary there, reflecting on the clash between the nineteenth century and the enduring powers of past ages.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 15 May.—Once more have I seen the Count go out in his lizard fashion.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And yet, unless my senses deceive me, the old centuries had, and have, powers of their own which mere “modernity” cannot kill.

events.text_segment: 15 May.—Once more have I seen the Count go out in his lizard fashion. He moved downwards in a sidelong way, some hundred feet down, and a good deal to the left. He vanished into some hole or window. When his head had disappeared, I leaned out to try and see more, but without avail—the distance was too great to allow a proper angle of sight. I knew he had left the castle now, and thought to use the opportunity to explore more than I had dared to do as yet. I went back to the room, and taking a lamp, tried all the doors. They were all locked, as I had expected, and the locks were comparatively new; but I went down the stone stairs to the hall where I had entered originally. I found I could pull back the bolts easily enough and unhook the great chains; but the door was locked, and the key was gone! That key must be in the Count’s room; I must watch should his door be unlocked, so that I may get it and escape. I went on to make a thorough examination of the various stairs and passages, and to try the doors that opened from them. One or two small rooms near the hall were open, but there was nothing to see in them except old furniture, dusty with age and moth-eaten. At last, however, I found one door at the top of the stairway which, though it seemed to be locked, gave a little under pressure. I tried it harder, and found that it was not really locked, but that the resistance came from the fact that the hinges had fallen somewhat, and the heavy door rested on the floor. Here was an opportunity which I might not have again, so I exerted myself, and with many efforts forced it back so that I could enter. I was now in a wing of the castle further to the right than the rooms I knew and a storey lower down. From the windows I could see that the suite of rooms lay along to the south of the castle, the windows of the end room looking out both west and south. On the latter side, as well as to the former, there was a great precipice. The castle was built on the corner of a great rock, so that on three sides it was quite impregnable, and great windows were placed here where sling, or bow, or culverin could not reach, and consequently light and comfort, impossible to a position which had to be guarded, were secured. To the west was a great valley, and then, rising far away, great jagged mountain fastnesses, rising peak on peak, the sheer rock studded with mountain ash and thorn, whose roots clung in cracks and crevices and crannies of the stone. This was evidently the portion of the castle occupied by the ladies in bygone days, for the furniture had more air of comfort than any I had seen. The windows were curtainless, and the yellow moonlight, flooding in through the diamond panes, enabled one to see even colours, whilst it softened the wealth of dust which lay over all and disguised in some measure the ravages of time and the moth. My lamp seemed to be of little effect in the brilliant moonlight, but I was glad to have it with me, for there was a dread loneliness in the place which chilled my heart and made my nerves tremble. Still, it was better than living alone in the rooms which I had come to hate from the presence of the Count, and after trying a little to school my nerves, I found a soft quietude come over me. Here I am, sitting at a little oak table where in old times possibly some fair lady sat to pen, with much thought and many blushes, her ill-spelt love-letter, and writing in my diary in shorthand all that has happened since I closed it last. It is nineteenth century up-to-date with a vengeance. And yet, unless my senses deceive me, the old centuries had, and have, powers of their own which mere “modernity” cannot kill.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
15 May.—Once more have I seen the Count go out in his lizard fashion. He glided from the room, and I watched him as he disappeared through an opening far below, as if he had melted into the earth. I believe that he has left the castle for the present, and I have resolved to make a thorough search of the place, in the hope of finding some means of escape.

I have examined all the doors, and they are all locked with new locks, which I have not seen before. The great door of the castle is also locked, and the key is missing, which I suppose is in the Count's room. I must watch for an opportunity to get it, and then I will make my escape.

I have been exploring the castle, and I have found a door at the top of a stairway which yielded to pressure, the hinges having fallen. With some difficulty I forced it open, and I found myself in a part of the castle which I had not before seen. It is a story lower and to the south, and I think it must have been the part occupied by the ladies of the castle. The furniture is more comfortable than in the other parts, but it is all covered with dust. The windows are large, and I could not reach them from the outside, so I could not see what was beyond them. I looked out, and I saw a great precipice and a valley to the west. The moon was shining brightly, and I felt a strange loneliness in that place. I found a small oak table, and I have decided to write in my diary there. I have been thinking of the contrast between the nineteenth century and the old world, and I have been wondering how long the old powers will last.

events.title: Forbidden Slumber: A Nightmarish Vision of Three Women
detailed_summary: By the morning of May 16th, the narrator questions his sanity and clings to the hope of not going mad.
He reflects that the Count, despite being a source of foulness, is paradoxically his only source of safety while he serves the Count's purpose.
He finds solace in his diary, likening his need to record events to Hamlet's.
The Count's earlier warning about sleeping elsewhere now frightens him more, realizing the hold the Count has over him.
Feeling sleepy after writing, he defiantly chooses to disobey the Count's warning, drawn by the soothing moonlight and the sense of freedom in the newly discovered room.
He prepares a couch to sleep on, positioning it to enjoy the view, and falls asleep, or into a state indistinguishable from reality.
He becomes aware he is not alone; three young women, distinguished by their attire and demeanor, are in the room.
He notices they cast no shadows despite the moonlight behind them, leading him to think he might be dreaming.
Two are dark-haired with aquiline noses and piercing, almost red eyes, resembling the Count. The third is exceptionally fair with golden hair and sapphire-like eyes.
He feels a vague, fearful recognition of the fair woman.
All three possess brilliant white teeth that contrast sharply with their voluptuous red lips.
He experiences a conflicting mix of unease, longing, and deadly fear, feeling a wicked desire for them to kiss him. He notes this truth with hesitation, fearing Mina's potential pain.

events.text_segment:
Later: the Morning of 16 May.—God preserve my sanity, for to this I am reduced. Safety and the assurance of safety are things of the past. Whilst I live on here there is but one thing to hope for, that I may not go mad, if, indeed, I be not mad already. If I be sane, then surely it is maddening to think that of all the foul things that lurk in this hateful place the Count is the least dreadful to me; that to him alone I can look for safety, even though this be only whilst I can serve his purpose. Great God! merciful God! Let me be calm, for out of that way lies madness indeed. I begin to get new lights on certain things which have puzzled me. Up to now I never quite knew what Shakespeare meant when he made Hamlet say:—
“My tablets! quick, my tablets!
’Tis meet that I put it down,” etc.,
for now, feeling as though my own brain were unhinged or as if the shock had come which must end in its undoing, I turn to my diary for repose. The habit of entering accurately must help to soothe me.
The Count’s mysterious warning frightened me at the time; it frightens me more now when I think of it, for in future he has a fearful hold upon me. I shall fear to doubt what he may say!
When I had written in my diary and had fortunately replaced the book and pen in my pocket I felt sleepy. The Count’s warning came into my mind, but I took a pleasure in disobeying it. The sense of sleep was upon me, and with it the obstinacy which sleep brings as outrider. The soft moonlight soothed, and the wide expanse without gave a sense of freedom which refreshed me. I determined not to return to-night to the gloom-haunted rooms, but to sleep here, where, of old, ladies had sat and sung and lived sweet lives whilst their gentle breasts were sad for their menfolk away in the midst of remorseless wars. I drew a great couch out of its place near the corner, so that as I lay, I could look at the lovely view to east and south, and unthinking of and uncaring for the dust, composed myself for sleep. I suppose I must have fallen asleep; I hope so, but I fear, for all that followed was startlingly real—so real that now sitting here in the broad, full sunlight of the morning, I cannot in the least believe that it was all sleep.
I was not alone. The room was the same, unchanged in any way since I came into it; I could see along the floor, in the brilliant moonlight, my own footsteps marked where I had disturbed the long accumulation of dust. In the moonlight opposite me were three young women, ladies by their dress and manner. I thought at the time that I must be dreaming when I saw them, for, though the moonlight was behind them, they threw no shadow on the floor. They came close to me, and looked at me for some time, and then whispered together. Two were dark, and had high aquiline noses, like the Count, and great dark, piercing eyes that seemed to be almost red when contrasted with the pale yellow moon. The other was fair, as fair as can be, with great wavy masses of golden hair and eyes like pale sapphires. I seemed somehow to know her face, and to know it in connection with some dreamy fear, but I could not recollect at the moment how or where. All three had brilliant white teeth that shone like pearls against the ruby of their voluptuous lips. There was something about them that made me uneasy, some longing and at the same time some deadly fear. I felt in my heart a wicked, burning desire that they would kiss me with those red lips. It is not good to note this down, lest some day it should meet Mina’s eyes and cause her pain; but it is the truth.

**Chapter III: Jonathan Harker’s Journal—continued**

*Later: the Morning of 16 May.—God preserve my sanity, for to this I am reduced.*

I find myself in a state of mind that borders on the absurd, yet I cling to the fragile thread of reason. The Count, that foul and repulsive creature, is the only tether I have to safety. I serve him, and yet I am bound to him in a way I cannot yet comprehend. I write these words not for posterity, but for my own sake, as Hamlet once did, to keep the madness at bay.

The Count warned me not to sleep elsewhere, and now I understand the weight of that warning. It is not a mere caution—it is a command, and I am its subject. I feel the pull of his will like a noose tightening around my neck, and yet I resist. I am tired, and the moonlight is soft and inviting. I find a room, newly discovered, and prepare a couch to rest upon. I position it so that I may gaze out at the world beyond the window, and I fall into a sleep—or perhaps a dream so vivid it is indistinguishable from waking.

I am not alone. Three young women stand in the room, their silhouettes framed by the pale light. They are unlike any I have ever seen. Two are dark-haired, with aquiline noses and eyes that gleam like rubies in the dimness. The third is a vision of fairness, her golden hair cascading like sunlight, her eyes the color of sapphires. I feel a strange recognition stir within me, a nameless fear that clings to the fair one in particular.

They cast no shadows. Not one. And yet, they are real. Or perhaps I am dreaming. Their teeth are white as bone, their lips red as blood. I feel a terrible longing, a desire that is both wicked and irresistible. I want them to kiss me. I want to be consumed by them. And yet, I shudder at the thought of Mina, and the pain this truth might bring her.

I write this with trembling hands, for I fear what I am becoming.

events.title: The Vampiresses' Kiss: A Dance of Desire and Dread
detailed_summary: The three women whisper amongst themselves and then laugh, a sound described as silvery and musical yet unnervingly hard, like the tingling of water-glasses.
The fair-haired woman, after some coquettish hesitation and encouragement from the others, is designated to approach the narrator first.
One dark woman states it is her right to begin, while the other remarks on his youth and strength, implying there are kisses for all of them.
The narrator lies still, observing through his eyelashes, consumed by an agony of delightful anticipation.
The fair woman approaches and leans over him, her breath feeling honey-sweet yet carrying a bitter, offensive undertone reminiscent of blood.
Afraid to open his eyes fully, he watches as she kneels and bends closer, her expression one of deliberate, gloating voluptuousness that is both thrilling and repulsive.
She arches her neck and licks her lips like an animal, the moisture on her scarlet lips and red tongue visible as it touches her sharp white teeth.
Her head descends lower, her lips moving past his mouth and chin, seemingly aiming for his throat.
She pauses, and he hears the sound of her tongue against her teeth and lips, feeling her hot breath on his neck.
His throat tingles in anticipation as he feels the soft touch of her lips and the hard pressure of two sharp teeth, just making contact.
He closes his eyes in a state of languorous ecstasy, his heart pounding, awaiting what is to come.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I closed my eyes in a languorous ecstasy and waited—waited with beating heart.

events.text_segment:
They whispered together, and then they all three laughed—such a silvery, musical laugh, but as hard as though the sound never could have come through the softness of human lips. It was like the intolerable, tingling sweetness of water-glasses when played on by a cunning hand. The fair girl shook her head coquettishly, and the other two urged her on. One said:—
“Go on! You are first, and we shall follow; yours is the right to begin.” The other added:—
“He is young and strong; there are kisses for us all.” I lay quiet, looking out under my eyelashes in an agony of delightful anticipation. The fair girl advanced and bent over me till I could feel the movement of her breath upon me. Sweet it was in one sense, honey-sweet, and sent the same tingling through the nerves as her voice, but with a bitter underlying the sweet, a bitter offensiveness, as one smells in blood.
I was afraid to raise my eyelids, but looked out and saw perfectly under the lashes. The girl went on her knees, and bent over me, simply gloating. There was a deliberate voluptuousness which was both thrilling and repulsive, and as she arched her neck she actually licked her lips like an animal, till I could see in the moonlight the moisture shining on the scarlet lips and on the red tongue as it lapped the white sharp teeth. Lower and lower went her head as the lips went below the range of my mouth and chin and seemed about to fasten on my throat. Then she paused, and I could hear the churning sound of her tongue as it licked her teeth and lips, and could feel the hot breath on my neck. Then the skin of my throat began to tingle as one’s flesh does when the hand that is to tickle it approaches nearer—nearer. I could feel the soft, shivering touch of the lips on the super-sensitive skin of my throat, and the hard dents of two sharp teeth, just touching and pausing there. I closed my eyes in a languorous ecstasy and waited—waited with beating heart.

events.title: Master's Fury: The Count Reclaims His Prize
detailed_summary: A new sensation abruptly interrupts the narrator's state; he becomes aware of the Count's presence, filled with immense fury.
Opening his eyes, he sees the Count's powerful hand seize the fair woman's neck, drawing her back with tremendous force. Her eyes are transformed with fury, teeth champing, and cheeks blazing red.
The Count's wrath is described as beyond anything imaginable, his eyes blazing with a lurid red light, his face deathly pale and features hard as wires.
He hurls the woman away and imperiously gestures the others back, similar to how he controlled the wolves.
In a low, cutting voice, he forbids them from touching the narrator, declaring, "This man belongs to me!" and warning them against meddling.
The fair woman mockingly retorts that the Count has never loved. The other women join in a mirthless, hard, soulless laughter.

The Count, after looking at the narrator, softly whispers that he too can love, and promises the women they can kiss the narrator at will once he is "done with him." He then orders them to go, stating he must awaken the narrator for work.
One woman asks if they are to have nothing that night, pointing to a bag the Count had thrown down, which shows signs of something living within.
The Count nods in affirmation. One woman opens the bag, and the narrator hears a gasp and a low wail like a half-smothered child.
The women close in around the bag as the narrator watches in horror. They then disappear, along with the bag, seemingly fading into the moonlight and out the window.
Overcome by the horror of the scene, the narrator sinks into unconsciousness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But at that instant, another sensation swept through me as quick as lightning.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the horror overcame me, and I sank down unconscious.

events.text_segment:
But at that instant, another sensation swept through me as quick as lightning. I was conscious of the presence of the Count, and of his being as if lapped in a storm of fury. As my eyes opened involuntarily I saw his strong hand grasp the slender neck of the fair woman and with giant’s power draw it back, the blue eyes transformed with fury, the white teeth champing with rage, and the fair cheeks blazing red with passion. But the Count! Never did I imagine such wrath and fury, even to the demons of the pit. His eyes were positively blazing. The red light in them was lurid, as if the flames of hell-fire blazed behind them. His face was deathly pale, and the lines of it were hard like drawn wires; the thick eyebrows that met over the nose now seemed like a heaving bar of white-hot metal. With a fierce sweep of his arm, he hurled the woman from him, and then motioned to the others, as though he were beating them back; it was the same imperious gesture that I had seen used to the wolves. In a voice which, though low and almost in a whisper seemed to cut through the air and then ring round the room he said:—
“How dare you touch him, any of you? How dare you cast eyes on him when I had forbidden it? Back, I tell you all! This man belongs to me! Beware how you meddle with him, or you’ll have to deal with me.” The fair girl, with a laugh of ribald coquetry, turned to answer him:—
“You yourself never loved; you never love!” On this the other women joined, and such a mirthless, hard, soulless laughter rang through the room that it almost made me faint to hear; it seemed like the pleasure of fiends. Then the Count turned, after looking at my face attentively, and said in a soft whisper:—
“Yes, I too can love; you yourselves can tell it from the past. Is it not so? Well, now I promise you that when I am done with him you shall kiss him at your will. Now go! go! I must awaken him, for there is work to be done.”
“Are we to have nothing to-night?” said one of them, with a low laugh, as she pointed to the bag which he had thrown upon the floor, and which moved as though there were some living thing within it. For answer he nodded his head. One of the women jumped forward and opened it. If my ears did not deceive me there was a gasp and a low wail, as of a half-smothered child. The women closed round, whilst I was aghast with horror; but as I looked they disappeared, and with them the dreadful bag. There was no door near them, and they could not have passed me without my noticing. They simply seemed to fade into the rays of the moonlight and pass out through the window, for I could see outside the dim, shadowy forms for a moment before they entirely faded away.
Then the horror overcame me, and I sank down unconscious.

It was as if some one had touched me with a red-hot iron, and I started up with a cry. The Count was there, close to me, and his face was a perfect picture of fury. His eyes were bloodshot, and his face was as pale as a sheet, the features drawn and rigid as if they were of wire. In his powerful hand he had seized the fair woman by the neck, and was drawing her back with a force that seemed to tear her from the ground. Her eyes were full of fury, her teeth champing, her cheeks blazing with a red that was almost unnatural. The Count, with a terrible gesture, flung her from him, and with a wave of his hand sent the others back, just as he had done the wolves. In a low, cutting voice he said, 'This man belongs to me!' and there was a menace in his tone that made the women recoil. 'You shall not touch him,' he said, 'for he is mine, and I have bought him with my blood.' The fair woman laughed mockingly. 'You have never loved,' she said. The others joined in a laugh that was hard and soulless, like the creaking of iron. The Count looked at me, and his face softened for a moment. 'I can love,' he said softly, 'and I do love. When I have done with him, you may kiss him as you will.' Then he turned to the women and said, 'Go, I must awaken the man for work.' One of them, the dark one, hesitated. 'And we are to have nothing to-night?' she asked, pointing to the bag which the Count had flung down. 'Yes,' he said, and she opened it. I heard a gasp, and then a low wail, like that of a child half-smothered. The women closed in around the bag, and I saw them lift it, and then they were gone, as if they had faded into the moonlight and out of the window. I sank back into the chair, and the world swirled around me, and I knew no more.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But at that instant, another sensation swept through me as quick as lightning. It was a feeling of cold, of a chill that ran through my very soul, as if the breath of death had touched me. I staggered back, my heart pounding in my chest, and looked around in alarm. The room, which had been warm and filled with the soft glow of the fire, now seemed cold and oppressive. The shadows in the corners seemed to move, and the air was thick with an unnatural stillness. I could not explain it, but I knew that something was wrong—something was watching me. I turned sharply, expecting to see some intruder, some unknown presence, but the room was empty. And yet, the feeling did not leave me. It clung to me like a shroud, and I could not shake it off. I looked down at my hands, and they were trembling. I had never felt such a thing before. It was not fear, not exactly, but something deeper, something more primal. It was as if I had been touched by the very essence of evil, and it had left its mark upon me. I tried to steady myself, to think rationally, but my mind was clouded. I could not remember if I had locked the door, if I had drawn the curtains, if I had left the window open. I moved toward the door, my hand on the knob, and hesitated. I did not want to go out into the night, into the darkness that now seemed to press in on me from all sides. I could hear the wind outside, howling like a beast in pain, and the trees creaking as if they, too, were afraid. I turned back to the fire, hoping that its warmth would drive away the chill that had settled in my bones. But the fire, which had been so bright and cheerful only moments before, now seemed dim and flickering, as if it, too, were afraid. I sat down, trying to gather my thoughts, but my mind was a whirlwind of confusion and fear. I could not shake the feeling that I was being watched, that something was waiting for me in the darkness. I looked at the clock on the wall. It was late, far later than I had intended to stay up. I should have gone to bed, but I could not bring myself to leave the room. I was afraid of what I might find in the hallway, afraid of what might be waiting for me in the shadows. I tried to tell myself that it was just my imagination, that I was tired and overwrought, but I could not convince myself. I had felt something, something real, something evil. And I knew that it was not going to leave me alone. I sat there, in the cold and the silence, waiting for the feeling to pass, but it did not. It remained, a constant presence, a whisper in the back of my mind, a warning that I could not ignore. I did not know what it was, but I knew that it was not human. And I knew that it was not going to let me go.

events.title: Uncertain Awakening and Lingering Dread
detailed_summary: Jonathan awakens in his bed, questioning whether the previous night's horrifying encounter was a dream or reality, suspecting the Count transported him.
He observes subtle signs, like his clothes being uncharacteristically folded and his watch unwound, which could indicate either the Count's intervention or his own disoriented state.
He resolves to seek definitive proof of what transpired.
He finds a small comfort in the fact that his pockets, containing his diary, were undisturbed, suggesting the Count, if responsible, was hurried.
He views his room, once a place of fear, as a temporary refuge from the terrifying women he believes are eager to prey on him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I AWOKE in my own bed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As I look round this room, although it has been to me so full of fear, it is now a sort of sanctuary, for nothing can be more dreadful than those awful women, who were—who are—waiting to suck my blood.

events.text_segment: I AWOKE in my own bed. If it be that I had not dreamt, the Count must have carried me here. I tried to satisfy myself on the subject, but could not arrive at any unquestionable result. To be sure, there were certain small evidences, such as that my clothes were folded and laid by in a manner which was not my habit. My watch was still unwound, and I am rigorously accustomed to wind it the last thing before going to bed, and many such details. But these things are no proof, for they may have been evidences that my mind was not as usual, and, from some cause or another, I had certainly been much upset. I must watch for proof. Of one thing I am glad: if it was that the Count carried me here and undressed me, he must have been hurried in his task, for my pockets are intact. I am sure this diary would have been a mystery to him which he would not have brooked. He would have taken or destroyed it. As I look round this room, although it has been to me so full of fear, it is now a sort of sanctuary, for nothing can be more dreadful than those awful women, who were—who are—waiting to suck my blood.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I AWOKE in my own bed. For a moment I could not remember where I was, and then the memory of the terrible night came back to me in a flood. Was it a dream or reality? I had been in the Count's house, had seen the awful things, had felt the cold hand of the Count on my shoulder, and had heard his voice, low and terrible, bidding me go. And yet here I am in my own room, in my own bed, and the morning is bright and cheerful. I must have been dreaming, but I cannot believe it. The Count has a way of making things seem real, and I have a feeling that I was not dreaming. My clothes are folded neatly, and my watch is unwound. I do not remember doing either. Was it the Count who did it? Or was I so tired that I did it in a daze and do not remember? I must find out. I must find some proof, some sign that will tell me whether I was in the Count's house or not. I feel that I am in a place of safety for the moment, but I know that the women are still out there, and I know that they are looking for me. I must be careful. I must not let them find me. I must not let the Count find me. I must find some way to get out of this place and away from them. I must find some way to get back to England and to my wife. I must find some way to get rid of the Count. I must find some way to make him leave this place and never come back. I must find some way to make him die.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I AWOKE in my own bed. The morning light filtered through the curtains, casting a soft glow across the room. I lay there for a moment, trying to recall the dream that had brought me here. It had been vivid—so real, in fact, that I could still feel the chill of the castle walls and the echo of distant footsteps. I had been in Transylvania again, in that cursed Carfax Abbey, where the shadows seemed to move of their own accord. I could almost hear the Count's voice, low and melodic, promising things I dared not name. I sat up, rubbing my temples, trying to shake the lingering sense of unease. The journal was still on my desk, its pages filled with my frantic scrawls and the notes of my companions. Had it all been a dream, or was there some truth buried in those pages? I glanced at the mirror across the room. My reflection stared back, but for a fleeting moment, I thought I saw something else—something ancient and hungry—just behind my eyes. I blinked, and it was gone. I rose, dressing quickly, my mind racing. I needed to speak with Van Helsing. There were things we had not yet uncovered, secrets that still lay hidden in the darkness. I could not shake the feeling that the battle was not over. The Count was still out there, and he was waiting.

events.title: Grim Confirmation of Reality
detailed_summary: Driven by the need for certainty, Jonathan revisits the room from his horrifying experience.
He discovers the door at the top of the stairs is closed and shows signs of being forcefully shut, with splintered woodwork.
He observes that although the lock's bolt wasn't engaged, the door is secured from within.
This evidence solidifies his fear that the encounter was not a dream, compelling him to accept this grim reality and plan accordingly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 18 May.—I have been down to look at that room again in daylight, for I must know the truth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I fear it was no dream, and must act on this surmise.

events.text_segment: 18 May.—I have been down to look at that room again in daylight, for I must know the truth. When I got to the doorway at the top of the stairs I found it closed. It had been so forcibly driven against the jamb that part of the woodwork was splintered. I could see that the bolt of the lock had not been shot, but the door is fastened from the inside. I fear it was no dream, and must act on this surmise.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 18 May.—I have been down to look at that room again in daylight, for I must know the truth. The door at the top of the stairs is closed, and I can see that it has been shut with violence, for the woodwork is splintered and the hinges creak as if in pain. I tried the handle, but it would not yield, and though the bolt was not drawn, the door is fastened from within. I can feel the chill of the room through the keyhole, and I know that what I saw and heard was no dream. I must be prepared for what is to come.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: 18 May.—I have been down to look at that room again in daylight, for I must know the truth. It is quite as I thought. The window is high and strong, and the door is solid. There is no way in or out except by the door or the window. And yet, I am sure that something has been in the room. The air is heavy, and the bed is disarranged, though I made it carefully last night.

events.title: Coerced Correspondence and Foreboding
detailed_summary: Jonathan acknowledges his entrapment by the Count.

The Count, with deceptive politeness, instructs Jonathan to write three letters: one stating his work is nearing completion and he'll leave in a few days, another announcing his departure the next morning, and a third confirming his arrival in Bistritz.
Jonathan feels compelled to comply, recognizing that open defiance against the powerful Count would be foolish and potentially fatal.
He understands the Count's motive: Jonathan knows too much and must be silenced; prolonging his stay is his only hope for an escape opportunity.
He perceives a simmering anger in the Count, reminiscent of the Count's earlier violent reaction to one of the women.

The Count rationalizes the request by citing infrequent and unreliable postal services, claiming the letters will reassure Jonathan's friends, and promising to hold back the later letters if Jonathan's stay extends.
Feigning agreement, Jonathan inquires about the dates for the letters.
The Count specifies June 12th, June 19th, and June 29th, leading Jonathan to a chilling realization of his perceived lifespan.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 19 May.—I am surely in the toils.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: God help me!

events.text_segment:
19 May.—I am surely in the toils. Last night the Count asked me in the suavest tones to write three letters, one saying that my work here was nearly done, and that I should start for home within a few days, another that I was starting on the next morning from the time of the letter, and the third that I had left the castle and arrived at Bistritz. I would fain have rebelled, but felt that in the present state of things it would be madness to quarrel openly with the Count whilst I am so absolutely in his power; and to refuse would be to excite his suspicion and to arouse his anger. He knows that I know too much, and that I must not live, lest I be dangerous to him; my only chance is to prolong my opportunities. Something may occur which will give me a chance to escape. I saw in his eyes something of that gathering wrath which was manifest when he hurled that fair woman from him. He explained to me that posts were few and uncertain, and that my writing now would ensure ease of mind to my friends; and he assured me with so much impressiveness that he would countermand the later letters, which would be held over at Bistritz until due time in case chance would admit of my prolonging my stay, that to oppose him would have been to create new suspicion. I therefore pretended to fall in with his views, and asked him what dates I should put on the letters. He calculated a minute, and then said:—
“The first should be June 12, the second June 19, and the third June 29.”
I know now the span of my life. God help me!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
19 May.—I am surely in the toils. The Count has played his game well, and I have been the dupe. I have seen the castle, and I have seen the Count's power. I am a prisoner here, and I must be very careful how I act. I have no doubt that he is watching me, and that every step I take is known to him. I must be cautious, and I must not let my fear show. I must try to keep my wits about me, and to find some way of escape.

20 May.—The Count came to me this morning, and with his usual politeness, he asked me to write three letters. The first is to say that my work is nearly done, and that I shall leave in a few days. The second is to say that I shall leave to-morrow morning. The third is to say that I have arrived in Bistritz. I must write them all, and I must write them in such a way that they shall not be suspected. I know that the Count is a man of great power, and that it would be folly to oppose him. I must do as he bids me, and I must do it well. I know that he is angry with me, and that he is watching me closely. I can see it in his eyes, and I can feel it in the air. I must not let him see that I know his game. I must play my part as well as I can.

21 May.—I have written the letters, and I have given them to the Count. He has read them, and he has smiled. I think he is satisfied. I think he believes that I am a man of my word, and that I shall not try to escape. I think he believes that I am a man who will do as he bids me. I think he believes that I am a man who will not try to tell the world what I have seen. I think he believes that I am a man who will not try to stop him. I think he believes that I am a man who will not try to save myself. I think he believes that I am a man who will not try to live.

events.title: Failed Attempt to Communicate and Heightened Imprisonment
detailed_summary: Jonathan sees a glimmer of hope for escape or communication with the arrival of a band of Szgany (gipsies) encamped in the castle courtyard.
He notes their unique status in the region, often attached to nobles, fearless, and speaking their own language.
He decides to write letters and try to convince the Szgany to post them, initiating contact through his window, which they acknowledge with bows and signs he doesn't understand.

He pens his letters: one to Mina in shorthand explaining his predicament without full horrifying details, and one to Mr. Hawkins asking him to contact Mina, hoping the shorthand will protect his secrets if the letters are intercepted.
He throws the letters with a gold coin through his window bars, making signs for them to be posted; a Szgany man receives them with a bow.
Later, the Count appears with two letters, claiming the Szgany gave them to him.

He opens one, addressed to Hawkins from Jonathan, and then the other, which is Mina's letter. Upon seeing the shorthand symbols, his face darkens with rage, calling it an outrage. He burns Mina's letter and envelope as it is unsigned.
The Count then calmly states he will send Hawkins' letter, feigning respect for Jonathan's correspondence and apologizing for breaking the seal, offering a new envelope.
Jonathan silently redresses the letter. After the Count leaves, Jonathan hears the key turn in his door and confirms he is locked in.

The Count returns later, cheerful, notices Jonathan had slept, and advises him to rest, claiming he has much work. Jonathan goes to his room and sleeps soundly, attributing it to the calmness of despair.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 28 May.—There is a chance of escape, or at any rate of being able to send word home.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Despair has its own calms.

events.text_segment:
28 May.—There is a chance of escape, or at any rate of being able to send word home. A band of Szgany have come to the castle, and are encamped in the courtyard. These Szgany are gipsies; I have notes of them in my book. They are peculiar to this part of the world, though allied to the ordinary gipsies all the world over. There are thousands of them in Hungary and Transylvania, who are almost outside all law. They attach themselves as a rule to some great noble or boyar, and call themselves by his name. They are fearless and without religion, save superstition, and they talk only their own varieties of the Romany tongue.
I shall write some letters home, and shall try to get them to have them posted. I have already spoken them through my window to begin acquaintanceship. They took their hats off and made obeisance and many signs, which, however, I could not understand any more than I could their spoken language....
I have written the letters. Mina’s is in shorthand, and I simply ask Mr. Hawkins to communicate with her. To her I have explained my situation, but without the horrors which I may only surmise. It would shock and frighten her to death were I to expose my heart to her. Should the letters not carry, then the Count shall not yet know my secret or the extent of my knowledge....
I have given the letters; I threw them through the bars of my window with a gold piece, and made what signs I could to have them posted. The man who took them pressed them to his heart and bowed, and then put them in his cap. I could do no more. I stole back to the study, and began to read. As the Count did not come in, I have written here....
The Count has come. He sat down beside me, and said in his smoothest voice as he opened two letters:—
“The Szgany has given me these, of which, though I know not whence they come, I shall, of course, take care. See!”—he must have looked at it—“one is from you, and to my friend Peter Hawkins; the other”—here he caught sight of the strange symbols as he opened the envelope, and the dark look came into his face, and his eyes blazed wickedly—“the other is a vile thing, an outrage upon friendship and hospitality! It is not signed. Well! so it cannot matter to us.” And he calmly held letter and envelope in the flame of the lamp till they were consumed. Then he went on:—
“The letter to Hawkins—that I shall, of course, send on, since it is yours. Your letters are sacred to me. Your pardon, my friend, that unknowingly I did break the seal. Will you not cover it again?” He held out the letter to me, and with a courteous bow handed me a clean envelope. I could only redirect it and hand it to him in silence. When he went out of the room I could hear the key turn softly. A minute later I went over and tried it, and the door was locked.
When, an hour or two after, the Count came quietly into the room, his coming awakened me, for I had gone to sleep on the sofa. He was very courteous and very cheery in his manner, and seeing that I had been sleeping, he said:—
“So, my friend, you are tired? Get to bed. There is the surest rest. I may not have the pleasure to talk to-night, since there are many labours to me; but you will sleep, I pray.” I passed to my room and went to bed, and, strange to say, slept without dreaming. Despair has its own calms.

events.title: Discovery of Stolen Necessities
detailed_summary: Upon waking, Jonathan intends to gather writing materials from his bag for potential future use.
He is shocked to find that every piece of paper, including his notes, travel memoranda, and letter of credit, has vanished.
A further search reveals that his travelling suit, overcoat, and rug are also missing from his portmanteau and wardrobe.
He perceives these disappearances as part of a new, ominous plan by the Count.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This looked like some new scheme of villainy....

events.text_segment:
31 May.—This morning when I woke I thought I would provide myself with some paper and envelopes from my bag and keep them in my pocket, so that I might write in case I should get an opportunity, but again a surprise, again a shock!
Every scrap of paper was gone, and with it all my notes, my memoranda, relating to railways and travel, my letter of credit, in fact all that might be useful to me were I once outside the castle. I sat and pondered awhile, and then some thought occurred to me, and I made search of my portmanteau and in the wardrobe where I had placed my clothes.
The suit in which I had travelled was gone, and also my overcoat and rug; I could find no trace of them anywhere. This looked like some new scheme of villainy....

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 31 May.—This morning when I woke I thought I would provide myself with some paper and envelopes from my bag and keep them in my pocket, so that I might write in case I should get an opportunity, but again a surprise, again a shock! My bag was there, but it was empty—absolutely empty! Not a scrap of paper, not a single letter, not the memorandum of my journey, not the letter of credit, not even the little notebook in which I have been keeping my diary—nothing, nothing at all! I turned it out, I shook it, I searched it, but in vain. Then I went to my portmanteau and wardrobe, and there I found that my travelling suit, my overcoat, and my rug had all disappeared. I was in a state of the greatest consternation. What could it mean? Who could have done it? I had locked my door, and I was quite sure no one had entered. It was as if the things had vanished of themselves. I could not understand it, but I felt that it was part of some new and terrible plan of the Count’s. I was afraid to go out, afraid to remain, afraid of everything. I felt as if I were in a trap, and that the Count was playing with me as a cat plays with a mouse. I could not sleep, I could not think, I could not do anything. I was in a state of the greatest distress.

I had no bag, and the clothes I wore were not mine. I was in a strange room, and the man who came in to see me was a stranger. I asked him where I was, and he said, 'In the Castle of Dracula.' I could not believe my ears, and I asked again, and he repeated it. I was in the hands of the Count!

events.title: Arrival of Workers and Ignored Pleas for Help
detailed_summary: Jonathan hears the arrival of wagons and horses, sparking a moment of hope.
He observes two large wagons, each drawn by eight horses, driven by Slovaks in distinctive attire, carrying long staves.
He attempts to go downstairs to meet them, hoping the main hall might be open, but finds his own door is fastened from the outside.
He then rushes to the window and calls out to the Slovaks.
They initially look up at him, but after the Szgany "hetman" intervenes and says something that makes them laugh, they pointedly ignore all his subsequent cries and entreaties.
The wagons are revealed to contain large, empty square boxes with rope handles, which the Slovaks unload and stack in the courtyard.
After being paid by the Szgany, the Slovaks depart, their whip cracks fading into the distance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 17 June.—This morning, as I was sitting on the edge of my bed cudgelling my brains, I heard without a cracking of whips and pounding and scraping of horses’ feet up the rocky path beyond the courtyard.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Shortly afterwards, I heard the cracking of their whips die away in the distance.

events.text_segment:
17 June.—This morning, as I was sitting on the edge of my bed cudgelling my brains, I heard without a cracking of whips and pounding and scraping of horses’ feet up the rocky path beyond the courtyard. With joy I hurried to the window, and saw drive into the yard two great leiter-wagons, each drawn by eight sturdy horses, and at the head of each pair a Slovak, with his wide hat, great nail-studded belt, dirty sheepskin, and high boots. They had also their long staves in hand. I ran to the door, intending to descend and try and join them through the main hall, as I thought that way might be opened for them. Again a shock: my door was fastened on the outside.
Then I ran to the window and cried to them. They looked up at me stupidly and pointed, but just then the “hetman” of the Szgany came out, and seeing them pointing to my window, said something, at which they laughed. Henceforth no effort of mine, no piteous cry or agonised entreaty, would make them even look at me. They resolutely turned away. The leiter-wagons contained great, square boxes, with handles of thick rope; these were evidently empty by the ease with which the Slovaks handled them, and by their resonance as they were roughly moved. When they were all unloaded and packed in a great heap in one corner of the yard, the Slovaks were given some money by the Szgany, and spitting on it for luck, lazily went each to his horse’s head. Shortly afterwards, I heard the cracking of their whips die away in the distance.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 17 June.—This morning, as I was sitting on the edge of my bed cudgelling my brains, I heard without a cracking of whips and pounding and scraping of horses’ feet up the rocky path beyond the courtyard. I sprang up, for I thought perhaps the Count had gone out, and that I might have a chance of escape. I hurried to the door, but it was fastened on the outside, and I could not open it. I ran to the window and looked out. There were two large wagons, each drawn by eight horses, and driven by Slovaks in long sheepskin coats and caps with earlaps. They had long staves, and looked very fierce. I called out to them, and waved my hand, but they only looked up at me and laughed. Then a man who was standing by, dressed in a long black coat, came forward and said something to them, and they laughed again, and then went on with their work. I could see that they were unloading large square boxes with rope handles, and stacking them in the courtyard. When they had finished, they were paid by the man in the black coat, and then drove off, the whips cracking and the horses pounding down the rocky path. I watched them go, and then I turned back to my room, and sat down and tried to think what I could do next.

I ran to the window and looked out. There were two large wagons, each drawn by eight horses, and driven by Slovaks in long sheepskin coats and caps with earlaps. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: 17 June.—This morning, as I was sitting on the edge of my bed cudgelling my brains, I heard without a cracking of whips and pounding and scraping of horses’ feet up the rocky path beyond the courtyard. I looked out of the window and saw a long line of carriages and wagons, with horses in all sorts of harness, coming slowly up the hill. They were led by a man on horseback, who seemed to be in command, and behind him came a number of men on foot, armed and looking very much like soldiers. I was just wondering what it could be, when the door of my room was thrown open and a man entered. He was a tall, broad-shouldered fellow, with a heavy moustache and a very red face. He introduced himself as Count Dracula, and he was most cordial and pleasant. He said that he had heard of my coming and had sent for me, and that he was very glad to see me. He spoke excellent English, and I was surprised at the ease with which he used it. He said that he had been in England before, and that he had many friends there. He invited me to walk with him, and I accepted. We went out into the courtyard, where the carriages were still coming in, and he told me that he was bringing over a great many things from his castle in Transylvania. He said that he was going to settle in England, and that he had bought a house in London. I was very much interested, and I asked him many questions, but he was very vague in his answers. I could not help feeling that there was something strange about him, but I could not say what it was. I only know that I felt a little uneasy in his presence, and that I was glad when the evening came and I could go to bed.

events.title: The Count's Impersonation and a Terrifying Spectral Encounter
detailed_summary: Jonathan, sensing activity, watches from his south-facing window after the Count locks himself in his room. He suspects the Szgany are engaged in some work within the castle.
He is shocked to see the Count emerge from his own window, dressed in Jonathan's stolen travelling clothes and carrying the bag previously seen with the women.
He deduces the Count's scheme: to be seen in Jonathan's attire in towns, thereby creating false evidence of Jonathan's movements and attributing any of the Count's misdeeds to him.
This realization fills Jonathan with rage at his helpless imprisonment.
While watching for the Count's return, he notices tiny dust-like specks in the moonlight, which begin to whirl and cluster, inducing a calm, hypnotic state.
A distant, piteous howling of dogs rouses him, and he struggles against the encroaching hypnosis as the dust motes seem to take phantom shapes.
Fully awakening, he screams and flees as the shapes materialize into the three ghostly women he is fated for.

He retreats to the safety of his lamp-lit room. Hours later, he hears a brief, sharp, suppressed wail from the Count's room, followed by an unnerving silence. He tries his door, finds it locked, and weeps in despair.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 24 June, before morning.—Last night the Count left me early, and locked himself into his own room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With a beating heart, I tried the door; but I was locked in my prison, and could do nothing. I sat down and simply cried.

events.text_segment:
24 June, before morning.—Last night the Count left me early, and locked himself into his own room. As soon as I dared I ran up the winding stair, and looked out of the window, which opened south. I thought I would watch for the Count, for there is something going on. The Szgany are quartered somewhere in the castle and are doing work of some kind. I know it, for now and then I hear a far-away muffled sound as of mattock and spade, and, whatever it is, it must be the end of some ruthless villainy.
I had been at the window somewhat less than half an hour, when I saw something coming out of the Count’s window. I drew back and watched carefully, and saw the whole man emerge. It was a new shock to me to find that he had on the suit of clothes which I had worn whilst travelling here, and slung over his shoulder the terrible bag which I had seen the women take away. There could be no doubt as to his quest, and in my garb, too! This, then, is his new scheme of evil: that he will allow others to see me, as they think, so that he may both leave evidence that I have been seen in the towns or villages posting my own letters, and that any wickedness which he may do shall by the local people be attributed to me.
It makes me rage to think that this can go on, and whilst I am shut up here, a veritable prisoner, but without that protection of the law which is even a criminal’s right and consolation.
I thought I would watch for the Count’s return, and for a long time sat doggedly at the window. Then I began to notice that there were some quaint little specks floating in the rays of the moonlight. They were like the tiniest grains of dust, and they whirled round and gathered in clusters in a nebulous sort of way. I watched them with a sense of soothing, and a sort of calm stole over me. I leaned back in the embrasure in a more comfortable position, so that I could enjoy more fully the aërial gambolling.
Something made me start up, a low, piteous howling of dogs somewhere far below in the valley, which was hidden from my sight. Louder it seemed to ring in my ears, and the floating motes of dust to take new shapes to the sound as they danced in the moonlight. I felt myself struggling to awake to some call of my instincts; nay, my very soul was struggling, and my half-remembered sensibilities were striving to answer the call. I was becoming hypnotised! Quicker and quicker danced the dust; the moonbeams seemed to quiver as they went by me into the mass of gloom beyond. More and more they gathered till they seemed to take dim phantom shapes. And then I started, broad awake and in full possession of my senses, and ran screaming from the place. The phantom shapes, which were becoming gradually materialised from the moonbeams, were those of the three ghostly women to whom I was doomed. I fled, and felt somewhat safer in my own room, where there was no moonlight and where the lamp was burning brightly.
When a couple of hours had passed I heard something stirring in the Count’s room, something like a sharp wail quickly suppressed; and then there was silence, deep, awful silence, which chilled me. With a beating heart, I tried the door; but I was locked in my prison, and could do nothing. I sat down and simply cried.
