events.title: A Mother's Anguish and a Brutal End
detailed_summary: While in his room, Jonathan hears a woman's agonized cry from the courtyard.
Looking out, he sees a disheveled woman, distressed and out of breath, leaning against the gateway.
Upon seeing Jonathan's face, she lunges forward, menacingly demanding her child back from the "monster."
She falls to her knees, repeating her plea with heart-wrenching tones, then tears her hair and beats her breast in extreme grief, eventually beating her hands against the door.
Jonathan hears the Count's harsh, metallic whisper from somewhere high up, seemingly answered by the howling of wolves from all around.
A pack of wolves then pours into the courtyard.
The woman makes no further sound, and the wolves' howling is brief; they soon depart, licking their lips.
Jonathan feels no pity for her, believing he knows her child's fate and that she is better off dead, leaving him overwhelmed by his terrifying situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I sat I heard a sound in the courtyard without—the agonised cry of a woman.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What shall I do? what can I do? How can I escape from this dreadful thing of night and gloom and fear?

events.text_segment:
As I sat I heard a sound in the courtyard without—the agonised cry of a woman. I rushed to the window, and throwing it up, peered out between the bars. There, indeed, was a woman with dishevelled hair, holding her hands over her heart as one distressed with running. She was leaning against a corner of the gateway. When she saw my face at the window she threw herself forward, and shouted in a voice laden with menace:—
“Monster, give me my child!”
She threw herself on her knees, and raising up her hands, cried the same words in tones which wrung my heart. Then she tore her hair and beat her breast, and abandoned herself to all the violences of extravagant emotion. Finally, she threw herself forward, and, though I could not see her, I could hear the beating of her naked hands against the door.
Somewhere high overhead, probably on the tower, I heard the voice of the Count calling in his harsh, metallic whisper. His call seemed to be answered from far and wide by the howling of wolves. Before many minutes had passed a pack of them poured, like a pent-up dam when liberated, through the wide entrance into the courtyard.
There was no cry from the woman, and the howling of the wolves was but short. Before long they streamed away singly, licking their lips.
I could not pity her, for I knew now what had become of her child, and she was better dead.
What shall I do? what can I do? How can I escape from this dreadful thing of night and gloom and fear?

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: As I sat I heard a sound in the courtyard without—the agonised cry of a woman. Looking out, I saw a woman, dishevelled and wild, leaning against the gateway, her face distorted with passion. She was out of breath, and her eyes were red with weeping. When she saw my face at the window, she started forward with a fierce cry, and with outstretched hands, as though to drag me from my room, she shrieked in a voice that was almost a howl: 'Give me my child, you foul monster!' Then she fell upon her knees, and with a voice that broke with passion, she repeated her cry, 'Give me my child, you foul monster!' and then, with a sudden frenzy, she tore her hair and beat her breast, and then, with a wild, despairing gesture, she beat her hands against the door. I heard the Count's voice from somewhere high up, a harsh, metallic whisper, and then the howling of wolves from all around. A pack of them poured into the courtyard, and the woman made no more sound. The howling was brief; the wolves soon departed, licking their lips. I felt no pity for her, for I knew what had become of her child, and I knew that she was better dead. I was alone, and I was in the power of a fiend.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: As I sat I heard a sound in the courtyard without—the agonised cry of a woman. I started to my feet, my heart pounding with a sudden, nameless terror. The cry was not one of ordinary distress, but of something deeper, more primal, as if the very soul of the woman were being torn asunder. I rushed to the window and looked out into the moonlit courtyard. All was still, save for the wind that whispered through the trees and the distant hoot of an owl. Yet the echo of that cry still rang in my ears, a sound that chilled me to the bone. I hesitated only a moment before grabbing my coat and stepping into the night. The air was cold and sharp, and the silence oppressive. I moved quickly, my footsteps muffled by the thick layer of fallen leaves. I reached the courtyard and scanned the area, my eyes searching for any sign of what had caused the cry. There was no one in sight, only the tall, shadowy trees and the pale light of the moon. I called out, my voice breaking the stillness, but there was no answer. Then, from the corner of my eye, I saw a figure—slender, pale, and moving with unnatural grace—vanish behind the old stone wall. My breath caught in my throat. I knew, with a terrible certainty, that I had just glimpsed something beyond the bounds of human understanding. I stood frozen, my mind reeling, as the night closed in around me once more.

events.title: Renewed Resolve with Daylight and a Desperate Plan
detailed_summary: The arrival of morning brings Jonathan a profound sense of relief and renewed courage, likened to the dove from Noah's ark.
He is spurred to action, especially as one of his post-dated letters, designed to erase his existence, has been sent.
He reflects that his dangers have always occurred at night and that he has never seen the Count in daylight, speculating that the Count might sleep during the day.
This leads him to consider entering the Count's room, though the door is always locked.
He devises a daring plan: to mimic the Count's own method of exiting his window and climbing the castle wall.
He acknowledges the extreme risk, potentially leading to death, but feels his current predicament is even more desperate. He prays for help and bids a mental farewell to Mina and his loved ones.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 25 June, morning.—No man knows till he has suffered from the night how sweet and how dear to his heart and eye the morning can be.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: God help me in my task! Good-bye, Mina, if I fail; good-bye, my faithful friend and second father; good-bye, all, and last of all Mina!

events.text_segment:
25 June, morning.—No man knows till he has suffered from the night how sweet and how dear to his heart and eye the morning can be. When the sun grew so high this morning that it struck the top of the great gateway opposite my window, the high spot which it touched seemed to me as if the dove from the ark had lighted there. My fear fell from me as if it had been a vaporous garment which dissolved in the warmth. I must take action of some sort whilst the courage of the day is upon me. Last night one of my post-dated letters went to post, the first of that fatal series which is to blot out the very traces of my existence from the earth.
Let me not think of it. Action!
It has always been at night-time that I have been molested or threatened, or in some way in danger or in fear. I have not yet seen the Count in the daylight. Can it be that he sleeps when others wake, that he may be awake whilst they sleep? If I could only get into his room! But there is no possible way. The door is always locked, no way for me.
Yes, there is a way, if one dares to take it. Where his body has gone why may not another body go? I have seen him myself crawl from his window. Why should not I imitate him, and go in by his window? The chances are desperate, but my need is more desperate still. I shall risk it. At the worst it can only be death; and a man’s death is not a calf’s, and the dreaded Hereafter may still be open to me. God help me in my task! Good-bye, Mina, if I fail; good-bye, my faithful friend and second father; good-bye, all, and last of all Mina!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 25 June, morning.—No man knows till he has suffered from the night how sweet and how dear to his heart and eye the morning can be. It is like the dove that came out of the Ark, bearing in its beak the olive leaf, the first sign of life and hope after the desolation. I feel a new courage rising in me, and I am determined to act. One of my post-dated letters has gone, and I must do something to counteract it. I have always found my dangers come to me in the night, and I have never seen the Count in the daylight. I have often thought that he sleeps during the day, and if that be so, then perhaps I may find him in his room. The door is always locked, but I have seen him go out of the window, and I have seen how he climbs the wall. I will try to do the same. I know it is a desperate thing to do, and that I may fall and break my neck, but I am in such a position that I have nothing to lose. I will pray for help, and say a last farewell in thought to Mina and to all I love.

events.title: Perilous Climb and Discovery in the Chapel
detailed_summary: Jonathan, with fresh courage, executes his plan, climbing out the south-side window onto a narrow stone ledge.
He removes his boots and carefully navigates the precarious path, focusing on reaching the Count's window without looking down at the terrifying drop.
He successfully reaches the Count's window, slides in feet first, and finds the room empty and barely furnished, covered in dust. He cannot find a key.
He discovers a large heap of ancient gold coins and old, stained jewelry in a corner.
He finds an open heavy door leading through a stone passage to a steeply descending circular stairway, dark and lit only by loopholes.
At the bottom, a tunnel-like passage emits a deathly, sickly odor of freshly turned earth, which intensifies as he proceeds.

He opens another heavy door and enters an old, ruined chapel, evidently used as a graveyard, with a broken roof and steps leading to vaults. The ground has been recently dug, and earth is piled in the large wooden boxes brought by the Slovaks.
Searching for an outlet and finding none, he meticulously examines the area, even entering two vaults which contain only old coffin fragments and dust.
In the third vault, he makes a momentous discovery: in one of fifty great boxes, lying on a pile of newly dug earth, is the Count.

The Count appears dead or asleep, with open, stony eyes lacking the glaze of death, cheeks holding life's warmth despite pallor, and red lips. There is no discernible movement, pulse, breath, or heartbeat.
Jonathan notes the recentness of the Count's placement due to the fresh earthy smell. The box's cover, pierced with holes, lies nearby.
He attempts to search for keys on the Count's body but is repulsed by the look of hate in the dead eyes, even though they seem unconscious of his presence.
He flees the scene, crawls back up the castle wall, and returns to his room, exhausted and trying to process his findings.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Regaining my room, I threw myself panting upon the bed and tried to think....

events.text_segment:
Same day, later.—I have made the effort, and God, helping me, have come safely back to this room. I must put down every detail in order. I went whilst my courage was fresh straight to the window on the south side, and at once got outside on the narrow ledge of stone which runs around the building on this side. The stones are big and roughly cut, and the mortar has by process of time been washed away between them. I took off my boots, and ventured out on the desperate way. I looked down once, so as to make sure that a sudden glimpse of the awful depth would not overcome me, but after that kept my eyes away from it. I knew pretty well the direction and distance of the Count’s window, and made for it as well as I could, having regard to the opportunities available. I did not feel dizzy—I suppose I was too excited—and the time seemed ridiculously short till I found myself standing on the window-sill and trying to raise up the sash. I was filled with agitation, however, when I bent down and slid feet foremost in through the window. Then I looked around for the Count, but, with surprise and gladness, made a discovery. The room was empty! It was barely furnished with odd things, which seemed to have never been used; the furniture was something the same style as that in the south rooms, and was covered with dust. I looked for the key, but it was not in the lock, and I could not find it anywhere. The only thing I found was a great heap of gold in one corner—gold of all kinds, Roman, and British, and Austrian, and Hungarian, and Greek and Turkish money, covered with a film of dust, as though it had lain long in the ground. None of it that I noticed was less than three hundred years old. There were also chains and ornaments, some jewelled, but all of them old and stained.
At one corner of the room was a heavy door. I tried it, for, since I could not find the key of the room or the key of the outer door, which was the main object of my search, I must make further examination, or all my efforts would be in vain. It was open, and led through a stone passage to a circular stairway, which went steeply down. I descended, minding carefully where I went, for the stairs were dark, being only lit by loopholes in the heavy masonry. At the bottom there was a dark, tunnel-like passage, through which came a deathly, sickly odour, the odour of old earth newly turned. As I went through the passage the smell grew closer and heavier. At last I pulled open a heavy door which stood ajar, and found myself in an old, ruined chapel, which had evidently been used as a graveyard. The roof was broken, and in two places were steps leading to vaults, but the ground had recently been dug over, and the earth placed in great wooden boxes, manifestly those which had been brought by the Slovaks. There was nobody about, and I made search for any further outlet, but there was none. Then I went over every inch of the ground, so as not to lose a chance. I went down even into the vaults, where the dim light struggled, although to do so was a dread to my very soul. Into two of these I went, but saw nothing except fragments of old coffins and piles of dust; in the third, however, I made a discovery.
There, in one of the great boxes, of which there were fifty in all, on a pile of newly dug earth, lay the Count! He was either dead or asleep, I could not say which—for the eyes were open and stony, but without the glassiness of death—and the cheeks had the warmth of life through all their pallor; the lips were as red as ever. But there was no sign of movement, no pulse, no breath, no beating of the heart. I bent over him, and tried to find any sign of life, but in vain. He could not have lain there long, for the earthy smell would have passed away in a few hours. By the side of the box was its cover, pierced with holes here and there. I thought he might have the keys on him, but when I went to search I saw the dead eyes, and in them, dead though they were, such a look of hate, though unconscious of me or my presence, that I fled from the place, and leaving the Count’s room by the window, crawled again up the castle wall. Regaining my room, I threw myself panting upon the bed and tried to think....

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Same day, later.—I have made the effort, and God, helping me, have come safely back to this room. I have seen the Count in his box, and I have seen the place where he lies. I can write of it now with some composure, but I confess that I am shaken to the very soul. I have not slept, and I have not eaten, and I feel the reaction of the terrible strain. But I must write, for I must have some record of what I have seen, and I must try to think out what it all means.

I went out by the window on the south side, as I had planned, and climbed down the narrow stone ledge. I took off my boots, for I knew that the slightest noise might be fatal. I went very slowly, and I did not look down, for I knew that if I did I should lose my nerve. I reached the Count's window at last, and I slid in feet first. The room was empty and bare, and the dust lay thick upon the floor. I could find no key, but I found a heap of old gold coins and old, stained jewelry in a corner. I did not touch them, for I had no time to waste.

I found a heavy door open, and through it was a stone passage leading to a steeply descending circular stairway. The light came only through loopholes, and the air was very cold. At the bottom was a tunnel-like passage, and the air was full of a deathly, sickly odor of freshly turned earth. I went on, and the smell grew stronger. I came to another heavy door, and I opened it, and I found myself in an old, ruined chapel, evidently used as a graveyard. The roof was broken in places, and the steps led down to the vaults. The ground had been recently dug, and the earth was piled in the large wooden boxes which the Slovaks had brought.

I searched for an outlet, but I could find none. I examined the place carefully, and I went into two of the vaults, but they contained only old coffin fragments and dust. In the third vault, I found the Count. He was in one of fifty great boxes, lying on a pile of newly dug earth. He looked dead or asleep, with open, stony eyes, and with no glaze of death upon them. His cheeks had the warmth of life, though they were very pale, and his lips were red. There was no movement, no pulse, no breath, no sign of life. I could see that he had been placed there but a short time ago, for the smell of the earth was fresh. The cover of the box, pierced with holes, lay near.

I tried to search for keys on his body, but I could not do it. The look in his eyes, though they seemed unconscious of my presence, was one of hate, and it repelled me. I fled from the place, crawling back up the castle wall, and I came back to this room, exhausted and trembling. I must think, I must act, but I am so tired that I can scarcely think at all. I must write, for I must have some record of what I have seen, and I must try to think out what it all means.

events.title: The Count's Deceptive Farewell and Thwarted Escape
detailed_summary: Jonathan observes the Count leaving the castle again in his clothes, lizard-fashion down the wall, on the day his final coerced letter is dated. He wishes for a weapon but doubts its efficacy.
He avoids watching for the Count's return for fear of the "weird sisters" and falls asleep reading in the library.

The Count awakens him with a grim expression, announcing their parting the next day: Jonathan to England, the Count to some work that might prevent their future meeting. He confirms Jonathan's letter home has been sent and assures him all will be ready for his journey.
Jonathan, suspicious, tests the Count's sincerity by asking to leave that night.
The Count demurs, claiming his coachman and horses are away. Jonathan offers to walk, eager to leave immediately.
The Count smiles diabolically and questions him about his baggage, which Jonathan dismisses.
With a show of courteous hospitality, the Count agrees to let him leave, quoting a saying about speeding the parting guest, and precedes Jonathan downstairs with a lamp.
Suddenly, the Count stops, and the howling of many wolves erupts nearby, as if summoned by his hand.
He calmly proceeds to the main door, unbolts and unchains it. Jonathan is astonished to see it unlocked.
As the door opens, the wolves' howling grows angrier, their red jaws and clawed feet visible. Jonathan realizes resistance is futile against such allies.
Believing he is being set up to be fed to the wolves at his own request, Jonathan cries out for the door to be shut, saying he'll wait till morning, hiding his bitter disappointment.
The Count slams the door shut. They return to the library in silence.
The last Jonathan sees of the Count is him kissing his hand, a triumphant red light in his eyes and a Judas-like smile.

Later, in his room, Jonathan hears the Count's voice outside his door, telling the three women to wait, that tonight is his, and tomorrow night will be theirs, followed by their laughter. Enraged, Jonathan flings open his door to see the three women, who laugh horribly and flee.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 29 June.—To-day is the date of my last letter, and the Count has taken steps to prove that it was genuine, for again I saw him leave the castle by the same window, and in my clothes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As I appeared they all joined in a horrible laugh, and ran away.

events.text_segment:
29 June.—To-day is the date of my last letter, and the Count has taken steps to prove that it was genuine, for again I saw him leave the castle by the same window, and in my clothes. As he went down the wall, lizard fashion, I wished I had a gun or some lethal weapon, that I might destroy him; but I fear that no weapon wrought alone by man’s hand would have any effect on him. I dared not wait to see him return, for I feared to see those weird sisters. I came back to the library, and read there till I fell asleep.
I was awakened by the Count, who looked at me as grimly as a man can look as he said:—
“To-morrow, my friend, we must part. You return to your beautiful England, I to some work which may have such an end that we may never meet. Your letter home has been despatched; to-morrow I shall not be here, but all shall be ready for your journey. In the morning come the Szgany, who have some labours of their own here, and also come some Slovaks. When they have gone, my carriage shall come for you, and shall bear you to the Borgo Pass to meet the diligence from Bukovina to Bistritz. But I am in hopes that I shall see more of you at Castle Dracula.” I suspected him, and determined to test his sincerity. Sincerity! It seems like a profanation of the word to write it in connection with such a monster, so asked him point-blank:—
“Why may I not go to-night?”
“Because, dear sir, my coachman and horses are away on a mission.”
“But I would walk with pleasure. I want to get away at once.” He smiled, such a soft, smooth, diabolical smile that I knew there was some trick behind his smoothness. He said:—
“And your baggage?”
“I do not care about it. I can send for it some other time.”
The Count stood up, and said, with a sweet courtesy which made me rub my eyes, it seemed so real:—
“You English have a saying which is close to my heart, for its spirit is that which rules our boyars: ‘Welcome the coming; speed the parting guest.’ Come with me, my dear young friend. Not an hour shall you wait in my house against your will, though sad am I at your going, and that you so suddenly desire it. Come!” With a stately gravity, he, with the lamp, preceded me down the stairs and along the hall. Suddenly he stopped.
“Hark!”
Close at hand came the howling of many wolves. It was almost as if the sound sprang up at the rising of his hand, just as the music of a great orchestra seems to leap under the bâton of the conductor. After a pause of a moment, he proceeded, in his stately way, to the door, drew back the ponderous bolts, unhooked the heavy chains, and began to draw it open.
To my intense astonishment I saw that it was unlocked. Suspiciously, I looked all round, but could see no key of any kind.
As the door began to open, the howling of the wolves without grew louder and angrier; their red jaws, with champing teeth, and their blunt-clawed feet as they leaped, came in through the opening door. I knew then that to struggle at the moment against the Count was useless. With such allies as these at his command, I could do nothing. But still the door continued slowly to open, and only the Count’s body stood in the gap. Suddenly it struck me that this might be the moment and means of my doom; I was to be given to the wolves, and at my own instigation. There was a diabolical wickedness in the idea great enough for the Count, and as a last chance I cried out:—
“Shut the door; I shall wait till morning!” and covered my face with my hands to hide my tears of bitter disappointment. With one sweep of his powerful arm, the Count threw the door shut, and the great bolts clanged and echoed through the hall as they shot back into their places.
In silence we returned to the library, and after a minute or two I went to my own room. The last I saw of Count Dracula was his kissing his hand to me; with a red light of triumph in his eyes, and with a smile that Judas in hell might be proud of.
When I was in my room and about to lie down, I thought I heard a whispering at my door. I went to it softly and listened. Unless my ears deceived me, I heard the voice of the Count:—
“Back, back, to your own place! Your time is not yet come. Wait! Have patience! To-night is mine. To-morrow night is yours!” There was a low, sweet ripple of laughter, and in a rage I threw open the door, and saw without the three terrible women licking their lips. As I appeared they all joined in a horrible laugh, and ran away.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 29 June.—To-day is the date of my last letter, and the Count has taken steps to prove that it was genuine, for again I saw him leave the castle by the same window, and in my clothes. I was in a great state of excitement, for I longed for some weapon, but I had none, and I doubted if any could avail against such an enemy. I did not care to watch for his return, for I feared the weird sisters, and so I took up a book and tried to read. I must have dozed, for I was suddenly awakened by the Count, who stood before me with a grave and solemn face. 'You are to leave me to-morrow,' he said, 'you for England, I for other work, which may prevent our meeting again.' I looked at him in astonishment, and he continued: 'Your letter has gone, and all is ready for your journey.' I was suspicious, and to test him I said: 'Then let me go to-night.' He shook his head. 'My coachman and horses are away,' he said. 'I will walk,' I answered, 'I am ready now.' He smiled diabolically, and asked me about my baggage, which I told him I had none. 'Then I will not hinder you,' he said, with a show of courteous hospitality, and quoted a saying about speeding the parting guest. He took a lamp and preceded me downstairs. Suddenly he stopped, and there came from the hills a long, low, wailing howl, like the cry of many wolves. It was as if he had summoned them with his hand. He went on to the main door, unbolting and unchaining it. I was astonished to find it unlocked. As the door opened, the howling grew louder and more furious, and I could see the red jaws and the clawed feet of the wolves. I saw that resistance was useless against such allies. I thought that I was being sent out to be devoured by them, and I cried out for the door to be shut, saying I would wait till morning, though I hid my bitter disappointment. The Count slammed the door, and we returned to the library in silence. The last I saw of him was his hand raised in a kiss, and in his eyes a triumphant red light, and on his face a smile like that of a Judas. Later, in my room, I heard the Count's voice outside my door, and he said to the three women: 'Wait, they are to-night mine, to-morrow night will be yours.' Then came their laughter, and I, in a fury, flung open my door, but they had fled.

events.title: Final Desperate Search and Horrific Transformation
detailed_summary: Jonathan, believing these might be his last diary entries, prepares for death.
At dawn, feeling safer, he goes to the hall door, remembering it was unlocked, only to find it now firmly bolted.
A wild desire to get the key at any cost seizes him, and he resolves to scale the wall again to the Count's room, preferring death to his current situation.
He scrambles down the wall into the Count's empty room, finds the gold but no key, and proceeds to the chapel.
He finds the Count's box in the same place, the lid laid on but not nailed.

Upon lifting the lid, he is horrified: the Count looks half-renewed, his white hair and moustache now dark iron-grey, cheeks fuller, skin ruby-red beneath, lips redder with fresh blood trickling down his chin and neck. His eyes seem set in swollen flesh.
The creature appears gorged with blood, like an exhausted leech. Jonathan shudders at the thought of touching him but knows he must search for the key.
He finds no key on the body. The Count's bloated face wears a mocking smile that enrages Jonathan.
The thought of this being preying on London's millions fuels a terrible desire to destroy him.
Lacking a weapon, he seizes a workman's shovel and strikes at the Count's face.
As he strikes, the Count's head turns, and his eyes, blazing with basilisk horror, fix on Jonathan, paralyzing him. The shovel glances off, making a gash above the forehead.
The shovel falls, and as Jonathan retrieves it, its flange catches the lid, causing it to fall back, hiding the Count. His last view is of the bloated, blood-stained, maliciously grinning face.

events.text_segment:
30 June, morning.—These may be the last words I ever write in this diary. I slept till just before the dawn, and when I woke threw myself on my knees, for I determined that if Death came he should find me ready.
At last I felt that subtle change in the air, and knew that the morning had come. Then came the welcome cock-crow, and I felt that I was safe. With a glad heart, I opened my door and ran down to the hall. I had seen that the door was unlocked, and now escape was before me. With hands that trembled with eagerness, I unhooked the chains and drew back the massive bolts.
But the door would not move. Despair seized me. I pulled, and pulled, at the door, and shook it till, massive as it was, it rattled in its casement. I could see the bolt shot. It had been locked after I left the Count.
Then a wild desire took me to obtain that key at any risk, and I determined then and there to scale the wall again and gain the Count’s room. He might kill me, but death now seemed the happier choice of evils. Without a pause I rushed up to the east window, and scrambled down the wall, as before, into the Count’s room. It was empty, but that was as I expected. I could not see a key anywhere, but the heap of gold remained. I went through the door in the corner and down the winding stair and along the dark passage to the old chapel. I knew now well enough where to find the monster I sought.
The great box was in the same place, close against the wall, but the lid was laid on it, not fastened down, but with the nails ready in their places to be hammered home. I knew I must reach the body for the key, so I raised the lid, and laid it back against the wall; and then I saw something which filled my very soul with horror. There lay the Count, but looking as if his youth had been half renewed, for the white hair and moustache were changed to dark iron-grey; the cheeks were fuller, and the white skin seemed ruby-red underneath; the mouth was redder than ever, for on the lips were gouts of fresh blood, which trickled from the corners of the mouth and ran over the chin and neck. Even the deep, burning eyes seemed set amongst swollen flesh, for the lids and pouches underneath were bloated. It seemed as if the whole awful creature were simply gorged with blood. He lay like a filthy leech, exhausted with his repletion. I shuddered as I bent over to touch him, and every sense in me revolted at the contact; but I had to search, or I was lost. The coming night might see my own body a banquet in a similar way to those horrid three. I felt all over the body, but no sign could I find of the key. Then I stopped and looked at the Count. There was a mocking smile on the bloated face which seemed to drive me mad. This was the being I was helping to transfer to London, where, perhaps, for centuries to come he might, amongst its teeming millions, satiate his lust for blood, and create a new and ever-widening circle of semi-demons to batten on the helpless. The very thought drove me mad. A terrible desire came upon me to rid the world of such a monster. There was no lethal weapon at hand, but I seized a shovel which the workmen had been using to fill the cases, and lifting it high, struck, with the edge downward, at the hateful face. But as I did so the head turned, and the eyes fell full upon me, with all their blaze of basilisk horror. The sight seemed to paralyse me, and the shovel turned in my hand and glanced from the face, merely making a deep gash above the forehead. The shovel fell from my hand across the box, and as I pulled it away the flange of the blade caught the edge of the lid which fell over again, and hid the horrid thing from my sight. The last glimpse I had was of the bloated face, blood-stained and fixed with a grin of malice which would have held its own in the nethermost hell.

I have no hope of escape, and I feel that I am in the power of a being who is neither man nor beast, but something worse. I have tried every means to get out of this castle, and I have failed. I have no idea how long I have been here, but it seems to me that it must be weeks. I have kept a careful account of the days, and I know that it is now the 30th of June. I have no idea what the time is, but I feel that it is morning, for the light is pale and cold, and the air is fresh. events.title: Trapped as the Count Departs, and a Final Leap of Faith
detailed_summary: Jonathan, brain on fire with despair, hears the approaching sounds of Gipsy songs, heavy wheels, and whip cracks—the Szgany and Slovaks are arriving.
He takes a last look at the box containing the Count and rushes back to the Count's room, intending to flee when the main door is opened.
He hears the great lock grinding and the door opening, followed by many tramping feet.
He turns to go back to the vault, thinking there might be a new entrance, but a sudden gust of wind slams the door to the winding stair shut, trapping him.
He hears the sounds of the boxes (presumably containing the Count and earth) being set down, hammering as the main box is nailed shut, and then departing footsteps.
The main door is shut, chains rattle, the key turns and is withdrawn, followed by another door opening and closing, and the creak of lock and bolt.
He hears the wheels, whips, and Szgany chorus fade into the distance.
He realizes he is alone in the castle with the three awful women, whom he considers devils.
Refusing to remain with them, he resolves to attempt a more ambitious scaling of the castle wall, taking some gold with him.
He hopes to find a way out of the cursed place and head for home, preferring God's mercy and a clean death from a fall to the fate the monsters offer. He bids a final farewell.

events.text_segment:
I thought and thought what should be my next move, but my brain seemed on fire, and I waited with a despairing feeling growing over me. As I waited I heard in the distance a gipsy song sung by merry voices coming closer, and through their song the rolling of heavy wheels and the cracking of whips; the Szgany and the Slovaks of whom the Count had spoken were coming. With a last look around and at the box which contained the vile body, I ran from the place and gained the Count’s room, determined to rush out at the moment the door should be opened. With strained ears, I listened, and heard downstairs the grinding of the key in the great lock and the falling back of the heavy door. There must have been some other means of entry, or some one had a key for one of the locked doors. Then there came the sound of many feet tramping and dying away in some passage which sent up a clanging echo. I turned to run down again towards the vault, where I might find the new entrance; but at the moment there seemed to come a violent puff of wind, and the door to the winding stair blew to with a shock that set the dust from the lintels flying. When I ran to push it open, I found that it was hopelessly fast. I was again a prisoner, and the net of doom was closing round me more closely.
As I write there is in the passage below a sound of many tramping feet and the crash of weights being set down heavily, doubtless the boxes, with their freight of earth. There is a sound of hammering; it is the box being nailed down. Now I can hear the heavy feet tramping again along the hall, with many other idle feet coming behind them.
The door is shut, and the chains rattle; there is a grinding of the key in the lock; I can hear the key withdraw: then another door opens and shuts; I hear the creaking of lock and bolt.
Hark! in the courtyard and down the rocky way the roll of heavy wheels, the crack of whips, and the chorus of the Szgany as they pass into the distance.
I am alone in the castle with those awful women. Faugh! Mina is a woman, and there is nought in common. They are devils of the Pit!
I shall not remain alone with them; I shall try to scale the castle wall farther than I have yet attempted. I shall take some of the gold with me, lest I want it later. I may find a way from this dreadful place.
And then away for home! away to the quickest and nearest train! away from this cursed spot, from this cursed land, where the devil and his children still walk with earthly feet!
At least God’s mercy is better than that of these monsters, and the precipice is steep and high. At its foot a man may sleep—as a man. Good-bye, all! Mina!

I heard the distant sounds of Gipsy songs, the heavy wheels, and the sharp cracks of whips—the Szgany and Slovaks were coming. I took a last look at the box containing the Count, and then I rushed back to his room, hoping to escape when the main door was opened. I heard the great lock grinding and the door creaking open, followed by the tramp of many feet. I turned to go back to the vault, thinking there might be a new entrance, but a sudden gust of wind slammed the door to the winding stair, and I was trapped. I heard the boxes being set down, the hammering as the main box was nailed shut, and then the departing footsteps. The main door was shut, the chains rattled, the key turned and was withdrawn, and then another door opened and closed, and the creak of lock and bolt followed. The wheels, the whips, and the Szgany chorus faded into the distance. I was alone in the castle with the three awful women, whom I considered devils. I could not remain with them. I resolved to attempt a more ambitious scaling of the castle wall, taking some gold with me. I would try to find a way out of this cursed place and head for home, preferring God's mercy and a clean death from a fall to the fate the monsters offer. I bid a final farewell.

I took a last look at the box containing the Count, and then I rushed back to his room, hoping to escape when the main door was opened. I heard the great lock grinding and the door creaking open, followed by the tramp of many feet. I turned to go back to the vault, thinking there might be a new entrance, but a sudden gust of wind slammed the door to the winding stair, and I was trapped. I heard the boxes being set down, the hammering as the main box was nailed shut, and then the departing footsteps. The main door was shut, the chains rattled, the key turned and was withdrawn, and then another door opened and closed, and the creak of lock and bolt followed. The wheels, the whips, and the Szgany chorus faded into the distance. I was alone in the castle with the three awful women, whom I considered devils. I could not remain with them. I resolved to attempt a more ambitious scaling of the castle wall, taking some gold with me. I would try to find a way out of this cursed place and head for home, preferring God's mercy and a clean death from a fall to the fate the monsters offer. I bid a final farewell.

events.title: Mina's Dedication, Journaling Aspirations, and Eagerness for News
detailed_summary: Mina apologizes for her delayed response, attributing it to being overwhelmed with her work as an assistant schoolmistress.
She expresses a fervent wish to be with Lucy by the sea, where they can converse without restraint and share their dreams.
Mina has been diligently applying herself to her studies, particularly shorthand, with the goal of keeping pace with Jonathan's academic pursuits.
She envisions assisting Jonathan after their marriage by taking down his words in shorthand and transcribing them on a typewriter, a skill she is also working hard to master.
She mentions that she and Jonathan occasionally exchange letters written in shorthand, and that Jonathan is documenting his travels abroad in a stenographic journal.
Mina plans to adopt a similar journaling practice when she is with Lucy, intending it to be a free-form diary rather than a restrictive one.
She clarifies that this journal is primarily for her own use as an exercise book, though she might share noteworthy entries with Jonathan.
Mina aspires to develop skills akin to those of female journalists, such as conducting interviews, writing descriptive pieces, and recalling conversations accurately.
She notes that she has received a brief message from Jonathan in Transylvania, confirming he is well and expecting to return in approximately one week.
Mina is eager to hear all about Jonathan's experiences and muses on the possibility of her and Jonathan exploring foreign lands together in the future.
The sound of the ten o'clock bell prompts her to conclude the letter.
She urges Lucy to share all her latest news, specifically inquiring about rumors concerning a 'tall, handsome, curly-haired man.'

events.text_segment:
9 May.
“My dearest Lucy,—
“Forgive my long delay in writing, but I have been simply overwhelmed with work. The life of an assistant schoolmistress is sometimes trying. I am longing to be with you, and by the sea, where we can talk together freely and build our castles in the air. I have been working very hard lately, because I want to keep up with Jonathan’s studies, and I have been practising shorthand very assiduously. When we are married I shall be able to be useful to Jonathan, and if I can stenograph well enough I can take down what he wants to say in this way and write it out for him on the typewriter, at which also I am practising very hard. He and I sometimes write letters in shorthand, and he is keeping a stenographic journal of his travels abroad. When I am with you I shall keep a diary in the same way. I don’t mean one of those two-pages-to-the-week-with-Sunday-squeezed-in-a-corner diaries, but a sort of journal which I can write in whenever I feel inclined. I do not suppose there will be much of interest to other people; but it is not intended for them. I may show it to Jonathan some day if there is in it anything worth sharing, but it is really an exercise book. I shall try to do what I see lady journalists do: interviewing and writing descriptions and trying to remember conversations. I am told that, with a little practice, one can remember all that goes on or that one hears said during a day. However, we shall see. I will tell you of my little plans when we meet. I have just had a few hurried lines from Jonathan from Transylvania. He is well, and will be returning in about a week. I am longing to hear all his news. It must be so nice to see strange countries. I wonder if we—I mean Jonathan and I—shall ever see them together. There is the ten o’clock bell ringing. Good-bye.
“Your loving
“Mina.
“Tell me all the news when you write. You have not told me anything for a long time. I hear rumours, and especially of a tall, handsome, curly-haired man???

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
9 May.

My dearest Lucy,

I do hope this letter finds you well and that you are enjoying the spring. I am so sorry for the delay in writing, but I have been so busy with my work as assistant schoolmistress that I have hardly had a moment to myself. I do so wish I could be with you by the sea, where we could sit and talk without restraint and tell each other all our dreams and hopes.

I have been working very hard at my studies, especially shorthand, and I am making good progress. I am determined to keep up with Jonathan in his studies, and I hope that after we are married I shall be able to take down his words in shorthand and type them out for him. I am also learning to use the typewriter, and I find it very interesting. Jonathan and I sometimes write to each other in shorthand, and he is keeping a stenographic journal of his travels abroad. I am going to try to do the same when I am with you, and I shall make it a free and easy diary, not a formal one. I think it will be a good exercise for me, and I may copy out some of the interesting parts for Jonathan to read.

I should like to be able to do as the lady journalists do, and take notes and write up interviews and descriptions, and remember what people say and do. I think it would be a very useful thing to be able to do, and I am determined to learn. I have had a short note from Jonathan from Transylvania, and he says he is well and expects to be home in about a week. I am so anxious to hear all about his experiences, and I wonder if we shall ever be able to travel together in foreign lands.

I must stop now, for I hear the ten o’clock bell. Do write and tell me all the news, and especially about the tall, handsome, curly-haired man I hear you are seeing so much of.

Ever your affectionate friend,

Mina Murray

events.title: Lucy's Social Updates and Ardent Confession of Love for Arthur Holmwood
detailed_summary: Lucy playfully refutes Mina's accusation of being a poor correspondent, stating she has written twice since their last meeting.
She claims to have little news of interest, describing her current town life as pleasant, filled with visits to art galleries and outdoor activities.
Addressing Mina's inquiry, Lucy identifies the 'tall, curly-haired man' as Mr. Holmwood, a frequent visitor who enjoys a good rapport with her mother due to shared interests.

Lucy introduces Dr. John Seward, a man she believes would be a suitable match for Mina if not for her engagement to Jonathan, describing him as handsome, affluent, well-born, clever, and only twenty-nine, yet in charge of a large lunatic asylum.
Mr. Holmwood introduced Dr. Seward to Lucy, and the doctor has since become a regular caller.

She perceives Dr. Seward as remarkably resolute yet calm, possessing an imperturbable demeanor and a commanding presence over his patients, noting his habit of looking intently into people's faces as if to discern their thoughts.
Lucy flatters herself that she is a difficult subject for Dr. Seward's thought-reading attempts, a conclusion she draws from her own self-reflection.
She acknowledges Dr. Seward's view of her as an intriguing psychological subject, a view she shares.
Dismissing fashion as tiresome, Lucy quotes 'Arthur' (Mr. Holmwood), which leads her to a pivotal confession.
She reveals to Mina her profound love for Arthur Holmwood.
Lucy describes her blush as she writes, expressing her belief that Arthur reciprocates her feelings, although he has not yet declared them verbally.
She passionately reaffirms her love and yearns to be with Mina to share her emotions in person, reminiscing about their past intimacy.
Fearing she might destroy the letter if she pauses, Lucy feels compelled to continue writing and share everything.
She implores Mina for an immediate response and her opinion, bids her good-night, and asks for her prayers for happiness.
A postscript underscores the confidential nature of her revelation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 17, Chatham Street,
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: L.

events.text_segment:
17, Chatham Street,
“Wednesday.
“My dearest Mina,—
“I must say you tax me very unfairly with being a bad correspondent. I wrote to you twice since we parted, and your last letter was only your second. Besides, I have nothing to tell you. There is really nothing to interest you. Town is very pleasant just now, and we go a good deal to picture-galleries and for walks and rides in the park. As to the tall, curly-haired man, I suppose it was the one who was with me at the last Pop. Some one has evidently been telling tales. That was Mr. Holmwood. He often comes to see us, and he and mamma get on very well together; they have so many things to talk about in common. We met some time ago a man that would just do for you, if you were not already engaged to Jonathan. He is an excellent parti, being handsome, well off, and of good birth. He is a doctor and really clever. Just fancy! He is only nine-and-twenty, and he has an immense lunatic asylum all under his own care. Mr. Holmwood introduced him to me, and he called here to see us, and often comes now. I think he is one of the most resolute men I ever saw, and yet the most calm. He seems absolutely imperturbable. I can fancy what a wonderful power he must have over his patients. He has a curious habit of looking one straight in the face, as if trying to read one’s thoughts. He tries this on very much with me, but I flatter myself he has got a tough nut to crack. I know that from my glass. Do you ever try to read your own face? I do, and I can tell you it is not a bad study, and gives you more trouble than you can well fancy if you have never tried it. He says that I afford him a curious psychological study, and I humbly think I do. I do not, as you know, take sufficient interest in dress to be able to describe the new fashions. Dress is a bore. That is slang again, but never mind; Arthur says that every day. There, it is all out. Mina, we have told all our secrets to each other since we were children; we have slept together and eaten together, and laughed and cried together; and now, though I have spoken, I would like to speak more. Oh, Mina, couldn’t you guess? I love him. I am blushing as I write, for although I think he loves me, he has not told me so in words. But oh, Mina, I love him; I love him; I love him! There, that does me good. I wish I were with you, dear, sitting by the fire undressing, as we used to sit; and I would try to tell you what I feel. I do not know how I am writing this even to you. I am afraid to stop, or I should tear up the letter, and I don’t want to stop, for I do so want to tell you all. Let me hear from you at once, and tell me all that you think about it. Mina, I must stop. Good-night. Bless me in your prayers; and, Mina, pray for my happiness.

“LUCY.
“P.S.—I need not tell you this is a secret. Good-night again.

“L.

17, Chatham Street, 

My Dearest Mina,

I am so sorry that I have not written oftener, but I have been so busy with all sorts of things that I have not had time. I have written twice since I saw you, and I think that is quite enough. I have not much news of interest, but I am having a very pleasant time here. I go to the pictures and the galleries, and I have been out walking a good deal. I have met a number of nice people, and I have had a great many invitations to tea and dinner. I have been asked to a great many places, and I have accepted quite a number of them. I have been to a great many balls and parties, and I have had a very good time.

You asked me about the tall, curly-haired man that you saw me with the other day. That is Mr. Holmwood, and he is a great friend of mine. He is a very nice man, and he and my mother get on very well together, for they both like the same sort of things. He has introduced me to a number of people, and among them is Dr. John Seward, who is a very nice man, and I think you would like him very much if you were not already engaged to Jonathan. 17, Chatham Street, 

My Dearest Mina,

I am so sorry that I have not written oftener, but I have been so busy with all sorts of things that I have not had time. I have written twice since I saw you, and I think that is quite enough. events.title: Lucy Recounts Dr. Seward's Heartfelt Proposal and Her Sorrowful Rejection
detailed_summary: Lucy expresses immense gratitude for Mina's supportive and understanding letter.
Reflecting on the adage 'it never rains but it pours,' she reveals the astonishing news that, despite never having a proposal before, she received three on a single day.
She conveys genuine sympathy for two of the men whose proposals she had to decline.
Overcome with happiness, Lucy asks Mina to keep the fact of the three proposals confidential to prevent envy among other girls.
She suggests that she and Mina, both being engaged and anticipating settled married life, are above such vanity.
Lucy begins to recount the first proposal, which came from Dr. John Seward before lunchtime.
She describes Dr. Seward as outwardly composed but palpably nervous, evidenced by his near-mishap with his hat and his anxious handling of a lancet.
He straightforwardly declared his deep affection for Lucy and his vision of a joyful life with her.
He started to express how unhappy he would be if she didn't care for him but stopped when he saw her crying, berating himself as a brute for causing her distress.
Dr. Seward then asked if Lucy could eventually develop feelings for him; her silent, negative shake of the head caused his hands to tremble.
With some hesitation, he inquired if her affections were already engaged, explaining that a man might still hope if a woman's heart was free.
Feeling a sense of obligation, Lucy admitted that there was someone else, though she did not provide details.
Upon hearing this, Dr. Seward stood, gravely took both her hands, wished her happiness, and offered his unwavering friendship should she ever need it.
Lucy is deeply moved to tears by his sincere love and the pain of his rejection, sorrowfully acknowledging that she is now passing out of his life.
She concludes this part of her letter, feeling a mixture of misery for Dr. Seward despite her own happiness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 24 May.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: My dear, I must stop here at present, I feel so miserable, though I am so happy.

events.text_segment:
24 May.
“My dearest Mina,—
“Thanks, and thanks, and thanks again for your sweet letter. It was so nice to be able to tell you and to have your sympathy.

“My dear, it never rains but it pours. How true the old proverbs are. Here am I, who shall be twenty in September, and yet I never had a proposal till to-day, not a real proposal, and to-day I have had three. Just fancy! THREE proposals in one day! Isn’t it awful! I feel sorry, really and truly sorry, for two of the poor fellows. Oh, Mina, I am so happy that I don’t know what to do with myself. And three proposals! But, for goodness’ sake, don’t tell any of the girls, or they would be getting all sorts of extravagant ideas and imagining themselves injured and slighted if in their very first day at home they did not get six at least. Some girls are so vain! You and I, Mina dear, who are engaged and are going to settle down soon soberly into old married women, can despise vanity. Well, I must tell you about the three, but you must keep it a secret, dear, from every one, except, of course, Jonathan. You will tell him, because I would, if I were in your place, certainly tell Arthur. A woman ought to tell her husband everything—don’t you think so, dear?—and I must be fair. Men like women, certainly their wives, to be quite as fair as they are; and women, I am afraid, are not always quite as fair as they should be. Well, my dear, number One came just before lunch. I told you of him, Dr. John Seward, the lunatic-asylum man, with the strong jaw and the good forehead. He was very cool outwardly, but was nervous all the same. He had evidently been schooling himself as to all sorts of little things, and remembered them; but he almost managed to sit down on his silk hat, which men don’t generally do when they are cool, and then when he wanted to appear at ease he kept playing with a lancet in a way that made me nearly scream. He spoke to me, Mina, very straightforwardly. He told me how dear I was to him, though he had known me so little, and what his life would be with me to help and cheer him. He was going to tell me how unhappy he would be if I did not care for him, but when he saw me cry he said that he was a brute and would not add to my present trouble. Then he broke off and asked if I could love him in time; and when I shook my head his hands trembled, and then with some hesitation he asked me if I cared already for any one else. He put it very nicely, saying that he did not want to wring my confidence from me, but only to know, because if a woman’s heart was free a man might have hope. And then, Mina, I felt a sort of duty to tell him that there was some one. I only told him that much, and then he stood up, and he looked very strong and very grave as he took both my hands in his and said he hoped I would be happy, and that if I ever wanted a friend I must count him one of my best. Oh, Mina dear, I can’t help crying: and you must excuse this letter being all blotted. Being proposed to is all very nice and all that sort of thing, but it isn’t at all a happy thing when you have to see a poor fellow, whom you know loves you honestly, going away and looking all broken-hearted, and to know that, no matter what he may say at the moment, you are passing quite out of his life. My dear, I must stop here at present, I feel so miserable, though I am so happy.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
24 May.

My dearest Mina,

I received your letter this morning, and I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for the kind and understanding words you wrote. I know you must have felt for me, and I am so grateful to have such a true and loyal friend as you. I have been thinking a great deal lately, and I feel that I must share with you something that has happened to me, for I know you will understand and not judge me.

You know how we often say, "It never rains but it pours," and I think that is certainly true in my case. I have had a most extraordinary day, for I received three proposals of marriage in the course of it. I never thought I should be in such a position, for I have never had a proposal before, and now I have had three in one day! I am quite overwhelmed, and I must ask you to keep this a secret, for I do not want the other girls to be envious. I think that you and I, who are both engaged and looking forward to a settled married life, are above such petty vanities.

I will tell you about the first proposal, for it was the most painful of all. It came from Dr. John Seward before lunchtime. He came to see me, and I thought it was about some patient of his, but I was mistaken. He was outwardly calm, but I could see that he was very nervous. He nearly dropped his hat, and his hands trembled as he handled his lancet. He told me that he loved me, and that he thought we should be very happy together. He was going to say how unhappy he would be if I did not care for him, but he stopped when he saw me crying, and he said he was a brute for making me cry. He asked me if I could ever come to care for him, and when I shook my head, he looked as if he had been struck. He asked me if my heart was already engaged, and I told him that it was, though I did not say to whom. He took my hands and said that he would always be my friend, and that he wished me happiness. I could not help but cry, for I saw the pain in his eyes, and I felt that I was passing out of his life. I am very sorry for him, for I know he is a good man, and I wish I could have loved him.

I will tell you about the other two proposals in my next letter, for I feel that I must write to you again soon. I hope you are well, and that you are not too surprised by what I have told you. I remain, as ever, your devoted friend,

Lucy.

We have now been in the Carpathians for some days, and I find the country more and more interesting. The scenery is wild and grand, and the people are very different from those I have known before. The peasants are simple and honest, and they seem to be very superstitious. They are afraid of certain places and certain times, and they have many strange customs. I have been told that this is a land of old traditions, and that the people here still believe in many things that have long been forgotten in the lowlands.

events.title: Lucy Details Quincey Morris's Charming Proposal and Her Admiring Rejection
detailed_summary: Writing later that evening, after Arthur Holmwood's visit, Lucy reports feeling in better spirits and resumes her letter to Mina.
She introduces her second suitor of the day, Mr. Quincey P. Morris, a Texan American who called after lunch.
Lucy portrays him as youthful, vibrant, and surprisingly well-traveled and adventurous, drawing a parallel to Desdemona's fascination with Othello's tales.
She speculates that women might marry men out of a desire for protection from their fears.
Mr. Morris managed to find Lucy alone, a feat she notes men often accomplish, though she admits to assisting Arthur in creating similar private moments.
She clarifies that Mr. Morris, despite being well-educated and possessing refined manners, uses American slang specifically to amuse her when they are alone.
Though appearing cheerful, Mr. Morris was visibly nervous as he took Lucy's hand to propose.
He made his proposal using his characteristic slang, inviting her to journey through life with him 'in double harness.'
Lucy, finding his good-humored approach less daunting than Dr. Seward's intensity, lightly replied that she wasn't yet 'broken to harness.'
Mr. Morris then adopted a serious tone, apologizing if his lightheartedness was unsuitable for such a significant moment for him.
Lucy experienced a mixture of solemnity and a thrill at receiving a second proposal in one day.
Before she could formulate a proper response, Morris launched into a passionate declaration of love.
He paused, seemingly perceiving her unspoken feelings from her expression, and with sincere fervor asked if she loved another, vowing to remain a loyal friend if that were the case.
Deeply impressed by his noble character, Lucy burst into tears and candidly confessed her love for someone else, even though that person had not yet declared his love for her.
Morris reacted with admiration for her honesty, asserting that her courage had earned her a friend, a bond he considered rarer and more selfless than that of a lover.
Lamenting his own 'lonely walk' ahead, he requested a kiss as a memento to ward off future 'darkness.'
Moved by his bravery, sweetness, and honorable conduct towards a rival, Lucy granted him a kiss.
Holding her hands, he affirmed that her honesty and the kiss had cemented their friendship, then thanked her and departed abruptly without any display of emotion.
Lucy is left crying, lamenting the unhappiness of such a worthy man when many others would adore him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Evening.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: My dear, this quite upset me, and I feel I cannot write of happiness just at once, after telling you of it; and I don’t wish to tell of the number three until it can be all happy.

events.text_segment:
Evening.
“Arthur has just gone, and I feel in better spirits than when I left off, so I can go on telling you about the day. Well, my dear, number Two came after lunch. He is such a nice fellow, an American from Texas, and he looks so young and so fresh that it seems almost impossible that he has been to so many places and has had such adventures. I sympathise with poor Desdemona when she had such a dangerous stream poured in her ear, even by a black man. I suppose that we women are such cowards that we think a man will save us from fears, and we marry him. I know now what I would do if I were a man and wanted to make a girl love me. No, I don’t, for there was Mr. Morris telling us his stories, and Arthur never told any, and yet—— My dear, I am somewhat previous. Mr. Quincey P. Morris found me alone. It seems that a man always does find a girl alone. No, he doesn’t, for Arthur tried twice to make a chance, and I helping him all I could; I am not ashamed to say it now. I must tell you beforehand that Mr. Morris doesn’t always speak slang—that is to say, he never does so to strangers or before them, for he is really well educated and has exquisite manners—but he found out that it amused me to hear him talk American slang, and whenever I was present, and there was no one to be shocked, he said such funny things. I am afraid, my dear, he has to invent it all, for it fits exactly into whatever else he has to say. But this is a way slang has. I do not know myself if I shall ever speak slang; I do not know if Arthur likes it, as I have never heard him use any as yet. Well, Mr. Morris sat down beside me and looked as happy and jolly as he could, but I could see all the same that he was very nervous. He took my hand in his, and said ever so sweetly:—
“‘Miss Lucy, I know I ain’t good enough to regulate the fixin’s of your little shoes, but I guess if you wait till you find a man that is you will go join them seven young women with the lamps when you quit. Won’t you just hitch up alongside of me and let us go down the long road together, driving in double harness?’
“Well, he did look so good-humoured and so jolly that it didn’t seem half so hard to refuse him as it did poor Dr. Seward; so I said, as lightly as I could, that I did not know anything of hitching, and that I wasn’t broken to harness at all yet. Then he said that he had spoken in a light manner, and he hoped that if he had made a mistake in doing so on so grave, so momentous, an occasion for him, I would forgive him. He really did look serious when he was saying it, and I couldn’t help feeling a bit serious too—I know, Mina, you will think me a horrid flirt—though I couldn’t help feeling a sort of exultation that he was number two in one day. And then, my dear, before I could say a word he began pouring out a perfect torrent of love-making, laying his very heart and soul at my feet. He looked so earnest over it that I shall never again think that a man must be playful always, and never earnest, because he is merry at times. I suppose he saw something in my face which checked him, for he suddenly stopped, and said with a sort of manly fervour that I could have loved him for if I had been free:—
“‘Lucy, you are an honest-hearted girl, I know. I should not be here speaking to you as I am now if I did not believe you clean grit, right through to the very depths of your soul. Tell me, like one good fellow to another, is there any one else that you care for? And if there is I’ll never trouble you a hair’s breadth again, but will be, if you will let me, a very faithful friend.’
“My dear Mina, why are men so noble when we women are so little worthy of them? Here was I almost making fun of this great-hearted, true gentleman. I burst into tears—I am afraid, my dear, you will think this a very sloppy letter in more ways than one—and I really felt very badly. Why can’t they let a girl marry three men, or as many as want her, and save all this trouble? But this is heresy, and I must not say it. I am glad to say that, though I was crying, I was able to look into Mr. Morris’s brave eyes, and I told him out straight:—
“‘Yes, there is some one I love, though he has not told me yet that he even loves me.’ I was right to speak to him so frankly, for quite a light came into his face, and he put out both his hands and took mine—I think I put them into his—and said in a hearty way:—
“‘That’s my brave girl. It’s better worth being late for a chance of winning you than being in time for any other girl in the world. Don’t cry, my dear. If it’s for me, I’m a hard nut to crack; and I take it standing up. If that other fellow doesn’t know his happiness, well, he’d better look for it soon, or he’ll have to deal with me. Little girl, your honesty and pluck have made me a friend, and that’s rarer than a lover; it’s more unselfish anyhow. My dear, I’m going to have a pretty lonely walk between this and Kingdom Come. Won’t you give me one kiss? It’ll be something to keep off the darkness now and then. You can, you know, if you like, for that other good fellow—he must be a good fellow, my dear, and a fine fellow, or you could not love him—hasn’t spoken yet.’ That quite won me, Mina, for it was brave and sweet of him, and noble, too, to a rival—wasn’t it?—and he so sad; so I leant over and kissed him. He stood up with my two hands in his, and as he looked down into my face—I am afraid I was blushing very much—he said:—
“‘Little girl, I hold your hand, and you’ve kissed me, and if these things don’t make us friends nothing ever will. Thank you for your sweet honesty to me, and good-bye.’ He wrung my hand, and taking up his hat, went straight out of the room without looking back, without a tear or a quiver or a pause; and I am crying like a baby. Oh, why must a man like that be made unhappy when there are lots of girls about who would worship the very ground he trod on? I know I would if I were free—only I don’t want to be free. My dear, this quite upset me, and I feel I cannot write of happiness just at once, after telling you of it; and I don’t wish to tell of the number three until it can be all happy.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Evening. I have just returned from a most exciting day, and I feel in better spirits, so I will write to you, my dearest Mina. I have had two suitors in one day, and I must tell you all about it. The first was Arthur, and I have written to you about him already. The second was a most unusual man, Mr. Quincey P. Morris, a Texan gentleman, who called after lunch. He is a most interesting person, full of life and adventure, and I found myself quite fascinated by his tales, as Desdemona might have been by Othello’s. I wonder sometimes if women marry men for the very reason that they are afraid, and so they choose a strong arm to lean on. Mr. Morris found me alone, which is a feat that men so often accomplish, though I must confess I did not make it difficult for him, as I had done for Arthur. He is a well-educated man, with the most refined manners, and yet he uses American slang with me, as if to amuse me. He was very nervous, though he tried to appear cheerful, and when he took my hand to propose, he did so in his own peculiar way, saying that he would be glad to go through life with me in double harness. I laughed at his good-humored way, and said I was not yet broken to harness, but he suddenly grew very serious, and said he was sorry if he had been too light-hearted for such a moment. I felt a strange mixture of solemnity and excitement at receiving a second proposal in one day. Before I could answer, he went on to speak of his love for me, and then, as if he saw something in my face, he stopped and asked me if I loved another, and said he would be a true friend if I did. I was so moved by his noble bearing that I could not help crying, and I told him I did love another, though that other had not yet said so to me. He said he admired my honesty, and that I had won a friend, which he said was rarer and more self-sacrificing than a lover. He said he would have to go on a lonely walk, and asked for a kiss to keep him from the darkness. I gave it to him, and he held my hands and said that my honesty and the kiss had made us friends, and then he thanked me and went away, without a sign of emotion. I am crying now, poor Quincey, for he is such a good man, and I do not see why he should be unhappy when so many would love him.

events.title: Lucy's Joyful Engagement to Arthur Holmwood Revealed in a Postscript
detailed_summary: In a postscript, Lucy addresses the matter of her third proposal, implying that Mina can likely guess the identity of 'number Three'.
She suggests the details are almost unnecessary to recount, or perhaps too overwhelming, as the proposal was a swift, almost instantaneous event.
Lucy describes the moment as a blur, from his entrance into the room to finding herself embraced and kissed by him.
She expresses profound and almost disbelieving happiness at this outcome.
Feeling a sense of unworthiness for such immense joy, Lucy resolves to spend her future demonstrating her gratitude to God for blessing her with such a wonderful lover, husband, and friend.
She concludes her letter with a final farewell.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: P.S.—Oh, about number Three—I needn’t tell you of number Three, need I?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Good-bye.

events.text_segment:
P.S.—Oh, about number Three—I needn’t tell you of number Three, need I? Besides, it was all so confused; it seemed only a moment from his coming into the room till both his arms were round me, and he was kissing me. I am very, very happy, and I don’t know what I have done to deserve it. I must only try in the future to show that I am not ungrateful to God for all His goodness to me in sending to me such a lover, such a husband, and such a friend.

“Good-bye.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: P.S.—Oh, about number Three—I needn’t tell you of number Three, need I? You can guess, I am sure, and if you can’t, I am not at liberty to say. But I will say this, that it was the most sudden and unexpected thing that ever happened to me. It was like a dream, or rather like a vision, for I can scarcely believe it myself. He came in, and before I knew what was happening, I was in his arms and he was kissing me. I was so startled at first, but then I felt such a rush of happiness that I could not help but return his kiss. I am so happy, Mina, so very happy. I feel as if I must have done something to deserve it, for it seems too good to be true. I shall try to make it all worth while, and to show, by my life and my love, how grateful I am to God for giving me such a wonderful lover, husband, and friend. Good-bye, dear Mina, and thank you for all your kindness and friendship.

But number Three—well, I think I had better say nothing. It is not that I fear to tell, but that I fear what might happen if I did. I shall say no more. I shall only say that number Three is not to be trusted, and that he is dangerous. —J. Seward

events.title: Dr. Seward's Despair Post-Rejection and Intensified Study of Patient Renfield
detailed_summary: Dr. Seward records in his phonograph diary his current state of diminished appetite and restlessness, a direct consequence of Lucy's rejection the previous day.
He experiences a profound sense of emptiness, feeling that nothing in the world holds sufficient importance to be worth pursuing.
Recognizing work as his sole remedy for such feelings, he has immersed himself among his patients.
He has chosen to focus his attention on one patient, R. M. Renfield, who has presented a particularly fascinating case study and whom Seward is determined to understand thoroughly.
Seward feels he is making progress in unraveling the core of Renfield's 'mystery.'
He recounts having questioned Renfield more extensively than ever before, aiming to fully grasp the details of the patient's hallucinations.

Upon reflection, Seward admits a certain cruelty in his recent method, acknowledging that he deliberately pushed Renfield to remain fixated on his madness—a practice he typically avoids as he would 'the mouth of hell.'
He muses philosophically on the idea that even 'hell has its price' and considers under what circumstances one might not avoid such a dangerous path.
Believing there might be something valuable behind Renfield's behavior, Seward resolves to document his observations meticulously from this point forward.
He provides a summary of Renfield: 59 years old, with a sanguine temperament, great physical strength, morbid excitability, and recurring periods of gloom that resolve into an obscure fixed idea.

Seward hypothesizes that Renfield's temperament and disturbing influences culminate in a dangerous mental state, particularly if Renfield were unselfish; selfish individuals, he notes, are protected by their caution.
He further theorizes on psychological dynamics, contrasting the balance of forces when 'self' is the central point versus when 'duty' or a 'cause' is the focus.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 25 May.—Ebb tide in appetite to-day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What I think of on this point is, when self is the fixed point the centripetal force is balanced with the centrifugal; when duty, a cause, etc., is the fixed point, the latter force is paramount, and only accident or a series of accidents can balance it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 25 May.—Ebb tide in appetite to-day. I feel restless and out of sorts. I suppose it is the effect of Lucy’s rejection yesterday. I have no heart for anything. I feel as if the world were a desert, and I were wandering through it without a purpose. I have taken to work as a remedy, and have been among my patients. I have selected one of them, a Mr. Renfield, as a special study, and I am determined to get to the bottom of his mystery. I have questioned him more than ever, and I think I am getting on. I have, I confess, been a little cruel in my method, for I have kept him fixed on his madness, which I would otherwise avoid as I would the mouth of hell. But I have been thinking that hell has its price, and that perhaps there is something behind it. I have made notes of him. He is 59 years of age, sanguine temperament, great physical strength, morbid excitability, and periods of gloom, which resolve into an obscure fixed idea. I think that his temperament, with the disturbing influences, would make a dangerous man if he were unselfish; for selfish men are protected by their caution. I have been thinking of the balance of forces when the self is the central point, and when the duty or the cause is the central point.
