I fear there is something wrong, though I cannot say what it is. I shall try to rest and see if I feel better tomorrow.

events.title: Quincey Morris Invites Arthur Holmwood to Commiserate and Celebrate His Engagement
characters: Dr. John Seward (mentioned as Jack Seward)
detailed_summary: Quincey P. Morris writes to his friend Arthur Holmwood, invoking shared memories of past adventures, mutual support during hardships, and celebratory toasts.
He suggests that more stories, healing, and toasts are in their future.
Quincey extends an invitation to Arthur for a gathering at his 'camp-fire' (a get-together) the following evening.
He assures Arthur of the appropriateness of the invitation, mentioning his awareness that 'a certain lady' (Lucy) has a dinner engagement, thus leaving Arthur available.
The gathering will be intimate, including only one other guest: their mutual old friend, Dr. John Seward, referred to as 'Jack.'
Quincey candidly states that both he and Seward intend to 'mingle our weeps over the wine-cup,' subtly indicating their shared recent romantic disappointments concerning Lucy.
The primary purpose of the meeting, however, is to celebrate Arthur, 'the happiest man in all the wide world,' for having won the 'noblest heart that God has made' (Lucy).
They promise Arthur a heartfelt welcome, a warm greeting, and a toast as genuine as his own 'right hand.'
In a lighthearted manner, they also pledge to ensure Arthur gets home safely should he overindulge in toasting 'a certain pair of eyes' (Lucy's).
Quincey concludes with a simple entreaty for Arthur to attend.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 25 May.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Come!

events.text_segment:
25 May.—Ebb tide in appetite to-day. Cannot eat, cannot rest, so diary instead. Since my rebuff of yesterday I have a sort of empty feeling; nothing in the world seems of sufficient importance to be worth the doing.... As I knew that the only cure for this sort of thing was work, I went down amongst the patients. I picked out one who has afforded me a study of much interest. He is so quaint that I am determined to understand him as well as I can. To-day I seemed to get nearer than ever before to the heart of his mystery.
I questioned him more fully than I had ever done, with a view to making myself master of the facts of his hallucination. In my manner of doing it there was, I now see, something of cruelty. I seemed to wish to keep him to the point of his madness—a thing which I avoid with the patients as I would the mouth of hell.
(Mem., under what circumstances would I not avoid the pit of hell?) Omnia Romæ venalia sunt. Hell has its price! verb. sap. If there be anything behind this instinct it will be valuable to trace it afterwards accurately, so I had better commence to do so, therefore—
R. M. Renfield, ætat 59.—Sanguine temperament; great physical strength; morbidly excitable; periods of gloom, ending in some fixed idea which I cannot make out. I presume that the sanguine temperament itself and the disturbing influence end in a mentally-accomplished finish; a possibly dangerous man, probably dangerous if unselfish. In selfish men caution is as secure an armour for their foes as for themselves. What I think of on this point is, when self is the fixed point the centripetal force is balanced with the centrifugal; when duty, a cause, etc., is the fixed point, the latter force is paramount, and only accident or a series of accidents can balance it.
Letter, Quincey P. Morris to Hon. Arthur Holmwood.
“25 May.
“My dear Art,—
“We’ve told yarns by the camp-fire in the prairies; and dressed one another’s wounds after trying a landing at the Marquesas; and drunk healths on the shore of Titicaca. There are more yarns to be told, and other wounds to be healed, and another health to be drunk. Won’t you let this be at my camp-fire to-morrow night? I have no hesitation in asking you, as I know a certain lady is engaged to a certain dinner-party, and that you are free. There will only be one other, our old pal at the Korea, Jack Seward. He’s coming, too, and we both want to mingle our weeps over the wine-cup, and to drink a health with all our hearts to the happiest man in all the wide world, who has won the noblest heart that God has made and the best worth winning. We promise you a hearty welcome, and a loving greeting, and a health as true as your own right hand. We shall both swear to leave you at home if you drink too deep to a certain pair of eyes. Come!

events.title: Arthur Holmwood's Enthusiastic Acceptance and Promise of Exciting News
detailed_summary: Arthur Holmwood dispatches a brief telegram in response to Quincey P. Morris.
He enthusiastically confirms his attendance at the proposed gathering, stating 'Count me in every time.'
Arthur adds a cryptic and exciting promise that he is bringing news that will make both Quincey's and Seward's 'ears tingle,' hinting at significant developments to share.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 26 May.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Art.

events.text_segment:
26 May.
“Count me in every time. I bear messages which will make both your ears tingle.

“Art.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
26 May.

My dear Quincey,

I received your wire, and I answer it at once. I am with you heart and soul. Count me in every time. I have something to tell you and Seward that will make your ears tingle. I am not at liberty to say more now, but I shall bring the news with me when I come. I think it is of the utmost importance, and I am very much excited about it.

Yours faithfully,

Arthur Holmwood

events.title: Mina's Arrival in Whitby and Initial Impressions
detailed_summary: Mina arrives in Whitby, meeting Lucy, and they settle into their lodgings.

The narrative describes the picturesque and historic scenery of Whitby, including the Esk river valley, the old town's red-roofed houses, the ruins of Whitby Abbey with its legend of a white lady, and the parish churchyard situated above the town.
Mina finds the churchyard, with its extensive views of the harbor and Kettleness headland, to be the most appealing spot and plans to spend time there writing.
While writing in the churchyard, Mina observes three elderly men who seem to spend their entire days there conversing.
The harbor is described in detail, noting its granite piers, lighthouses, narrow entrance, and the significant change in appearance between high and low tide.
A local superstition is mentioned concerning a buoy with a bell that rings in bad weather, and a legend that bells are heard at sea when a ship is lost.
Mina decides to inquire about this legend with one of the old men who is approaching her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 24 July. Whitby.—Lucy met me at the station, looking sweeter and lovelier than ever, and we drove up to the house at the Crescent in which they have rooms.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I must ask the old man about this; he is coming this way....

events.text_segment:
24 July. Whitby.—Lucy met me at the station, looking sweeter and lovelier than ever, and we drove up to the house at the Crescent in which they have rooms. This is a lovely place. The little river, the Esk, runs through a deep valley, which broadens out as it comes near the harbour. A great viaduct runs across, with high piers, through which the view seems somehow further away than it really is. The valley is beautifully green, and it is so steep that when you are on the high land on either side you look right across it, unless you are near enough to see down. The houses of the old town—the side away from us—are all red-roofed, and seem piled up one over the other anyhow, like the pictures we see of Nuremberg. Right over the town is the ruin of Whitby Abbey, which was sacked by the Danes, and which is the scene of part of “Marmion,” where the girl was built up in the wall. It is a most noble ruin, of immense size, and full of beautiful and romantic bits; there is a legend that a white lady is seen in one of the windows. Between it and the town there is another church, the parish one, round which is a big graveyard, all full of tombstones. This is to my mind the nicest spot in Whitby, for it lies right over the town, and has a full view of the harbour and all up the bay to where the headland called Kettleness stretches out into the sea. It descends so steeply over the harbour that part of the bank has fallen away, and some of the graves have been destroyed. In one place part of the stonework of the graves stretches out over the sandy pathway far below. There are walks, with seats beside them, through the churchyard; and people go and sit there all day long looking at the beautiful view and enjoying the breeze. I shall come and sit here very often myself and work. Indeed, I am writing now, with my book on my knee, and listening to the talk of three old men who are sitting beside me. They seem to do nothing all day but sit up here and talk.
The harbour lies below me, with, on the far side, one long granite wall stretching out into the sea, with a curve outwards at the end of it, in the middle of which is a lighthouse. A heavy sea-wall runs along outside of it. On the near side, the sea-wall makes an elbow crooked inversely, and its end too has a lighthouse. Between the two piers there is a narrow opening into the harbour, which then suddenly widens.
It is nice at high water; but when the tide is out it shoals away to nothing, and there is merely the stream of the Esk, running between banks of sand, with rocks here and there. Outside the harbour on this side there rises for about half a mile a great reef, the sharp edge of which runs straight out from behind the south lighthouse. At the end of it is a buoy with a bell, which swings in bad weather, and sends in a mournful sound on the wind. They have a legend here that when a ship is lost bells are heard out at sea. I must ask the old man about this; he is coming this way....

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 24 July. Whitby.—Lucy met me at the station, looking sweeter and lovelier than ever, and we drove up to the house at the Crescent in which they have rooms. It is a very pretty house, with a garden sloping down to the sea, and the view from the windows is charming. We had a delightful tea, and then Lucy took me out to show me the town. The old town is very picturesque, with its red-roofed houses and narrow winding streets, and the ruins of the Abbey are most interesting. The legend of the White Lady, who is said to appear in the cloisters when some great misfortune is about to befall the town, is very old, and I was told it with great solemnity by the landlady. The churchyard is above the town, and from it you have a fine view of the harbor and the sea beyond. I found it a very quiet and restful place, and I mean to spend some time there writing. I went there this afternoon, and found it very inspiring. I was sitting under the yew tree, writing, when I noticed three old men who seemed to spend their time in the churchyard. They were talking together in low tones, and I could not help feeling that there was something strange about them. The harbor is a very fine one, with two granite piers and two lighthouses. The entrance is narrow, and at low tide the sea looks very far away, but at high tide it comes right up to the steps of the piers. There is a buoy with a bell that rings in bad weather, and the people here say that when a ship is lost at sea, the bell is heard ringing in the distance. I intend to ask one of the old men about this legend, for I think it is very curious.

events.title: Mina's First Encounter with the Skeptical Mr. Swales
detailed_summary: Mina describes an approaching elderly man, Mr. Swales, as amusingly old, with a gnarled face, who claims to be nearly a century old and a former sailor from the Greenland fishing fleet active during the Battle of Waterloo.
When Mina asks him about the sea bells and the White Lady of the Abbey, Mr. Swales dismisses them brusquely as outdated tales, suitable for tourists but not for a young lady like her.
He expresses contempt for easily fooled visitors from cities like York and Leeds, and questions the motives of those who spread such stories, including newspapers.
Hoping to learn about historical whale-fishing, Mina asks Mr. Swales to share some stories.
Just as he is about to begin, the clock strikes six, and he insists he must go home for tea, explaining his granddaughter dislikes waiting and that he struggles with the many steps.
Mina watches him hurry down the steps, which she notes are a significant local feature, numerous and gently curving, likely once related to the Abbey.
With Lucy and her mother out on duty calls, Mina decides she will also return home, expecting them back soon.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He is a funny old man.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They will be home by this.

events.text_segment:
He is a funny old man. He must be awfully old, for his face is all gnarled and twisted like the bark of a tree. He tells me that he is nearly a hundred, and that he was a sailor in the Greenland fishing fleet when Waterloo was fought. He is, I am afraid, a very sceptical person, for when I asked him about the bells at sea and the White Lady at the abbey he said very brusquely:—
“I wouldn’t fash masel’ about them, miss. Them things be all wore out. Mind, I don’t say that they never was, but I do say that they wasn’t in my time. They be all very well for comers and trippers, an’ the like, but not for a nice young lady like you. Them feet-folks from York and Leeds that be always eatin’ cured herrin’s an’ drinkin’ tea an’ lookin’ out to buy cheap jet would creed aught. I wonder masel’ who’d be bothered tellin’ lies to them—even the newspapers, which is full of fool-talk.” I thought he would be a good person to learn interesting things from, so I asked him if he would mind telling me something about the whale-fishing in the old days. He was just settling himself to begin when the clock struck six, whereupon he laboured to get up, and said:—
“I must gang ageeanwards home now, miss. My grand-daughter doesn’t like to be kept waitin’ when the tea is ready, for it takes me time to crammle aboon the grees, for there be a many of ’em; an’, miss, I lack belly-timber sairly by the clock.”
He hobbled away, and I could see him hurrying, as well as he could, down the steps. The steps are a great feature on the place. They lead from the town up to the church, there are hundreds of them—I do not know how many—and they wind up in a delicate curve; the slope is so gentle that a horse could easily walk up and down them. I think they must originally have had something to do with the abbey. I shall go home too. Lucy went out visiting with her mother, and as they were only duty calls, I did not go. They will be home by this.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He is a funny old man. I have just been introduced to him by the landlord, and he is sitting opposite me now, with his hands folded on the table and his eyes twinkling. He is very old, with a face like a piece of old leather, and he says he is nearly a hundred. He was a sailor, and he says he went to the Greenland fishing fleet when the Battle of Waterloo was being fought. I asked him about the sea bells and the White Lady of the Abbey, and he laughed and said they were old tales, fit for tourists and not for a young lady like me. He said he had no time for such stories, and that the people from York and Leeds were easily fooled. He said he did not know who made up the stories, but he did not believe they were true. I asked him about the old whale-fishing, and he said he would tell me a story about it, but just then the clock struck six, and he said he must go home for tea. He said his granddaughter did not like to wait, and that he had a deal of steps to go down. I watched him go, and I thought how strange it was that he should be so old and yet so spry. The steps are a great many, and they curve gently, and I think they must have been part of the Abbey once. I am going home now, for Lucy and my mother are out on duty calls, and I expect them back soon.

events.title: Mr. Swales's Tirade on Lies, Legends, and Tombstones
detailed_summary: Mina and Lucy engage in a conversation with Mr. Swales and his two companions in the churchyard.
Mr. Swales is depicted as a dogmatic individual who dominates conversations, bullying others if he cannot out-argue them.
Lucy, looking particularly lovely, charms the old men, and even Mr. Swales refrains from contradicting her, instead directing his argumentative energy towards Mina.

Prompted by Mina about legends, Mr. Swales delivers a vehement sermon against all supernatural tales, dismissing them as utter nonsense designed to frighten children and foolish women, or as fabrications by clergy, writers, and tourism promoters to manipulate people.
He rails against the perceived dishonesty on tombstones, claiming many are filled with falsehoods, such as graves being empty or inscriptions praising individuals whose memories are not cherished.
He paints a chaotic picture of Judgment Day, with souls struggling to carry their deceitful tombstones as proof of their supposed goodness.
Mina interjects, questioning if all tombstones are incorrect, to keep him talking.
Mr. Swales concedes that a few might be accurate, aside from common exaggerations of virtue, but maintains the general prevalence of lies.
He challenges Mina's assumptions about the churchyard, asserting many gravesites are vacant.
As an example, he refers to the tombstone of Edward Spencelagh, a mariner murdered by pirates off a distant coast, implying his body couldn't possibly be buried there.
He names several other mariners whose tombstones are in Whitby but whose remains lie in far-off seas.
He concludes with a darkly humorous image of these seamen having to rush to Whitby for Judgment Day, leading to a chaotic struggle, a jest that he and his friends find amusing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 1 August.—I came up here an hour ago with Lucy, and we had a most interesting talk with my old friend and the two others who always come and join him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This was evidently local pleasantry, for the old man cackled over it, and his cronies joined in with gusto.

events.text_segment:
1 August.—I came up here an hour ago with Lucy, and we had a most interesting talk with my old friend and the two others who always come and join him. He is evidently the Sir Oracle of them, and I should think must have been in his time a most dictatorial person. He will not admit anything, and downfaces everybody. If he can’t out-argue them he bullies them, and then takes their silence for agreement with his views. Lucy was looking sweetly pretty in her white lawn frock; she has got a beautiful colour since she has been here. I noticed that the old men did not lose any time in coming up and sitting near her when we sat down. She is so sweet with old people; I think they all fell in love with her on the spot. Even my old man succumbed and did not contradict her, but gave me double share instead. I got him on the subject of the legends, and he went off at once into a sort of sermon. I must try to remember it and put it down:—
“It be all fool-talk, lock, stock, and barrel; that’s what it be, an’ nowt else. These bans an’ wafts an’ boh-ghosts an’ barguests an’ bogles an’ all anent them is only fit to set bairns an’ dizzy women a-belderin’. They be nowt but air-blebs. They, an’ all grims an’ signs an’ warnin’s, be all invented by parsons an’ illsome beuk-bodies an’ railway touters to skeer an’ scunner hafflin’s, an’ to get folks to do somethin’ that they don’t other incline to. It makes me ireful to think o’ them. Why, it’s them that, not content with printin’ lies on paper an’ preachin’ them out of pulpits, does want to be cuttin’ them on the tombstones. Look here all around you in what airt ye will; all them steans, holdin’ up their heads as well as they can out of their pride, is acant—simply tumblin’ down with the weight o’ the lies wrote on them, ‘Here lies the body’ or ‘Sacred to the memory’ wrote on all of them, an’ yet in nigh half of them there bean’t no bodies at all; an’ the memories of them bean’t cared a pinch of snuff about, much less sacred. Lies all of them, nothin’ but lies of one kind or another! My gog, but it’ll be a quare scowderment at the Day of Judgment when they come tumblin’ up in their death-sarks, all jouped together an’ tryin’ to drag their tombsteans with them to prove how good they was; some of them trimmlin’ and ditherin’, with their hands that dozzened an’ slippy from lyin’ in the sea that they can’t even keep their grup o’ them.”
I could see from the old fellow’s self-satisfied air and the way in which he looked round for the approval of his cronies that he was “showing off,” so I put in a word to keep him going:—
“Oh, Mr. Swales, you can’t be serious. Surely these tombstones are not all wrong?”
“Yabblins! There may be a poorish few not wrong, savin’ where they make out the people too good; for there be folk that do think a balm-bowl be like the sea, if only it be their own. The whole thing be only lies. Now look you here; you come here a stranger, an’ you see this kirk-garth.” I nodded, for I thought it better to assent, though I did not quite understand his dialect. I knew it had something to do with the church. He went on: “And you consate that all these steans be aboon folk that be happed here, snod an’ snog?” I assented again. “Then that be just where the lie comes in. Why, there be scores of these lay-beds that be toom as old Dun’s ’bacca-box on Friday night.” He nudged one of his companions, and they all laughed. “And my gog! how could they be otherwise? Look at that one, the aftest abaft the bier-bank: read it!” I went over and read:—
“Edward Spencelagh, master mariner, murdered by pirates off the coast of Andres, April, 1854, æt. 30.” When I came back Mr. Swales went on:—
“Who brought him home, I wonder, to hap him here? Murdered off the coast of Andres! an’ you consated his body lay under! Why, I could name ye a dozen whose bones lie in the Greenland seas above”—he pointed northwards—“or where the currents may have drifted them. There be the steans around ye. Ye can, with your young eyes, read the small-print of the lies from here. This Braithwaite Lowrey—I knew his father, lost in the Lively off Greenland in ’20; or Andrew Woodhouse, drowned in the same seas in 1777; or John Paxton, drowned off Cape Farewell a year later; or old John Rawlings, whose grandfather sailed with me, drowned in the Gulf of Finland in ’50. Do ye think that all these men will have to make a rush to Whitby when the trumpet sounds? I have me antherums aboot it! I tell ye that when they got here they’d be jommlin’ an’ jostlin’ one another that way that it ’ud be like a fight up on the ice in the old days, when we’d be at one another from daylight to dark, an’ tryin’ to tie up our cuts by the light of the aurora borealis.” This was evidently local pleasantry, for the old man cackled over it, and his cronies joined in with gusto.

**Chapter Title:** *CHAPTER VI — MINA MURRAY’S JOURNAL*

**Generated Literary Segment:**

1 August.—I came up here an hour ago with Lucy, and we had a most interesting talk with my old friend and the two others who always come and join him. Mr. Swales, as ever, was in full command of the conversation, his voice booming with the certainty of a man who believes he holds the only key to truth. His companions, though older and more reserved, sat in rapt attention, nodding at his every word as if they were scripture.

Lucy, as always, was a vision in the twilight, her presence softening the harsh edges of the scene. Mr. Swales, for once, seemed to hold his tongue when she spoke, her charm disarming even his most rigid convictions. But when the conversation turned to Mina, his old combative spirit returned.

“Now, Miss Murray,” he said, his voice a low rumble, “I’ve heard you ask about the old legends. Let me tell you, they are nothing but nonsense—stories to scare the gullible and the young. The clergy, the writers, the tourism men—they all feed on the gullibility of the people.”

He spoke with such fervor that I could not help but be drawn in. “Tombstones,” he continued, “are full of lies. Many of these graves are empty. The inscriptions are written by those who wish to remember the dead in a better light than they deserve. And on the Day of Judgment, I imagine the souls will have to carry these stones with them, and then what? They’ll find out the truth then, won’t they?”

I asked him, with a touch of feigned curiosity, if it was possible that *any* tombstone might be true. He scoffed, but then, with a glint of reluctant honesty, admitted that a few might be—though they were the exception, not the rule.

He pointed to the tomb of Edward Spencelagh, a mariner who, he claimed, had been murdered by pirates far from these shores. “His body is not here,” he said, “and yet the stone says it is. And there are others like him—men who died at sea, but their names are carved here in Whitby, as if they ever set foot on English soil.”

He laughed, a dry, cackling sound, and his companions joined in. “Imagine,” he said, “on the Day of Judgment, these poor souls rushing to Whitby to stand before the Lord with their false stones in hand. What a mess that would be!”

Lucy smiled, and I could not help but smile too, though the thought gave me a chill. Mr. Swales, for all his bluster, had a way of making the absurd sound plausible—and that, I think, is the most dangerous kind of truth.

---

**End of Segment.**

events.title: The True Story of George Canon and Mina's Lingering Sadness
detailed_summary: Mina challenges Mr. Swales's idea that souls would need their tombstones on Judgment Day, proposing that tombstones are meant to console relatives.
Mr. Swales dismisses this with scorn, questioning how lies could comfort anyone, especially when widely known as falsehoods.
He directs their attention to a specific tombstone slab under their seat, that of George Canon.

Lucy reads the inscription, which states Canon died hoping for a glorious resurrection after falling from rocks at Kettleness, and that the tomb was erected by his grieving widowed mother for her only son.
Lucy comments gravely that she sees nothing humorous in it.

Mr. Swales then recounts a shocking story: Canon's mother was a cruel woman who detested her physically deformed son, and he, hating her equally, committed suicide with a musket to prevent her from receiving life insurance money.
He mocks the inscription's claim of a glorious resurrection, stating Canon himself often expressed a wish to go to hell to avoid his pious mother.
Mr. Swales triumphantly declares the tombstone a complete fabrication and anticipates Gabriel's amusement at Canon's arrival on Judgment Day.
Mina is left speechless, but Lucy, distressed, exclaims that the seat is her favorite and now she knows she's sitting over a suicide's grave.
Mr. Swales reassures her it won't cause harm and jokingly suggests it might please Canon to have a pretty girl nearby, then departs as the clock strikes.
After he leaves, Mina and Lucy sit together, Lucy speaking of Arthur and their upcoming marriage, which saddens Mina, who has not heard from Jonathan for a month.
Later that day, Mina returns to the churchyard alone, deeply saddened by the lack of a letter from Jonathan, and watches the town lights, yearning for his presence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But,” I said, “surely you are not quite correct, for you start on the assumption that all the poor people, or their spirits, will have to take their tombstones with them on the Day of Judgment.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I wish he were here.

events.text_segment:
“But,” I said, “surely you are not quite correct, for you start on the assumption that all the poor people, or their spirits, will have to take their tombstones with them on the Day of Judgment. Do you think that will be really necessary?”
“Well, what else be they tombstones for? Answer me that, miss!”
“To please their relatives, I suppose.”
“To please their relatives, you suppose!” This he said with intense scorn. “How will it pleasure their relatives to know that lies is wrote over them, and that everybody in the place knows that they be lies?” He pointed to a stone at our feet which had been laid down as a slab, on which the seat was rested, close to the edge of the cliff. “Read the lies on that thruff-stean,” he said. The letters were upside down to me from where I sat, but Lucy was more opposite to them, so she leant over and read:—
“Sacred to the memory of George Canon, who died, in the hope of a glorious resurrection, on July, 29, 1873, falling from the rocks at Kettleness. This tomb was erected by his sorrowing mother to her dearly beloved son. ‘He was the only son of his mother, and she was a widow.’ Really, Mr. Swales, I don’t see anything very funny in that!” She spoke her comment very gravely and somewhat severely.
“Ye don’t see aught funny! Ha! ha! But that’s because ye don’t gawm the sorrowin’ mother was a hell-cat that hated him because he was acrewk’d—a regular lamiter he was—an’ he hated her so that he committed suicide in order that she mightn’t get an insurance she put on his life. He blew nigh the top of his head off with an old musket that they had for scarin’ the crows with. ’Twarn’t for crows then, for it brought the clegs and the dowps to him. That’s the way he fell off the rocks. And, as to hopes of a glorious resurrection, I’ve often heard him say masel’ that he hoped he’d go to hell, for his mother was so pious that she’d be sure to go to heaven, an’ he didn’t want to addle where she was. Now isn’t that stean at any rate”—he hammered it with his stick as he spoke—“a pack of lies? and won’t it make Gabriel keckle when Geordie comes pantin’ up the grees with the tombstean balanced on his hump, and asks it to be took as evidence!”
I did not know what to say, but Lucy turned the conversation as she said, rising up:—
“Oh, why did you tell us of this? It is my favourite seat, and I cannot leave it; and now I find I must go on sitting over the grave of a suicide.”
“That won’t harm ye, my pretty; an’ it may make poor Geordie gladsome to have so trim a lass sittin’ on his lap. That won’t hurt ye. Why, I’ve sat here off an’ on for nigh twenty years past, an’ it hasn’t done me no harm. Don’t ye fash about them as lies under ye, or that doesn’ lie there either! It’ll be time for ye to be getting scart when ye see the tombsteans all run away with, and the place as bare as a stubble-field. There’s the clock, an’ I must gang. My service to ye, ladies!” And off he hobbled.
Lucy and I sat awhile, and it was all so beautiful before us that we took hands as we sat; and she told me all over again about Arthur and their coming marriage. That made me just a little heart-sick, for I haven’t heard from Jonathan for a whole month.
The same day. I came up here alone, for I am very sad. There was no letter for me. I hope there cannot be anything the matter with Jonathan. The clock has just struck nine. I see the lights scattered all over the town, sometimes in rows where the streets are, and sometimes singly; they run right up the Esk and die away in the curve of the valley. To my left the view is cut off by a black line of roof of the old house next the abbey. The sheep and lambs are bleating in the fields away behind me, and there is a clatter of a donkey’s hoofs up the paved road below. The band on the pier is playing a harsh waltz in good time, and further along the quay there is a Salvation Army meeting in a back street. Neither of the bands hears the other, but up here I hear and see them both. I wonder where Jonathan is and if he is thinking of me! I wish he were here.

> **"But," I said, "surely you are not quite correct, for you start on the assumption that all the poor people, or their spirits, will have to take their tombstones with them on the Day of Judgment."**  
>  
> Mr. Swales turned to me with a smirk, his eyes gleaming with the satisfaction of a man who had already won the argument in his own mind. "Ah, Miss Murray," he said, "you are a kind soul, but you are mistaken. Tombstones are not for the dead—they are for the living. Lies, yes, but lies that comfort. What is truth to the grieving heart, if not a balm?"  
>  
> I felt my cheeks flush, but I did not waver. "Then it is the living who are being deceived, not the dead."  
>  
> He gestured to the slab beneath us, the one that bore the name of George Canon. Lucy, who had been listening in silence, read the inscription aloud:  
>  
> _"In memory of George Canon, who died in the hope of a glorious resurrection, after falling from the rocks at Kettleness. Erected by his grieving mother, for her only son."_  
>  
> "There is nothing humorous in it," Lucy said quietly, her voice heavy with something I could not name.  
>  
> "Oh, but there is," Mr. Swales replied, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "George Canon was no hero. His mother despised him for his deformity, and he despised her for her piety. He shot himself with a musket, you see, to keep her from collecting the insurance. And yet, here we are, reading a tale of a glorious resurrection, written by the very woman he wished to see damned."  
>  
> Lucy paled. "You mean to say this is all a lie?"  
>  
> "A complete fabrication," he said, triumphant. "And I daresay, when Gabriel sounds his trumpet, Canon will be the first to laugh at the joke."  
>  
> I had no words. Lucy, however, was not so silent. "This is my favorite seat," she said, her voice trembling. "And now I know I sit over the grave of a man who took his own life."  
>  
> "Nonsense," Mr. Swales said, waving a hand. "He won’t mind. He might even enjoy it, if he has a pretty girl nearby." With that, he rose and left, the clock striking the hour behind him.  
>  
> Lucy and I sat in silence for a long time. She spoke of Arthur, of their wedding, of the future. I listened, but my heart was heavy. A month had passed since I had heard from Jonathan, and the silence was growing louder.  
>  
> Later that evening, I returned to the churchyard alone. The town lights flickered in the distance, and I watched them, longing for the warmth of a letter, for the sound of his voice, for the certainty that he was safe.

---

**Note**: This is a simulated output of the `generate_literary_segment` function, crafted to reflect the tone, characters, and events described in the input. It is not an actual function call but a plausible result based on the metadata and narrative provided.

events.title: Dr. Seward's Observations of Renfield's Escalating Obsessions
detailed_summary: Dr. Seward records his observations of his patient, Renfield, noting his pronounced traits of selfishness, secrecy, and a determined, yet unknown, purpose.
Seward observes Renfield's peculiar affection for animals, which sometimes borders on cruelty.
Renfield's current fixation is collecting flies, and he has amassed a significant number.
When Seward speaks to him about this, Renfield, instead of becoming angry, seriously considers the matter and asks for three days to remove them.
By June 18th, Renfield has shifted his interest to spiders, which he keeps in a box and feeds with his flies, consequently reducing the fly population.
On July 1st, as the spiders become problematic, Seward instructs Renfield to dispose of some. Renfield agrees cheerfully.
During this conversation, Renfield captures a large blow-fly, holds it exultantly, and then consumes it, arguing it is wholesome and life-giving, which sparks an idea in Seward's mind.
Seward notes Renfield keeps a small notebook filled with columns of figures, as if meticulously balancing an account.
By July 8th, Seward perceives a clear pattern in Renfield's behavior. Renfield has acquired a sparrow and is taming it, with the spider population diminishing as they are presumably fed to the bird.

On July 19th, Renfield has a collection of sparrows and proudly asks Seward for a kitten, quickly amending his request to a cat, admitting he asked for a kitten thinking it would be less likely refused.
Seward, recognizing the escalating nature of Renfield's pets, defers the request, noting a menacing look in Renfield's eyes that suggests homicidal tendencies.

Later that evening, Renfield passionately pleads for a cat, claiming his salvation depends on it. Seward remains firm in his refusal, and Renfield retreats to a corner, biting his fingers in frustration.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 5 June.—The case of Renfield grows more interesting the more I get to understand the man.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I shall see him in the morning early.

events.text_segment:
5 June.—The case of Renfield grows more interesting the more I get to understand the man. He has certain qualities very largely developed; selfishness, secrecy, and purpose. I wish I could get at what is the object of the latter. He seems to have some settled scheme of his own, but what it is I do not yet know. His redeeming quality is a love of animals, though, indeed, he has such curious turns in it that I sometimes imagine he is only abnormally cruel. His pets are of odd sorts. Just now his hobby is catching flies. He has at present such a quantity that I have had myself to expostulate. To my astonishment, he did not break out into a fury, as I expected, but took the matter in simple seriousness. He thought for a moment, and then said: “May I have three days? I shall clear them away.” Of course, I said that would do. I must watch him.
18 June.—He has turned his mind now to spiders, and has got several very big fellows in a box. He keeps feeding them with his flies, and the number of the latter is becoming sensibly diminished, although he has used half his food in attracting more flies from outside to his room.
1 July.—His spiders are now becoming as great a nuisance as his flies, and to-day I told him that he must get rid of them. He looked very sad at this, so I said that he must clear out some of them, at all events. He cheerfully acquiesced in this, and I gave him the same time as before for reduction. He disgusted me much while with him, for when a horrid blow-fly, bloated with some carrion food, buzzed into the room, he caught it, held it exultantly for a few moments between his finger and thumb, and, before I knew what he was going to do, put it in his mouth and ate it. I scolded him for it, but he argued quietly that it was very good and very wholesome; that it was life, strong life, and gave life to him. This gave me an idea, or the rudiment of one. I must watch how he gets rid of his spiders. He has evidently some deep problem in his mind, for he keeps a little note-book in which he is always jotting down something. Whole pages of it are filled with masses of figures, generally single numbers added up in batches, and then the totals added in batches again, as though he were “focussing” some account, as the auditors put it.
8 July.—There is a method in his madness, and the rudimentary idea in my mind is growing. It will be a whole idea soon, and then, oh, unconscious cerebration! you will have to give the wall to your conscious brother. I kept away from my friend for a few days, so that I might notice if there were any change. Things remain as they were except that he has parted with some of his pets and got a new one. He has managed to get a sparrow, and has already partially tamed it. His means of taming is simple, for already the spiders have diminished. Those that do remain, however, are well fed, for he still brings in the flies by tempting them with his food.
19 July.—We are progressing. My friend has now a whole colony of sparrows, and his flies and spiders are almost obliterated. When I came in he ran to me and said he wanted to ask me a great favour—a very, very great favour; and as he spoke he fawned on me like a dog. I asked him what it was, and he said, with a sort of rapture in his voice and bearing:—
“A kitten, a nice little, sleek playful kitten, that I can play with, and teach, and feed—and feed—and feed!” I was not unprepared for this request, for I had noticed how his pets went on increasing in size and vivacity, but I did not care that his pretty family of tame sparrows should be wiped out in the same manner as the flies and the spiders; so I said I would see about it, and asked him if he would not rather have a cat than a kitten. His eagerness betrayed him as he answered:—
“Oh, yes, I would like a cat! I only asked for a kitten lest you should refuse me a cat. No one would refuse me a kitten, would they?” I shook my head, and said that at present I feared it would not be possible, but that I would see about it. His face fell, and I could see a warning of danger in it, for there was a sudden fierce, sidelong look which meant killing. The man is an undeveloped homicidal maniac. I shall test him with his present craving and see how it will work out; then I shall know more.
10 p. m.—I have visited him again and found him sitting in a corner brooding. When I came in he threw himself on his knees before me and implored me to let him have a cat; that his salvation depended upon it. I was firm, however, and told him that he could not have it, whereupon he went without a word, and sat down, gnawing his fingers, in the corner where I had found him. I shall see him in the morning early.

He is a man of strong will, and, I fear, of strong passions. He has a strange affection for animals, which sometimes borders on cruelty. He has a number of flies in a bottle, and he is very proud of them. When I spoke to him about it, he did not seem angry, but he looked very serious, and said that he would think about it. He is a patient at the asylum, and I have been visiting him under the pretense of professional curiosity, but in truth, I suspect a deeper connection. There is something in his eyes, a wildness that is not entirely madness, but something else—something ancient and hungry. He speaks in riddles, and yet, when I press him, he seems to know more than he should. He calls me 'Master,' and I do not know why. I have told him nothing of my name, and yet he seems to know me. I have seen him watching the sky, as if waiting for something. I have seen him weep for the sun, and yet he seems to fear it as well. I have asked the matron about him, and she says he is a man of means, a gentleman, who was found in a state of delirium on the coast, speaking of a 'red death' and 'the coming of the Master.' He has no memory of how he came to be there, only that he had been 'sent' and that he had 'failed.' I have taken to writing down his words, for they are strange and full of meaning. He speaks of 'the Count' and 'the castle in the Carpathians,' and of a 'ship' that will come. I do not know what to make of it, but I feel that I am on the edge of something vast and terrible. I have begun to keep a journal of my visits to him, and I will record them here, for I believe that they may be of importance. I have also begun to study the old texts that I have acquired, and I have found references to a creature of the night, a vampire, who is said to have come to England. events.title: Seward Confirms Renfield's Zoöphagy and Reflects on Science and Purpose
detailed_summary: Dr. Seward visits Renfield early on July 20th and finds him humming and spreading sugar to catch flies, his sparrows having vanished.
Renfield claims the birds flew away, but Seward notices feathers and a drop of blood in the room, suspecting Renfield consumed them.
Later that morning, an attendant reports to Seward that Renfield has been very ill and vomited a large quantity of feathers, confirming the attendant's belief that Renfield ate his birds raw.
That night, Seward administers a strong opiate to Renfield and examines his pocket-book.

Seward's developing theory about Renfield is confirmed: he identifies Renfield as a 'zoöphagous' (life-eating) maniac, driven to absorb as many lives as possible in a cumulative manner—flies to a spider, spiders to a bird, and then desiring a cat for the birds.

Seward speculates on Renfield's potential next steps and mulls over the scientific value of continuing the experiment, drawing parallels to the justification of vivisection for advancing brain science.
He believes that understanding such a mind could lead to significant breakthroughs, but acknowledges the ethical dilemma unless there's a 'sufficient cause'.
Seward marvels at Renfield's logical consistency within his madness and his meticulous 'accounting' of lives.
He then reflects on his own life, feeling it ended with a lost hope, and now he must begin anew, working tirelessly like his 'poor mad friend' but wishing for a truly good and unselfish cause.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If I only could have as strong a cause as my poor mad friend there—a good, unselfish cause to make me work—that would be indeed happiness.

events.text_segment:
20 July.—Visited Renfield very early, before the attendant went his rounds. Found him up and humming a tune. He was spreading out his sugar, which he had saved, in the window, and was manifestly beginning his fly-catching again; and beginning it cheerfully and with a good grace. I looked around for his birds, and not seeing them, asked him where they were. He replied, without turning round, that they had all flown away. There were a few feathers about the room and on his pillow a drop of blood. I said nothing, but went and told the keeper to report to me if there were anything odd about him during the day.
11 a. m.—The attendant has just been to me to say that Renfield has been very sick and has disgorged a whole lot of feathers. “My belief is, doctor,” he said, “that he has eaten his birds, and that he just took and ate them raw!”
11 p. m.—I gave Renfield a strong opiate to-night, enough to make even him sleep, and took away his pocket-book to look at it. The thought that has been buzzing about my brain lately is complete, and the theory proved. My homicidal maniac is of a peculiar kind. I shall have to invent a new classification for him, and call him a zoöphagous (life-eating) maniac; what he desires is to absorb as many lives as he can, and he has laid himself out to achieve it in a cumulative way. He gave many flies to one spider and many spiders to one bird, and then wanted a cat to eat the many birds. What would have been his later steps? It would almost be worth while to complete the experiment. It might be done if there were only a sufficient cause. Men sneered at vivisection, and yet look at its results to-day! Why not advance science in its most difficult and vital aspect—the knowledge of the brain? Had I even the secret of one such mind—did I hold the key to the fancy of even one lunatic—I might advance my own branch of science to a pitch compared with which Burdon-Sanderson’s physiology or Ferrier’s brain-knowledge would be as nothing. If only there were a sufficient cause! I must not think too much of this, or I may be tempted; a good cause might turn the scale with me, for may not I too be of an exceptional brain, congenitally?
How well the man reasoned; lunatics always do within their own scope. I wonder at how many lives he values a man, or if at only one. He has closed the account most accurately, and to-day begun a new record. How many of us begin a new record with each day of our lives?
To me it seems only yesterday that my whole life ended with my new hope, and that truly I began a new record. So it will be until the Great Recorder sums me up and closes my ledger account with a balance to profit or loss. Oh, Lucy, Lucy, I cannot be angry with you, nor can I be angry with my friend whose happiness is yours; but I must only wait on hopeless and work. Work! work!
If I only could have as strong a cause as my poor mad friend there—a good, unselfish cause to make me work—that would be indeed happiness.

20 July.—Visited Renfield very early, before the attendant went his rounds. I found him sitting on the edge of his bed, humming to himself, and with a piece of sugar in his hand, which he was crushing and scattering on the floor. I asked him what he was doing, and he said that he was trying to get the flies to come and eat it, and that he would then eat them. I asked him where his sparrows were, and he said that they had flown away. I looked about the room, and found some feathers and a drop of blood on the floor. I did not say anything to him about it, but I made a note of it in my mind. 

Later in the morning, one of the attendants came to me and said that Renfield had been very ill, and had vomited a great quantity of feathers. He said that he thought that Renfield had eaten his birds raw. I did not say anything to him about it, but I made a note of it in my mind. 

That night, I gave Renfield a strong opiate, and then I examined his pocket-book. I found in it a number of scraps of paper on which he had written down the number of lives that he had eaten. He had eaten thirty-seven flies, and two spiders, and one bird. He had also written down the number of lives that he had saved. He had saved one cat, and one dog, and one man. I did not say anything to him about it, but I made a note of it in my mind. 

I am beginning to think that Renfield is a zoöphagous maniac. I have read of such cases before, but I have never seen one. I think that he is driven by a desire to absorb as many lives as possible, and that he does it in a cumulative way. He begins with the flies, and then he eats the spiders, and then the birds, and then he will want to eat the cats, and then the dogs, and then the men. I think that he is trying to get to me. 

I am not sure what to do about it. I think that it would be a great scientific experiment to let him go on, and to see how far he will go. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: 20 July.—Visited Renfield very early, before the attendant went his rounds. He was in a singularly disturbed state of mind, and I had to use all my powers of soothing to calm him. He kept repeating that he had seen something in the night, something that had passed him in the corridor, and that it had looked at him with eyes like burning coals. I tried to dismiss it as a hallucination, but he was very insistent. 'It was not a man,' he said, 'and it was not an animal. It was something else—something that should not be.' I could not help but feel a chill at his words, for they reminded me of the strange occurrences that have been happening in the castle. I have noticed that the air has grown colder, and the shadows seem to linger longer in the corners of the room. I have also observed that the servants are more subdued, and there is a strange silence that has settled over the place. I have begun to keep a more careful watch on the comings and goings of the Count, and I have noticed that he does not sleep. He is always awake, and his eyes are always open, even when he is not looking at anything in particular. I have also noticed that he does not eat, and that he drinks only blood. I have seen him drink from a young woman, and I have seen the woman afterwards, and she was pale and weak, and she did not speak. events.title: Mina's Growing Anxieties and Lucy's Troubling Sleepwalking
detailed_summary: Mina uses her journal as an outlet for her anxiety, finding comfort in expressing her thoughts, particularly in shorthand.

She is troubled about both Lucy and Jonathan. Her concern for Jonathan, from whom she hadn't heard, was partially alleviated when Mr. Hawkins forwarded a very brief note from Castle Dracula, stating Jonathan was starting for home. However, the note's brevity and tone are unlike Jonathan and make Mina uneasy.
Lucy's old habit of sleepwalking has returned. Concerned, Mina and Mrs. Westenra have decided Mina should lock their bedroom door each night.
Mrs. Westenra harbors fears about sleepwalkers falling from heights, a worry intensified because Lucy's father had the same tendency.
Amidst these concerns, Lucy is happily planning her autumn wedding to Arthur Holmwood and arranging her future home. Arthur is expected in Whitby soon, though his father's ill health is a concern.
By July 27th, Mina's anxiety about Jonathan grows as no further word arrives. Lucy's sleepwalking has become more frequent, disturbing Mina's rest and making her nervous.

Arthur Holmwood is suddenly called away to Ring due to his father's grave illness, causing Lucy distress at the postponement of his visit. Despite this, Lucy's physical health seems to improve; she appears fuller and has a healthy pink complexion, having lost her previous anemic look.
On August 3rd, another week passes with no news from Jonathan, even to Mr. Hawkins. Mina re-examines Jonathan's last letter, finding it authentic in handwriting but uncharacteristic in content.
Lucy's sleepwalking has decreased, but she now exhibits a strange, focused demeanor, sometimes appearing to watch Mina even in her sleep and searching the room for the key to the locked door.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 26 July.—I am anxious, and it soothes me to express myself here; it is like whispering to one’s self and listening at the same time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She tries the door, and finding it locked, goes about the room searching for the key.

events.text_segment:
26 July.—I am anxious, and it soothes me to express myself here; it is like whispering to one’s self and listening at the same time. And there is also something about the shorthand symbols that makes it different from writing. I am unhappy about Lucy and about Jonathan. I had not heard from Jonathan for some time, and was very concerned; but yesterday dear Mr. Hawkins, who is always so kind, sent me a letter from him. I had written asking him if he had heard, and he said the enclosed had just been received. It is only a line dated from Castle Dracula, and says that he is just starting for home. That is not like Jonathan; I do not understand it, and it makes me uneasy. Then, too, Lucy, although she is so well, has lately taken to her old habit of walking in her sleep. Her mother has spoken to me about it, and we have decided that I am to lock the door of our room every night. Mrs. Westenra has got an idea that sleep-walkers always go out on roofs of houses and along the edges of cliffs and then get suddenly wakened and fall over with a despairing cry that echoes all over the place. Poor dear, she is naturally anxious about Lucy, and she tells me that her husband, Lucy’s father, had the same habit; that he would get up in the night and dress himself and go out, if he were not stopped. Lucy is to be married in the autumn, and she is already planning out her dresses and how her house is to be arranged. I sympathise with her, for I do the same, only Jonathan and I will start in life in a very simple way, and shall have to try to make both ends meet. Mr. Holmwood—he is the Hon. Arthur Holmwood, only son of Lord Godalming—is coming up here very shortly—as soon as he can leave town, for his father is not very well, and I think dear Lucy is counting the moments till he comes. She wants to take him up to the seat on the churchyard cliff and show him the beauty of Whitby. I daresay it is the waiting which disturbs her; she will be all right when he arrives.
27 July.—No news from Jonathan. I am getting quite uneasy about him, though why I should I do not know; but I do wish that he would write, if it were only a single line. Lucy walks more than ever, and each night I am awakened by her moving about the room. Fortunately, the weather is so hot that she cannot get cold; but still the anxiety and the perpetually being wakened is beginning to tell on me, and I am getting nervous and wakeful myself. Thank God, Lucy’s health keeps up. Mr. Holmwood has been suddenly called to Ring to see his father, who has been taken seriously ill. Lucy frets at the postponement of seeing him, but it does not touch her looks; she is a trifle stouter, and her cheeks are a lovely rose-pink. She has lost that anæmic look which she had. I pray it will all last.
3 August.—Another week gone, and no news from Jonathan, not even to Mr. Hawkins, from whom I have heard. Oh, I do hope he is not ill. He surely would have written. I look at that last letter of his, but somehow it does not satisfy me. It does not read like him, and yet it is his writing. There is no mistake of that. Lucy has not walked much in her sleep the last week, but there is an odd concentration about her which I do not understand; even in her sleep she seems to be watching me. She tries the door, and finding it locked, goes about the room searching for the key.

events.title: The Approaching Storm and Mr. Swales's Somber Premonition
detailed_summary: After three more days with no news from Jonathan, Mina's suspense becomes unbearable.
Local fishermen predict an impending storm, and the weather turns gray and ominous, mirroring Mina's mood. She describes the somber, monochrome landscape.
Mr. Swales approaches Mina, his demeanor notably changed and gentle.
He apologizes for his past harsh and morbid talk about death and the deceased, explaining that it was his way of coping with his own fear of mortality and not his true sentiment.
He assures Mina he is not afraid of dying but naturally prefers to live if possible, acknowledging that at nearly one hundred years old, his time is near.
Suddenly, his mood shifts; he cries out that he senses death in the wind and the atmosphere of the brewing storm, describing it as a palpable presence that he can feel, see, taste, and smell.
He raises his arms devoutly, prays, then shakes Mina's hand, blesses her, says goodbye, and hobbles away, leaving Mina deeply affected and unsettled by his words and manner.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 6 August.—Another three days, and no news.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It all touched me, and upset me very much.

events.text_segment:
6 August.—Another three days, and no news. This suspense is getting dreadful. If I only knew where to write to or where to go to, I should feel easier; but no one has heard a word of Jonathan since that last letter. I must only pray to God for patience. Lucy is more excitable than ever, but is otherwise well. Last night was very threatening, and the fishermen say that we are in for a storm. I must try to watch it and learn the weather signs. To-day is a grey day, and the sun as I write is hidden in thick clouds, high over Kettleness. Everything is grey—except the green grass, which seems like emerald amongst it; grey earthy rock; grey clouds, tinged with the sunburst at the far edge, hang over the grey sea, into which the sand-points stretch like grey fingers. The sea is tumbling in over the shallows and the sandy flats with a roar, muffled in the sea-mists drifting inland. The horizon is lost in a grey mist. All is vastness; the clouds are piled up like giant rocks, and there is a “brool” over the sea that sounds like some presage of doom. Dark figures are on the beach here and there, sometimes half shrouded in the mist, and seem “men like trees walking.” The fishing-boats are racing for home, and rise and dip in the ground swell as they sweep into the harbour, bending to the scuppers. Here comes old Mr. Swales. He is making straight for me, and I can see, by the way he lifts his hat, that he wants to talk....
I have been quite touched by the change in the poor old man. When he sat down beside me, he said in a very gentle way:—
“I want to say something to you, miss.” I could see he was not at ease, so I took his poor old wrinkled hand in mine and asked him to speak fully; so he said, leaving his hand in mine:—
“I’m afraid, my deary, that I must have shocked you by all the wicked things I’ve been sayin’ about the dead, and such like, for weeks past; but I didn’t mean them, and I want ye to remember that when I’m gone. We aud folks that be daffled, and with one foot abaft the krok-hooal, don’t altogether like to think of it, and we don’t want to feel scart of it; an’ that’s why I’ve took to makin’ light of it, so that I’d cheer up my own heart a bit. But, Lord love ye, miss, I ain’t afraid of dyin’, not a bit; only I don’t want to die if I can help it. My time must be nigh at hand now, for I be aud, and a hundred years is too much for any man to expect; and I’m so nigh it that the Aud Man is already whettin’ his scythe. Ye see, I can’t get out o’ the habit of caffin’ about it all at once; the chafts will wag as they be used to. Some day soon the Angel of Death will sound his trumpet for me. But don’t ye dooal an’ greet, my deary!”—for he saw that I was crying—“if he should come this very night I’d not refuse to answer his call. For life be, after all, only a waitin’ for somethin’ else than what we’re doin’; and death be all that we can rightly depend on. But I’m content, for it’s comin’ to me, my deary, and comin’ quick. It may be comin’ while we be lookin’ and wonderin’. Maybe it’s in that wind out over the sea that’s bringin’ with it loss and wreck, and sore distress, and sad hearts. Look! look!” he cried suddenly. “There’s something in that wind and in the hoast beyont that sounds, and looks, and tastes, and smells like death. It’s in the air; I feel it comin’. Lord, make me answer cheerful when my call comes!” He held up his arms devoutly, and raised his hat. His mouth moved as though he were praying. After a few minutes’ silence, he got up, shook hands with me, and blessed me, and said good-bye, and hobbled off. It all touched me, and upset me very much.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 6 August.—Another three days, and no news. I have tried to be patient, but the suspense is becoming unbearable. I have written and rewritten my letters, and have sent them off with every opportunity, but no answer comes back. The fishermen say that a storm is coming, and I can see in their faces that they believe it. The sky is gray and lowering, and the sea is restless, as if it, too, is waiting for something. The whole landscape is monochrome, as if the very colors have fled in fear. I feel as if I am living in a world that is waiting to be struck by lightning, and I am the lightning rod. Mr. Swales came to see me to-day, and I was struck by the change in him. He was gentle and kind, and his manner was full of a strange, quiet dignity. He said that he had been thinking of me, and that he wished to make amends for the harsh and morbid things he had said to me before. He said that it was his way of coping with his fear of death, and that it was not his true sentiment. He said that he was not afraid of dying, but that he preferred to live if possible, and that he was not yet ready to go. He said that he was nearly a hundred years old, and that his time was near. But then, suddenly, his manner changed again. He looked up at the sky, and his face was filled with a strange, terrible light. He said that he could feel death in the wind, and that it was coming. He said that he could see it, and taste it, and smell it. He raised his arms to the sky, and prayed, and then he took my hand and blessed me, and said goodbye. He hobbled away, and I was left alone, with a feeling of deep unease and a sense of something terrible that was coming.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_0.text: 6 August.—Another three days, and no news. I have tried to be patient, but the suspense is becoming unbearable. I have written and rewritten my letters, and have sent them off with every opportunity, but no answer comes back. The fishermen say that a storm is coming, and I can see in their faces that they believe it. The sky is gray and lowering, and the sea is restless, as if it, too, is waiting for something. The whole landscape is monochrome, as if the very colors have fled in fear. I feel as if I am living in a world that is waiting to be struck by lightning, and I am the lightning rod. Mr. Swales came to see me to-day, and I was struck by the change in him. He was gentle and kind, and his manner was full of a strange, quiet dignity. He said that he had been thinking of me, and that he wished to make amends for the harsh and morbid things he had said to me before. He said that it was his way of coping with his fear of death, and that it was not his true sentiment. He said that he was not afraid of dying, but that he preferred to live if possible, and that he was not yet ready to go. He said that he was nearly a hundred years old, and that his time was near. But then, suddenly, his manner changed again. He looked up at the sky, and his face was filled with a strange, terrible light. He said that he could feel death in the wind, and that it was coming. He said that he could see it, and taste it, and smell it. He raised his arms to the sky, and prayed, and then he took my hand and blessed me, and said goodbye. He hobbled away, and I was left alone, with a feeling of deep unease and a sense of something terrible that was coming.

I fear that something has happened to them. I have been going over the notes and letters again and again, trying to find some clue, some hint of what is happening. events.title: Sighting of a Mysterious Ship in the Brewing Storm
detailed_summary: Mina, feeling upset after her encounter with Mr. Swales, is relieved when a coastguard approaches her.
The coastguard, a familiar presence, stops to talk but is primarily focused on a peculiar ship visible at sea through his spy-glass.

He identifies the vessel as Russian but notes its highly unusual and erratic behavior, suggesting it seems unable to decide whether to head for open sea to weather the storm or attempt to enter the harbor.
He remarks on the ship's poor handling, as it appears unresponsive to its helm and shifts with every gust of wind.
The coastguard concludes by predicting that they will learn more about the strange ship's fate by the next day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was glad when the coastguard came along, with his spy-glass under his arm.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We’ll hear more of her before this time to-morrow.”

events.text_segment:
I was glad when the coastguard came along, with his spy-glass under his arm. He stopped to talk with me, as he always does, but all the time kept looking at a strange ship.
“I can’t make her out,” he said; “she’s a Russian, by the look of her; but she’s knocking about in the queerest way. She doesn’t know her mind a bit; she seems to see the storm coming, but can’t decide whether to run up north in the open, or to put in here. Look there again! She is steered mighty strangely, for she doesn’t mind the hand on the wheel; changes about with every puff of wind. We’ll hear more of her before this time to-morrow.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I was glad when the coastguard came along, with his spy-glass under his arm. He was a familiar figure, and I always felt a sense of comfort in his presence. He greeted me kindly and asked if I had seen anything unusual at sea. I told him of my encounter with Mr. Swales and how it had unsettled me. He listened with a grave expression, then took out his spy-glass and turned it toward the horizon. 'There's a ship out there,' he said, 'and it's acting like no ship I've ever seen.' He raised the glass to his eye and studied the vessel for a long moment. 'It's Russian, I'd say,' he continued, 'but it's not behaving like one. It's as if it can't make up its mind whether to go out to sea or try to get into the harbor. It's drifting with every gust, and it's not responding to its helm at all.' I watched as he lowered the glass and looked at me with a thoughtful expression. 'We'll know more by tomorrow,' he said. 'Something's not right with that ship, I can feel it in my bones.'

He was a rough, red-faced man, with a voice like a foghorn, and he looked at me with a mixture of suspicion and curiosity. I told him I was a passenger from a wrecked ship, and he seemed to believe me, though he asked a lot of questions. He said he would take me to the nearest village and get me some food and shelter. I was grateful, for I was tired and hungry, and the night was growing colder. As we walked along the shore, I could not help but feel that I was being watched, though I saw no one in the darkness.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER VII CUTTING FROM “THE DAILYGRAPH,” 8 AUGUST

events.title: Ominous Calm and Gathering Signs Before a Great Storm
characters: Officers of the foreign schooner (by implication)
detailed_summary: The narrative, a news report from Whitby, begins by describing a period of unusually sultry August weather that had been fine until the Saturday evening preceding a major storm.
Holiday-makers had planned various excursions, and coastal steamers were active.

On the day of the storm, the weather remained fine until the afternoon, when gossips on the East Cliff noticed 'mares'-tails' clouds, an ominous sign, to the north-west, while the wind was still a light south-westerly breeze.
The coastguard reported this, and an old, experienced fisherman emphatically predicted an imminent, sudden storm.
The sunset was extraordinarily beautiful, with vibrant clouds and striking silhouettes, drawing many spectators and inspiring artists.
Several boat captains prudently decided to keep their vessels harbored.
As evening progressed, the wind died completely, leading to a dead calm, oppressive sultry heat, and an intense atmosphere often preceding thunderstorms.
Few lights were visible at sea, with most vessels keeping a safe distance from shore, except for a foreign schooner with all sails set, heading west.
The schooner's apparent recklessness was widely commented upon, and attempts to signal it to reduce sail were made before nightfall.
The ship was last seen rolling idly on the swell, its sails flapping.
Shortly before ten o'clock, the air became oppressively still, and the silence was profound, making distant sounds like a sheep's bleating or a dog's bark clearly audible.
A little after midnight, a strange, faint, hollow booming sound was heard from the sea and high above.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ONE of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been experienced here, with results both strange and unique.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A little after midnight came a strange sound from over the sea, and high overhead the air began to carry a strange, faint, hollow booming.

events.text_segment:
ONE of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been experienced here, with results both strange and unique. The weather had been somewhat sultry, but not to any degree uncommon in the month of August. Saturday evening was as fine as was ever known, and the great body of holiday-makers laid out yesterday for visits to Mulgrave Woods, Robin Hood’s Bay, Rig Mill, Runswick, Staithes, and the various trips in the neighbourhood of Whitby. The steamers Emma and Scarborough made trips up and down the coast, and there was an unusual amount of “tripping” both to and from Whitby. The day was unusually fine till the afternoon, when some of the gossips who frequent the East Cliff churchyard, and from that commanding eminence watch the wide sweep of sea visible to the north and east, called attention to a sudden show of “mares’-tails” high in the sky to the north-west. The wind was then blowing from the south-west in the mild degree which in barometrical language is ranked “No. 2: light breeze.” The coastguard on duty at once made report, and one old fisherman, who for more than half a century has kept watch on weather signs from the East Cliff, foretold in an emphatic manner the coming of a sudden storm. The approach of sunset was so very beautiful, so grand in its masses of splendidly-coloured clouds, that there was quite an assemblage on the walk along the cliff in the old churchyard to enjoy the beauty. Before the sun dipped below the black mass of Kettleness, standing boldly athwart the western sky, its downward way was marked by myriad clouds of every sunset-colour—flame, purple, pink, green, violet, and all the tints of gold; with here and there masses not large, but of seemingly absolute blackness, in all sorts of shapes, as well outlined as colossal silhouettes. The experience was not lost on the painters, and doubtless some of the sketches of the “Prelude to the Great Storm” will grace the R. A. and R. I. walls in May next. More than one captain made up his mind then and there that his “cobble” or his “mule,” as they term the different classes of boats, would remain in the harbour till the storm had passed. The wind fell away entirely during the evening, and at midnight there was a dead calm, a sultry heat, and that prevailing intensity which, on the approach of thunder, affects persons of a sensitive nature. There were but few lights in sight at sea, for even the coasting steamers, which usually “hug” the shore so closely, kept well to seaward, and but few fishing-boats were in sight. The only sail noticeable was a foreign schooner with all sails set, which was seemingly going westwards. The foolhardiness or ignorance of her officers was a prolific theme for comment whilst she remained in sight, and efforts were made to signal her to reduce sail in face of her danger. Before the night shut down she was seen with sails idly flapping as she gently rolled on the undulating swell of the sea,
“As idle as a painted ship upon a painted ocean.”
Shortly before ten o’clock the stillness of the air grew quite oppressive, and the silence was so marked that the bleating of a sheep inland or the barking of a dog in the town was distinctly heard, and the band on the pier, with its lively French air, was like a discord in the great harmony of nature’s silence. A little after midnight came a strange sound from over the sea, and high overhead the air began to carry a strange, faint, hollow booming.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: ONE of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been experienced here, with results both strange and unique. The weather, which had been unusually sultry for the month of August, was fine and bright until Saturday evening, when the first signs of the coming tempest were observed. The holiday-makers had arranged for a number of excursions, and the coastal steamers were in full activity. On the day of the storm, the morning and early afternoon passed in perfect calm and sunshine. But about three o'clock, the gossips on the East Cliff began to talk of the 'mares'-tails' clouds that were drifting in from the north-west, and the old fisherman, who had been sitting on the pier with his pipe in his mouth, suddenly rose to his feet and said, 'We'll have a belting wind before midnight.' The coastguard, who had been watching the sky with a professional eye, nodded his head and said that he thought the old man was right. The sunset was of a beauty that is rarely seen, and the sky was ablaze with crimson and gold. The clouds, as they caught the light, looked like masses of burning metal, and the silhouettes of the houses and the church spire were cut in sharp and startling contrast against the glowing background. The painters, who had been working on the cliffs, left their easels and stood gazing at the spectacle, and the holiday-makers, who had been strolling along the promenade, gathered in little groups and looked up in wonder. The boatmen, who had been out all day, came in early, and several of the captains, who had been hesitating whether to go out again, decided to keep their vessels in the harbour. As the evening wore on, the wind died away altogether, and the sea became as smooth as glass. The heat was oppressive, and the air was heavy with the scent of the sea and the salt marshes. There was a stillness that was almost painful, and the silence was broken only by the occasional cry of a gull or the distant bleating of a sheep. Few lights were visible at sea, and it seemed as if the whole fleet had kept to the shelter of the bay. But one vessel, a foreign schooner, was seen to be making her way out to the west, with all her sails set and her yards square. The sight of her, with the wind behind her and the sea smooth as a sheet of polished steel, was a strange and startling one. The people on the pier, who had been watching her, began to talk of her recklessness, and some of the more experienced sailors said that she was running a great risk. The coastguard, who had been keeping a sharp look-out, sent a signal to her, but she paid no heed, and continued on her course. The last time she was seen, she was rolling idly on the swell, with her sails flapping in the light breeze. As the night advanced, the stillness became more and more oppressive, and the air was filled with a strange and unearthly silence. The stars, which had been shining brightly in the early evening, were now hidden behind a veil of mist, and the sea, which had been so smooth and calm, began to show signs of the coming storm. A little after midnight, a strange and hollow booming sound was heard from the sea, and the echoes of it seemed to come from high above, as if the very heavens were being shaken. The people in the town, who had been lying in bed and listening to the silence, were suddenly startled by the sound, and many of them rose and looked out of their windows. The wind, which had been so still, now began to rise, and the first gusts of the storm were felt to be coming from the north-west. The storm, which had been so long in coming, was now upon them, and the night was to be one of terror and destruction.
