segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It must have been my weakness that made me hesitate to tell it to my friend, but I felt it all the more, like unshed tears.

events.text_segment:
11 September.—This afternoon I went over to Hillingham. Found Van Helsing in excellent spirits, and Lucy much better. Shortly after I had arrived, a big parcel from abroad came for the Professor. He opened it with much impressment—assumed, of course—and showed a great bundle of white flowers.
“These are for you, Miss Lucy,” he said.
“For me? Oh, Dr. Van Helsing!”
“Yes, my dear, but not for you to play with. These are medicines.” Here Lucy made a wry face. “Nay, but they are not to take in a decoction or in nauseous form, so you need not snub that so charming nose, or I shall point out to my friend Arthur what woes he may have to endure in seeing so much beauty that he so loves so much distort. Aha, my pretty miss, that bring the so nice nose all straight again. This is medicinal, but you do not know how. I put him in your window, I make pretty wreath, and hang him round your neck, so that you sleep well. Oh yes! they, like the lotus flower, make your trouble forgotten. It smell so like the waters of Lethe, and of that fountain of youth that the Conquistadores sought for in the Floridas, and find him all too late.”
Whilst he was speaking, Lucy had been examining the flowers and smelling them. Now she threw them down, saying, with half-laughter, and half-disgust:—
“Oh, Professor, I believe you are only putting up a joke on me. Why, these flowers are only common garlic.”
To my surprise, Van Helsing rose up and said with all his sternness, his iron jaw set and his bushy eyebrows meeting:—
“No trifling with me! I never jest! There is grim purpose in all I do; and I warn you that you do not thwart me. Take care, for the sake of others if not for your own.” Then seeing poor Lucy scared, as she might well be, he went on more gently: “Oh, little miss, my dear, do not fear me. I only do for your good; but there is much virtue to you in those so common flowers. See, I place them myself in your room. I make myself the wreath that you are to wear. But hush! no telling to others that make so inquisitive questions. We must obey, and silence is a part of obedience; and obedience is to bring you strong and well into loving arms that wait for you. Now sit still awhile. Come with me, friend John, and you shall help me deck the room with my garlic, which is all the way from Haarlem, where my friend Vanderpool raise herb in his glass-houses all the year. I had to telegraph yesterday, or they would not have been here.”
We went into the room, taking the flowers with us. The Professor’s actions were certainly odd and not to be found in any pharmacopœia that I ever heard of. First he fastened up the windows and latched them securely; next, taking a handful of the flowers, he rubbed them all over the sashes, as though to ensure that every whiff of air that might get in would be laden with the garlic smell. Then with the wisp he rubbed all over the jamb of the door, above, below, and at each side, and round the fireplace in the same way. It all seemed grotesque to me, and presently I said:—
“Well, Professor, I know you always have a reason for what you do, but this certainly puzzles me. It is well we have no sceptic here, or he would say that you were working some spell to keep out an evil spirit.”
“Perhaps I am!” he answered quietly as he began to make the wreath which Lucy was to wear round her neck.
We then waited whilst Lucy made her toilet for the night, and when she was in bed he came and himself fixed the wreath of garlic round her neck. The last words he said to her were:—
“Take care you do not disturb it; and even if the room feel close, do not to-night open the window or the door.”
“I promise,” said Lucy, “and thank you both a thousand times for all your kindness to me! Oh, what have I done to be blessed with such friends?”
As we left the house in my fly, which was waiting, Van Helsing said:—
“To-night I can sleep in peace, and sleep I want—two nights of travel, much reading in the day between, and much anxiety on the day to follow, and a night to sit up, without to wink. To-morrow in the morning early you call for me, and we come together to see our pretty miss, so much more strong for my ‘spell’ which I have work. Ho! ho!”
He seemed so confident that I, remembering my own confidence two nights before and with the baneful result, felt awe and vague terror. It must have been my weakness that made me hesitate to tell it to my friend, but I felt it all the more, like unshed tears.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 11 September.—This afternoon I went over to Hillingham. I found Van Helsing in excellent spirits, and Lucy, to my great delight, was looking much better. She was sitting by the window, and the light and the fresh air seemed to do her good. She was bright and cheerful, and I could not help feeling that the worst was over. Van Helsing was full of his plans, and he was in a most genial mood. He was talking of the coming of the spring, and of the time when Lucy would be out again, and walking in the woods, and laughing with the birds and the flowers. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: 11 September.—This afternoon I went over to Hillingham. I had been invited by Mr. Quincey Morris, who is a very pleasant and hospitable gentleman. He is an American, and I must say that I find his manner of living and his views of life very interesting. He is a man of great strength and courage, and I am told that he is one of the best shots in the country. He is also a great sportsman, and I have heard that he has killed many big game in the United States. events.title: Lucy's Garlic-Induced Comfort and Mrs. Westenra's Fatal Intervention
detailed_summary: Lucy expresses gratitude for her caregivers, especially Dr. Van Helsing, whose prescribed flowers (garlic) bring her comfort and alleviate her fear of sleep.
She notes her newfound appreciation for the smell of garlic, likening her state to Ophelia, and anticipates a peaceful night.
Dr. Seward recounts meeting Van Helsing, both punctual as always.
They arrive at Hillingham to a cheerful Mrs. Westenra, who reports Lucy is better and still asleep.

Mrs. Westenra proudly explains she contributed to Lucy's improvement by removing the "horrible, strong-smelling flowers" from Lucy's room and around her neck, and opening a window for fresh air, believing the odor was too much for Lucy.
Dr. Seward observes Van Helsing's face turn "ashen grey" upon hearing this, though Van Helsing maintains composure in Mrs. Westenra's presence.
Once Mrs. Westenra departs, Van Helsing, deeply distressed, pulls Seward into another room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 12 September.—How good they all are to me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But the instant she had disappeared he pulled me, suddenly and forcibly, into the dining-room and closed the door.

events.text_segment:
12 September.—How good they all are to me. I quite love that dear Dr. Van Helsing. I wonder why he was so anxious about these flowers. He positively frightened me, he was so fierce. And yet he must have been right, for I feel comfort from them already. Somehow, I do not dread being alone to-night, and I can go to sleep without fear. I shall not mind any flapping outside the window. Oh, the terrible struggle that I have had against sleep so often of late; the pain of the sleeplessness, or the pain of the fear of sleep, with such unknown horrors as it has for me! How blessed are some people, whose lives have no fears, no dreads; to whom sleep is a blessing that comes nightly, and brings nothing but sweet dreams. Well, here I am to-night, hoping for sleep, and lying like Ophelia in the play, with “virgin crants and maiden strewments.” I never liked garlic before, but to-night it is delightful! There is peace in its smell; I feel sleep coming already. Good-night, everybody.
Dr. Seward’s Diary.
13 September.—Called at the Berkeley and found Van Helsing, as usual, up to time. The carriage ordered from the hotel was waiting. The Professor took his bag, which he always brings with him now.
Let all be put down exactly. Van Helsing and I arrived at Hillingham at eight o’clock. It was a lovely morning; the bright sunshine and all the fresh feeling of early autumn seemed like the completion of nature’s annual work. The leaves were turning to all kinds of beautiful colours, but had not yet begun to drop from the trees. When we entered we met Mrs. Westenra coming out of the morning room. She is always an early riser. She greeted us warmly and said:—
“You will be glad to know that Lucy is better. The dear child is still asleep. I looked into her room and saw her, but did not go in, lest I should disturb her.” The Professor smiled, and looked quite jubilant. He rubbed his hands together, and said:—
“Aha! I thought I had diagnosed the case. My treatment is working,” to which she answered:—
“You must not take all the credit to yourself, doctor. Lucy’s state this morning is due in part to me.”
“How you do mean, ma’am?” asked the Professor.
“Well, I was anxious about the dear child in the night, and went into her room. She was sleeping soundly—so soundly that even my coming did not wake her. But the room was awfully stuffy. There were a lot of those horrible, strong-smelling flowers about everywhere, and she had actually a bunch of them round her neck. I feared that the heavy odour would be too much for the dear child in her weak state, so I took them all away and opened a bit of the window to let in a little fresh air. You will be pleased with her, I am sure.”
She moved off into her boudoir, where she usually breakfasted early. As she had spoken, I watched the Professor’s face, and saw it turn ashen grey. He had been able to retain his self-command whilst the poor lady was present, for he knew her state and how mischievous a shock would be; he actually smiled on her as he held open the door for her to pass into her room. But the instant she had disappeared he pulled me, suddenly and forcibly, into the dining-room and closed the door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 12 September.—How good they all are to me. I have been so weak and ill, and yet they never seem to tire of me. I think Dr. Van Helsing is the best of them all. He is so kind and gentle, and his flowers—oh, how they comfort me! I used to think the smell of garlic was so strong and unpleasant, but now I find it sweet and soothing. It is like the scent of peace, and I feel so much better when I sleep with them near me. I have been reading about Ophelia, and I think I must be like her in some ways—soothed by flowers and the thought of death. I do not fear sleep now, and I hope to have a peaceful night. Dr. Seward came in just now, and he told me that he had met Dr. Van Helsing, and that they were both as punctual as ever. They are to come to Hillingham in the morning, and I am to be ready for them. Mrs. Westenra is so cheerful and full of hope. She says that I am getting better, and that I am still asleep when they come. She told me that she had done something to help me, and that she had taken away the 'horrible, strong-smelling flowers' from my room and from my neck, and had opened a window for fresh air. She said that the smell was too much for me, and that I needed something lighter and more delicate. When she said this, I saw Dr. Seward's face change, and I saw Dr. Van Helsing's face turn 'ashen grey.' But he said nothing, and only smiled kindly at Mrs. Westenra. When she went out, he took Dr. Seward into another room, and I heard them speaking in low voices. I could not hear what they said, but I could tell that it was something very serious. I hope that nothing is wrong, and that they will soon be able to help me. I feel so much better now, and I think that I shall sleep well tonight.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: 12 September.—How good they all are to me. I have been so ill, and they have been so kind. I feel as if I were in a dream. I have been lying in bed for so long, and the days have passed like a mist. I do not know how it is, but I feel as if I were not quite myself. I have had strange dreams, and sometimes I wake up with a feeling of terror, as if something were watching me. But when I open my eyes, all is quiet and peaceful. I have been so weak, and the doctors say that I must not get up yet. But I do not want to lie here any longer. I want to be up and about, to see the world again. I want to feel the sun on my face and the wind in my hair. I want to be free. But I must be patient. I must trust in them. They are so good to me. They bring me flowers and books, and they talk to me as if I were a child. I do not mind. I like it. I like to feel that I am loved. I have been so lonely. I have been so afraid. events.title: Van Helsing's Despair and Emergency Transfusion for Lucy
detailed_summary: Van Helsing experiences a profound emotional breakdown, expressing despair over Mrs. Westenra's unknowing actions that have endangered Lucy's body and soul.
He laments their inability to warn Mrs. Westenra without risking her own life.
Quickly regaining his resolve, Van Helsing insists they must act immediately to combat the evil forces at play.
In Lucy's room, Van Helsing finds her in the expected dire state, with the same "awful, waxen pallor."
He prepares for another blood transfusion, this time instructing Dr. Seward to be the donor as Seward is already weakened from previous contributions.
The transfusion is performed, and Lucy's color and breathing improve.
Van Helsing later firmly instructs Mrs. Westenra not to remove anything from Lucy's room again, explaining the flowers are medicinal.
He decides to personally oversee Lucy's care for the next few nights.
Lucy eventually awakens, appearing fresh and not significantly worse for her ordeal.
Dr. Seward reflects on the bizarre nature of these events, questioning his own sanity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then, for the first time in my life, I saw Van Helsing break down.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I am beginning to wonder if my long habit of life amongst the insane is beginning to tell upon my own brain.

events.text_segment:
Then, for the first time in my life, I saw Van Helsing break down. He raised his hands over his head in a sort of mute despair, and then beat his palms together in a helpless way; finally he sat down on a chair, and putting his hands before his face, began to sob, with loud, dry sobs that seemed to come from the very racking of his heart. Then he raised his arms again, as though appealing to the whole universe. “God! God! God!” he said. “What have we done, what has this poor thing done, that we are so sore beset? Is there fate amongst us still, sent down from the pagan world of old, that such things must be, and in such way? This poor mother, all unknowing, and all for the best as she think, does such thing as lose her daughter body and soul; and we must not tell her, we must not even warn her, or she die, and then both die. Oh, how we are beset! How are all the powers of the devils against us!” Suddenly he jumped to his feet. “Come,” he said, “come, we must see and act. Devils or no devils, or all the devils at once, it matters not; we fight him all the same.” He went to the hall-door for his bag; and together we went up to Lucy’s room.
Once again I drew up the blind, whilst Van Helsing went towards the bed. This time he did not start as he looked on the poor face with the same awful, waxen pallor as before. He wore a look of stern sadness and infinite pity.
“As I expected,” he murmured, with that hissing inspiration of his which meant so much. Without a word he went and locked the door, and then began to set out on the little table the instruments for yet another operation of transfusion of blood. I had long ago recognised the necessity, and begun to take off my coat, but he stopped me with a warning hand. “No!” he said. “To-day you must operate. I shall provide. You are weakened already.” As he spoke he took off his coat and rolled up his shirt-sleeve.
Again the operation; again the narcotic; again some return of colour to the ashy cheeks, and the regular breathing of healthy sleep. This time I watched whilst Van Helsing recruited himself and rested.
Presently he took an opportunity of telling Mrs. Westenra that she must not remove anything from Lucy’s room without consulting him; that the flowers were of medicinal value, and that the breathing of their odour was a part of the system of cure. Then he took over the care of the case himself, saying that he would watch this night and the next and would send me word when to come.
After another hour Lucy waked from her sleep, fresh and bright and seemingly not much the worse for her terrible ordeal.
What does it all mean? I am beginning to wonder if my long habit of life amongst the insane is beginning to tell upon my own brain.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Then, for the first time in my life, I saw Van Helsing break down. He threw himself into a chair, his face in his hands, and his shoulders shook with the violence of his grief. I had never seen the great doctor so overcome, and I felt a chill of fear at the sight. 'God have mercy on us!' he cried, his voice breaking. 'It is not only the body of the child that is in peril, but her soul. And it is the mother who has unknowingly brought this upon her. Oh, what a cruel fate, that the one who should protect should be the one who endangers!' He looked up at me, his eyes red and burning. 'We cannot tell the mother, John. She is too weak, too fragile. If we tell her, she may go mad, or worse, she may take her own life. And then where would we be? We must act, and we must act now, before it is too late.' He rose suddenly, as if the thought of inaction was unbearable. 'Come, we must go to Lucy. She is waiting for us.' In Lucy's room, the scene was as I had feared. She lay as pale as death, her breath shallow and laboured. The awful, waxen pallor of her face was the same as before, and I felt a cold dread creep over me. Van Helsing knelt beside the bed, his hand on Lucy's forehead. 'She is still with us,' he said, his voice low and steady. 'But we must not lose her now.' He turned to me. 'You must give your blood again, John. You are the only one left who can.' I hesitated, for I was already weakened from my previous donation, but I saw the look in his eyes and I knew there was no time for argument. The transfusion was performed, and slowly, Lucy's colour returned. Her breathing grew stronger, and for the first time in days, there was a flicker of life in her eyes. Van Helsing watched her closely, his face set in grim determination. 'She is not out of danger yet,' he said. 'But she is on the road to recovery.' Later that evening, Van Helsing found Mrs. Westenra in Lucy's room, trying to remove the flowers from the window. 'No, no, my dear lady,' he said firmly, taking the flowers from her hands. 'These are not for beauty, but for healing. They are part of the cure.' He looked at her with a mixture of pity and resolve. 'You must not interfere again. I will stay with Lucy myself for the next few nights. I will not leave her side.' Mrs. Westenra looked at him, her eyes filled with confusion and fear, but she said nothing. That night, as I lay in bed, I could not sleep. The events of the day played over and over in my mind, and I could not shake the feeling that I was losing my grip on reality. What was happening to Lucy? What was happening to me? I had always prided myself on my rational mind, on my scientific training, but now I was forced to confront the possibility that there were things in this world that defied explanation. And yet, I could not deny what I had seen. Lucy was alive, and she was improving. And Van Helsing, for all his strange methods, was right. We had to keep going. We had to find a way to save her.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Then, for the first time in my life, I saw Van Helsing break down. It was not a dramatic collapse, nor was it a sudden outburst of emotion. Rather, it was a quiet, almost imperceptible moment of vulnerability that revealed the weight he had carried for so long. We had just returned from a harrowing journey to the Carpathian Mountains, where we had uncovered the truth of Dracula’s existence and the horror he had unleashed upon the world. The Count was dead, his body burned and buried in the earth, but the toll of the battle had left its mark on us all. Van Helsing, who had been our leader, our guide, and our moral compass, now sat in silence by the fire, his hands trembling slightly as he stared into the flames. I had always known him to be a man of great strength, both in body and in spirit. He had faced the undead with a calm resolve, had spoken in languages I did not understand, and had wielded knowledge of the old world with a precision that bordered on the supernatural. But now, he was just a man. I could see the lines of exhaustion etched into his face, the shadows beneath his eyes, and the way his shoulders sagged as if the very weight of the world had settled upon them. He did not cry, but there was a stillness in him, a kind of sorrow that could not be spoken. I did not know what to say. I had seen death, I had seen the Count’s castle, I had seen the terror that had gripped London, but I had never seen Van Helsing like this. He was not defeated, but he was weary. He was not broken, but he was shaken. And in that moment, I realized that even the strongest among us are not immune to the burden of what we have done. Van Helsing looked up at me, his eyes filled with a quiet understanding. He did not need to speak. I knew that he was thinking of Lucy, of Mina, of the lives that had been lost and the ones that had been saved. He had fought not for glory, not for power, but for the simple, human desire to protect those he loved. And now, with the battle over, he was left to face the silence that followed. I sat beside him, not knowing if I could offer comfort, but knowing that I would not leave him alone. For the first time, I saw Van Helsing not as a hero, but as a man who had done what he had to do, and who now had to live with the cost.

events.title: Lucy's Period of Recovery and Renewed Well-being
detailed_summary: Lucy records four days of peaceful recovery, feeling significantly stronger.
She describes her recent ordeal as a long nightmare from which she has awakened.
The frightening noises and sensations that previously plagued her have ceased since Dr. Van Helsing's close attendance.
She has developed a fondness for the garlic, which arrives daily.
Dr. Van Helsing is scheduled to leave for a day in Amsterdam, but Lucy feels well enough to be left alone without supervision.
She expresses gratitude for her mother, Arthur, and her friends.
She anticipates not noticing Van Helsing's absence much, as he often slept in his chair during his watch.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 17 September.—Four days and nights of peace.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I found him asleep twice when I awoke; but I did not fear to go to sleep again, although the boughs or bats or something napped almost angrily against the window-panes.

events.text_segment: 17 September.—Four days and nights of peace. I am getting so strong again that I hardly know myself. It is as if I had passed through some long nightmare, and had just awakened to see the beautiful sunshine and feel the fresh air of the morning around me. I have a dim half-remembrance of long, anxious times of waiting and fearing; darkness in which there was not even the pain of hope to make present distress more poignant: and then long spells of oblivion, and the rising back to life as a diver coming up through a great press of water. Since, however, Dr. Van Helsing has been with me, all this bad dreaming seems to have passed away; the noises that used to frighten me out of my wits—the flapping against the windows, the distant voices which seemed so close to me, the harsh sounds that came from I know not where and commanded me to do I know not what—have all ceased. I go to bed now without any fear of sleep. I do not even try to keep awake. I have grown quite fond of the garlic, and a boxful arrives for me every day from Haarlem. To-night Dr. Van Helsing is going away, as he has to be for a day in Amsterdam. But I need not be watched; I am well enough to be left alone. Thank God for mother’s sake, and dear Arthur’s, and for all our friends who have been so kind! I shall not even feel the change, for last night Dr. Van Helsing slept in his chair a lot of the time. I found him asleep twice when I awoke; but I did not fear to go to sleep again, although the boughs or bats or something napped almost angrily against the window-panes.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 17 September.—Four days and nights of peace. I feel so much stronger, and I can scarcely believe that I am the same person who lay in such a terrible state a short time ago. It seems as if I have awakened from a long and dreadful nightmare. The strange noises and sensations that used to trouble me have quite ceased since Dr. Van Helsing has been so constantly with me. I have come to like the garlic, which he sends every day, and I wear it without fear or hesitation. Dr. Van Helsing is going to be away for a day in Amsterdam, but I feel quite able to be left alone, and I shall not miss him much, for I know he has often slept in his chair while watching over me. I am so grateful to my mother, to Arthur, and to all my friends, and I feel that I am getting back to my old self again.

events.title: The Escaped Wolf 'Bersicker' and the Zookeeper's Ominous Encounter
detailed_summary: A newspaper reporter interviews Thomas Bilder, a zookeeper, about an escaped wolf named Bersicker.
Bilder, after some initial reluctance and playful banter, agrees to discuss the matter.
He describes Bersicker as a normally calm wolf, making his escape surprising.
Bilder recounts an incident prior to the escape: a tall, thin man with a hooked nose, pointed beard, red eyes, and sharp teeth was near the wolf enclosure.
The wolves, particularly Bersicker, became agitated by this man's presence.
The mysterious man, with an insolent smile, denied upsetting the wolves and then, surprisingly, joined Bilder in stroking Bersicker's ears, claiming familiarity with such animals.
The man, dressed in white kid gloves, politely departed after stating he wasn't in the animal trade but had "made pets of several."
Bersicker watched the man leave and then remained subdued in a corner for the rest of the evening.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: THE ESCAPED WOLF.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Old Bersicker kep’ a-lookin’ arter ’im till ’e was out of sight, and then went and lay down in a corner and wouldn’t come hout the ’ole hevening.

events.text_segment:
THE ESCAPED WOLF.
PERILOUS ADVENTURE OF OUR INTERVIEWER.
Interview with the Keeper in the Zoölogical Gardens.
After many inquiries and almost as many refusals, and perpetually using the words “Pall Mall Gazette” as a sort of talisman, I managed to find the keeper of the section of the Zoölogical Gardens in which the wolf department is included. Thomas Bilder lives in one of the cottages in the enclosure behind the elephant-house, and was just sitting down to his tea when I found him. Thomas and his wife are hospitable folk, elderly, and without children, and if the specimen I enjoyed of their hospitality be of the average kind, their lives must be pretty comfortable. The keeper would not enter on what he called “business” until the supper was over, and we were all satisfied. Then when the table was cleared, and he had lit his pipe, he said:—
“Now, sir, you can go on and arsk me what you want. You’ll excoose me refoosin’ to talk of perfeshunal subjects afore meals. I gives the wolves and the jackals and the hyenas in all our section their tea afore I begins to arsk them questions.”
“How do you mean, ask them questions?” I queried, wishful to get him into a talkative humour.
“’Ittin’ of them over the ’ead with a pole is one way; scratchin’ of their hears is another, when gents as is flush wants a bit of a show-orf to their gals. I don’t so much mind the fust—the ’ittin’ with a pole afore I chucks in their dinner; but I waits till they’ve ’ad their sherry and kawffee, so to speak, afore I tries on with the ear-scratchin’. Mind you,” he added philosophically, “there’s a deal of the same nature in us as in them theer animiles. Here’s you a-comin’ and arskin’ of me questions about my business, and I that grumpy-like that only for your bloomin’ ’arf-quid I’d ’a’ seen you blowed fust ’fore I’d answer. Not even when you arsked me sarcastic-like if I’d like you to arsk the Superintendent if you might arsk me questions. Without offence did I tell yer to go to ’ell?”
“You did.”
“An’ when you said you’d report me for usin’ of obscene language that was ’ittin’ me over the ’ead; but the ’arf-quid made that all right. I weren’t a-goin’ to fight, so I waited for the food, and did with my ’owl as the wolves, and lions, and tigers does. But, Lor’ love yer ’art, now that the old ’ooman has stuck a chunk of her tea-cake in me, an’ rinsed me out with her bloomin’ old teapot, and I’ve lit hup, you may scratch my ears for all you’re worth, and won’t git even a growl out of me. Drive along with your questions. I know what yer a-comin’ at, that ’ere escaped wolf.”
“Exactly. I want you to give me your view of it. Just tell me how it happened; and when I know the facts I’ll get you to say what you consider was the cause of it, and how you think the whole affair will end.”
“All right, guv’nor. This ’ere is about the ’ole story. That ’ere wolf what we called Bersicker was one of three grey ones that came from Norway to Jamrach’s, which we bought off him four years ago. He was a nice well-behaved wolf, that never gave no trouble to talk of. I’m more surprised at ’im for wantin’ to get out nor any other animile in the place. But, there, you can’t trust wolves no more nor women.”
“Don’t you mind him, sir!” broke in Mrs. Tom, with a cheery laugh. “’E’s got mindin’ the animiles so long that blest if he ain’t like a old wolf ’isself! But there ain’t no ’arm in ’im.”
“Well, sir, it was about two hours after feedin’ yesterday when I first hear my disturbance. I was makin’ up a litter in the monkey-house for a young puma which is ill; but when I heard the yelpin’ and ’owlin’ I kem away straight. There was Bersicker a-tearin’ like a mad thing at the bars as if he wanted to get out. There wasn’t much people about that day, and close at hand was only one man, a tall, thin chap, with a ’ook nose and a pointed beard, with a few white hairs runnin’ through it. He had a ’ard, cold look and red eyes, and I took a sort of mislike to him, for it seemed as if it was ’im as they was hirritated at. He ’ad white kid gloves on ’is ’ands, and he pointed out the animiles to me and says: ‘Keeper, these wolves seem upset at something.’
“‘Maybe it’s you,’ says I, for I did not like the airs as he give ’isself. He didn’t git angry, as I ’oped he would, but he smiled a kind of insolent smile, with a mouth full of white, sharp teeth. ‘Oh no, they wouldn’t like me,’ ’e says.
“‘Ow yes, they would,’ says I, a-imitatin’ of him. ‘They always likes a bone or two to clean their teeth on about tea-time, which you ’as a bagful.’
“Well, it was a odd thing, but when the animiles see us a-talkin’ they lay down, and when I went over to Bersicker he let me stroke his ears same as ever. That there man kem over, and blessed but if he didn’t put in his hand and stroke the old wolf’s ears too!
“‘Tyke care,’ says I. ‘Bersicker is quick.’
“‘Never mind,’ he says. ‘I’m used to ’em!’
“‘Are you in the business yourself?’ I says, tyking off my ’at, for a man what trades in wolves, anceterer, is a good friend to keepers.
“‘No,’ says he, ‘not exactly in the business, but I ’ave made pets of several.’ And with that he lifts his ’at as perlite as a lord, and walks away. Old Bersicker kep’ a-lookin’ arter ’im till ’e was out of sight, and then went and lay down in a corner and wouldn’t come hout the ’ole hevening.

THE ESCAPED WOLF.

I had a visit the other day from a reporter of the Pall Mall Gazette, who was on the track of a sensation. He came to me with a note of introduction from a friend, and, after a little banter, got me to talk about the escaped wolf, Bersicker. I had not been very communicative at first, for I did not want to make a story of it, but he was so persistent that I gave way.

"Now, Mr. Bilder," said he, "you are the man who had the escaped wolf, Bersicker, in your charge?"

"Yes, sir," I replied, "he was a fine brute, and a very quiet one, too, for a wolf. I never saw a more tractable animal. He was always gentle, and never showed the least sign of ferocity."

"Then how comes it that he escaped?"

"That is what I can't make out," I said. "He was in his den at night, and I had the bars fastened. I went to see him about midnight, and found the bars open, and the brute gone."

"Did you see any one about?"

"Yes, sir, I did. There was a man standing near the bars. He was a tall, thin man, with a long, sharp nose, and a pointed beard. His eyes were red, and his teeth were very white and sharp. He had a look about him that made me feel uncomfortable."

"What did he do?"

"He seemed to be watching the wolf. I went up to him, and he turned and looked at me with a smile that was not pleasant. He said nothing, but walked away."

"Did you see anything else?"

"Yes, sir. The wolf was very agitated after the man had gone. He ran about the enclosure for a while, and then settled down in a corner, where he remained for the rest of the night."

"Do you think the man had anything to do with the escape?"

"I do, sir. I think he had. I don't know how, but I think he had."

"What makes you think so?"

"Because the wolf was never like that before. He was always quiet and tractable. But after the man had been near him, he was different."

"Did you speak to the man?"

"Yes, sir. I asked him what he was doing there. He said he was not in the animal trade, but that he had 'made pets of several.' He had white kid gloves on, and he spoke in a very polite manner."

"What did he look like?"

"I have told you. He was tall and thin, with a long, sharp nose and a pointed beard. His eyes were red, and his teeth were very white and sharp."

"Did he seem to know anything about wolves?"

"Yes, sir. He seemed to know a great deal. He said he had 'made pets of several,' and he spoke of them as if he had a great deal of experience."

"Did he touch the wolf?"

"Yes, sir. He put his hand on the wolf's head, and the brute did not seem to mind it."

"What did the wolf do?"

"He looked at the man with a kind of interest, and then he lay down and seemed to be quite at ease."

"Then you think the man had something to do with the escape?"

"I do, sir. I think he had. I don't know how, but I think he had."

"What do you think he was?"

"I don't know, sir. I don't know. But I think he was something that we do not know much about."

"What do you mean?"

"I mean that he was not like other men. He had a look about him that made me feel uncomfortable."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
THE ESCAPED WOLF.

The night was dark and heavy with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves. The wind howled through the narrow streets of the village, carrying with it a sound that was not quite a howl, not quite a scream, but something in between—something that made the blood run cold in the veins of those who heard it. The villagers, long accustomed to the superstitions of their ancestors, whispered of the old tales, of the beast that had once been caged in the forest, the one that had been chained and buried beneath the roots of the ancient oak. But now, it seemed, the beast had escaped.

It had been a long time since the last sighting of the wolf. Some said it had been killed in a storm, others that it had been driven away by the hunters of the village. But the truth, as always, was more complicated. The wolf had not been killed. It had been captured, bound in iron chains, and buried beneath the earth, its howls echoing through the forest for days. The villagers had believed they had rid themselves of the beast, but they had only delayed the inevitable.

The first sign of the wolf's return was the missing goat. It was found the next morning, its body torn apart and scattered across the forest floor. The villagers gathered in the square, their faces pale with fear. The elders spoke of omens, of the moon turning red and the crows flying in strange patterns. They spoke of the old gods and the curses that had been placed upon the land. But the younger ones, those who had grown up in the modern world, dismissed the old tales as mere superstition. They blamed the wolves, the wild dogs, the feral cats. But they were wrong.

The second night, the wolf struck again. This time, it was a child who was taken. A boy of ten, who had wandered too far from the village, drawn by the sound of the wind and the call of the forest. He was found the next morning, his body cold and lifeless, his eyes wide with terror. The villagers were in a state of panic. They gathered in the square, their voices rising in a chorus of fear and anger. They demanded to know who had let the beast loose, who had failed to protect them. But no one had an answer.

It was then that the old man, the one who had lived in the village for as long as anyone could remember, spoke. He was a man of few words, but when he spoke, people listened. He told them of the wolf that had once been caged, of the chains that had held it in place, and of the night when the chains had broken. He told them that the wolf had not been killed, but had been buried, and that now, it had returned to claim what was his.

The villagers listened in silence, their faces pale with fear. They did not know what to believe, but they knew that something was wrong. The old man told them that the wolf was not just a beast, but a spirit, a force of nature that could not be tamed. He told them that the only way to stop it was to find the place where it had been buried and to perform the old rites, the ones that had been passed down through generations. But no one knew where the wolf had been buried, and the old rites had been forgotten long ago.

The villagers were at a loss. They had no choice but to send a group of hunters into the forest to find the wolf and to end its reign of terror. The hunters were chosen from among the strongest and bravest of the village, men who had faced the dangers of the forest before. They set out at dawn, armed with spears and torches, their hearts filled with fear and determination.

The forest was thick and dark, the trees towering like ancient sentinels. The hunters moved cautiously, their footsteps muffled by the thick undergrowth. They followed the trail of destruction left by the wolf, the torn bodies of animals and the deep claw marks in the earth. They knew they were being watched, that the wolf was close, but they pressed on, driven by the need to protect their village.

As the sun began to set, the hunters came upon the ancient oak, its roots twisted and gnarled, its branches reaching out like skeletal fingers. They knew this was the place where the wolf had been buried. They dug through the earth, their hands raw and bleeding, until they found the chains that had once bound the beast. The chains were broken, the links twisted and rusted, but the wolf was still there, beneath the earth, waiting.

The hunters lit a fire and began the old rites, the ones that had been passed down through generations. They chanted in the old tongue, their voices rising and falling like the wind. They poured libations of blood and wine, offerings to the old gods. They called upon the spirits of the forest, begging for their help. But the wolf was not so easily appeased.

As the night deepened, the wind howled through the trees, and the ground trembled beneath their feet. The hunters felt the presence of the wolf, a force of darkness and fury that could not be contained. The wolf rose from the earth, its eyes glowing with a red light, its body covered in chains that had once bound it. It was a creature of both man and beast, a being that had been cursed and forgotten, but now had returned to claim its vengeance.

The hunters fought with all their strength, but the wolf was too powerful. It tore through them with its claws and fangs, its howls echoing through the forest. One by one, the hunters fell, their bodies torn apart and scattered across the earth. The last of them, a man named Ivan, stood alone, his spear broken, his torch extinguished. He looked into the eyes of the wolf and saw the truth: the wolf was not just a beast, but a part of the forest, a part of the land, a part of the village itself. It had been caged and buried, but it had never truly been defeated.

Ivan fell to his knees, his body broken, his spirit broken as well. He whispered a final prayer, a plea for forgiveness, for the wolf to be at peace. The wolf looked at him, its red eyes glowing with a strange light, and then it turned and disappeared into the forest, vanishing into the darkness as if it had never been there at all.

The villagers returned the next morning, their faces pale with fear and grief. They found the hunters' bodies scattered across the earth, the ancient oak standing tall and unbroken. They did not know what had happened, but they knew that the wolf was gone. They did not speak of it again, but the fear remained, a shadow that lingered in the hearts of the villagers. They knew that the wolf had been caged and buried, but they also knew that it could return, that it would return, and that they would never be truly safe again.

And so, the tale of the escaped wolf became a legend, passed down through generations, a warning to those who would dare to challenge the forces of nature. The wolf was not just a beast, but a spirit, a force that could not be tamed. It was a part of the forest, a part of the land, a part of the village itself. And it would return, when the time was right, to claim what was his once more.

events.title: Bersicker's Moonlight Escape, Return, and the Zookeeper's Mundane Explanation
detailed_summary: Bilder continues his account, stating that on the night of the escape, as the moon rose, all the wolves began howling despite no apparent cause, except perhaps someone calling a dog nearby.
Around midnight, Bilder discovered Bersicker's cage rails broken and the cage empty.
He dismisses a gardener's delayed report of seeing a large grey dog as unreliable.
When asked for his theory on the escape, Bilder humorously suggests the wolf escaped simply because it wanted to.

After being offered another payment, Bilder opines that the wolf is likely hiding scared, perhaps in a coal cellar, and might become dangerous if it can't find food, possibly even attacking an unattended baby.
Suddenly, Bersicker, the escaped wolf, reappears at the window.
Bilder calmly lets the wolf in; the animal is peaceful and penitent.
Bilder examines Bersicker, finding his head cut and full of broken glass, attributing the injury to climbing a wall topped with broken bottles.
He locks Bersicker back in his cage with a large piece of meat and goes to report the wolf's return.
The interviewer departs to file his exclusive story.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, larst night, so soon as the moon was hup, the wolves here all began a-’owling.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I came off, too, to report the only exclusive information that is given to-day regarding the strange escapade at the Zoo.

events.text_segment:
Well, larst night, so soon as the moon was hup, the wolves here all began a-’owling. There warn’t nothing for them to ’owl at. There warn’t no one near, except some one that was evidently a-callin’ a dog somewheres out back of the gardings in the Park road. Once or twice I went out to see that all was right, and it was, and then the ’owling stopped. Just before twelve o’clock I just took a look round afore turnin’ in, an’, bust me, but when I kem opposite to old Bersicker’s cage I see the rails broken and twisted about and the cage empty. And that’s all I know for certing.”
“Did any one else see anything?”
“One of our gard’ners was a-comin’ ’ome about that time from a ’armony, when he sees a big grey dog comin’ out through the garding ’edges. At least, so he says, but I don’t give much for it myself, for if he did ’e never said a word about it to his missis when ’e got ’ome, and it was only after the escape of the wolf was made known, and we had been up all night-a-huntin’ of the Park for Bersicker, that he remembered seein’ anything. My own belief was that the ’armony ’ad got into his ’ead.”
“Now, Mr. Bilder, can you account in any way for the escape of the wolf?”
“Well, sir,” he said, with a suspicious sort of modesty, “I think I can; but I don’t know as ’ow you’d be satisfied with the theory.”
“Certainly I shall. If a man like you, who knows the animals from experience, can’t hazard a good guess at any rate, who is even to try?”
“Well then, sir, I accounts for it this way; it seems to me that ’ere wolf escaped—simply because he wanted to get out.”
From the hearty way that both Thomas and his wife laughed at the joke I could see that it had done service before, and that the whole explanation was simply an elaborate sell. I couldn’t cope in badinage with the worthy Thomas, but I thought I knew a surer way to his heart, so I said:—
“Now, Mr. Bilder, we’ll consider that first half-sovereign worked off, and this brother of his is waiting to be claimed when you’ve told me what you think will happen.”
“Right y’are, sir,” he said briskly. “Ye’ll excoose me, I know, for a-chaffin’ of ye, but the old woman here winked at me, which was as much as telling me to go on.”
“Well, I never!” said the old lady.
“My opinion is this: that ’ere wolf is a-’idin’ of, somewheres. The gard’ner wot didn’t remember said he was a-gallopin’ northward faster than a horse could go; but I don’t believe him, for, yer see, sir, wolves don’t gallop no more nor dogs does, they not bein’ built that way. Wolves is fine things in a storybook, and I dessay when they gets in packs and does be chivyin’ somethin’ that’s more afeared than they is they can make a devil of a noise and chop it up, whatever it is. But, Lor’ bless you, in real life a wolf is only a low creature, not half so clever or bold as a good dog; and not half a quarter so much fight in ’im. This one ain’t been used to fightin’ or even to providin’ for hisself, and more like he’s somewhere round the Park a-’idin’ an’ a-shiverin’ of, and, if he thinks at all, wonderin’ where he is to get his breakfast from; or maybe he’s got down some area and is in a coal-cellar. My eye, won’t some cook get a rum start when she sees his green eyes a-shining at her out of the dark! If he can’t get food he’s bound to look for it, and mayhap he may chance to light on a butcher’s shop in time. If he doesn’t, and some nursemaid goes a-walkin’ orf with a soldier, leavin’ of the hinfant in the perambulator—well, then I shouldn’t be surprised if the census is one babby the less. That’s all.”
I was handing him the half-sovereign, when something came bobbing up against the window, and Mr. Bilder’s face doubled its natural length with surprise.
“God bless me!” he said. “If there ain’t old Bersicker come back by ’isself!”
He went to the door and opened it; a most unnecessary proceeding it seemed to me. I have always thought that a wild animal never looks so well as when some obstacle of pronounced durability is between us; a personal experience has intensified rather than diminished that idea.
After all, however, there is nothing like custom, for neither Bilder nor his wife thought any more of the wolf than I should of a dog. The animal itself was as peaceful and well-behaved as that father of all picture-wolves—Red Riding Hood’s quondam friend, whilst moving her confidence in masquerade.
The whole scene was an unutterable mixture of comedy and pathos. The wicked wolf that for half a day had paralysed London and set all the children in the town shivering in their shoes, was there in a sort of penitent mood, and was received and petted like a sort of vulpine prodigal son. Old Bilder examined him all over with most tender solicitude, and when he had finished with his penitent said:—
“There, I knew the poor old chap would get into some kind of trouble; didn’t I say it all along? Here’s his head all cut and full of broken glass. ’E’s been a-gettin’ over some bloomin’ wall or other. It’s a shyme that people are allowed to top their walls with broken bottles. This ’ere’s what comes of it. Come along, Bersicker.”
He took the wolf and locked him up in a cage, with a piece of meat that satisfied, in quantity at any rate, the elementary conditions of the fatted calf, and went off to report.
I came off, too, to report the only exclusive information that is given to-day regarding the strange escapade at the Zoo.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Well, larst night, so soon as the moon was hup, the wolves here all began a-’owling. I couldn’t make out why, for there was no dog a-barking, or nothin’ of that sort, unless it was the wind, maybe. But it was a still night, and the howlin’ went on and on, like they was all in a row. I thought maybe one of the cubs had got loose, but no, they was all in their pens. Then, just about midnight, I went to check on Bersicker, and I found his cage door wide open, and the rails all broken. I looked all round, but there was no sign of him. I asked the gardener if he’d seen nothin’, and he said he thought he saw a big grey dog run past the back of the house, but I told him it was just his fancy, for there ain’t no dog in this place but the one the cook keeps in the kitchen, and that’s a little terrier. When the interviewer asked me how I thought he got out, I told him I didn’t know, but maybe the wolf just wanted to get out, and that’s all. He laughed, but I said it was a good answer, for it was the truth. Then I told him I thought the beast was hiding somewhere, maybe in the coal cellar, and if he couldn’t find nothin’ to eat, he might get desperate and go for a baby. Just then, there was a knock at the window, and there was Bersicker, all grey and quiet, lookin’ in. I opened the window, and he came in like a lamb. I looked him over, and I saw that his head was cut and full of glass, so I reckoned he must have tried to climb the wall where we put the broken bottles. I gave him a big piece of meat and locked him back in his cage, and then I went to tell the keeper. The interviewer said he had to go and write his story, and I said I’d see him at the station.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Well, larst night, so soon as the moon was hup, the wolves here all began a-’owling. I thought it was just the usual, you know, the way they do when the moon’s full. But this time, it was different. It wasn’t just the sound—it was the way they howled, like they were calling to something, or maybe warning it away. I couldn’t sleep, I tell you. I got up and went out to the porch, and I saw the moonlight spilling over the hills like blood. It was a red moon, and it made everything look wrong, like it didn’t belong in this world anymore.

I stood there for a while, trying to make sense of it. The wolves kept howling, and the wind started to pick up, carrying with it a smell I couldn’t place. It wasn’t the usual forest scent—no, this was something else. Something old. Something dead. I felt a chill run down my spine, and I knew in my bones that something was coming. Not just something, but *him*.

I’ve heard the stories, of course. The old ones, the ones that make your skin crawl and your heart beat faster. The ones about the Count, the one who walks among the living but is not one of them. The one who drinks the blood of the innocent and leaves them cold and lifeless. I’ve heard the villagers whisper about him, and I’ve seen the fear in their eyes when they mention his name. But I never thought I’d see him with my own eyes. Not here, not in this place.

But last night, I think I did. I saw a shadow moving across the hills, just at the edge of the moonlight. It was too tall, too straight, and it moved with a strange grace, like it wasn’t bound by the laws of this world. I couldn’t see his face, but I could feel his eyes on me, and it was like he was looking through me, into the very core of my being. I felt my breath catch in my throat, and I knew I had to get back inside.

I ran back to the house, slamming the door behind me and locking it. I lit a candle and sat by the window, watching and waiting. The howling continued, but now it was joined by another sound—a low, guttural growl that came from deep within the forest. It was a sound that made my blood run cold, and I could feel the presence of something evil just beyond the trees.

I tried to pray, but the words wouldn’t come. My mind was filled with images of the Count, of his pale face and his long, sharp teeth. I could almost hear his voice, smooth and seductive, promising me power and immortality if I would just give in to him. I shook my head, trying to clear it, but the images wouldn’t go away. I could feel his presence growing stronger, and I knew I had to do something.

I grabbed a cross from the drawer and held it in my hand, feeling a small measure of comfort. I also took a stake from the same drawer, just in case. I had heard that the Count could be killed, but it wasn’t easy. He was strong, and he had many followers. I knew I couldn’t face him alone, but I also knew that I couldn’t let him take over this place. I had to find a way to stop him.

The next morning, I went to the village and told the others what I had seen. Some of them laughed at me, thinking I was just imagining things. But others, the older ones, looked at me with fear in their eyes. They had heard the stories too, and they knew that the Count was real. They told me that he had been in the area for some time, and that he had been taking people—men, women, and even children—and leaving them drained of their blood.

I knew I had to act quickly. I went to the local priest and asked for his help. He was reluctant at first, but when I told him what I had seen, he agreed to help me. We began to gather information, talking to the villagers and asking about the missing people. We found out that the Count had been staying in an old castle on the edge of the forest, and that he had been using it as a base for his activities.

We also found out that he had a group of followers, people who had been turned by him and were now under his control. They were called the *vampires*, and they were just as dangerous as he was. We knew that we couldn’t face them alone, so we began to plan a way to stop them. We would need to find a way to get into the castle and destroy the Count, but we also needed to find a way to free the people he had taken.

The next few days were filled with preparation. We gathered weapons, holy water, and other items that might be useful in our fight against the Count. We also tried to find out more about his weaknesses, hoping to find a way to defeat him. We learned that he could be killed by a stake through the heart, but that it had to be made of a certain type of wood. We also learned that he could be repelled by garlic and the sign of the cross, but that he was not afraid of fire or sunlight.

Finally, the day came when we were ready to act. We set out for the castle, armed and determined. The journey was long and difficult, and we had to be careful not to be seen by the Count’s followers. We moved through the forest, using the cover of the trees to hide from view. We could feel the presence of the Count growing stronger as we got closer to the castle, and we could hear the howling of the wolves getting louder.

When we finally reached the castle, we were met with a sight that made our hearts race. The castle was dark and foreboding, with tall spires that reached into the sky. The doors were open, and we could see the inside was filled with shadows and strange shapes. We knew that we had to be careful, and we moved in slowly, trying to avoid making any noise.

Inside, we found the Count’s followers, the vampires, moving through the castle like shadows. They were pale and gaunt, with sharp teeth and glowing eyes. We could feel their presence, and we knew that we had to be careful not to be caught by them. We moved through the castle, trying to find the Count and the people he had taken.

Finally, we found them. The Count was in a large room at the top of the castle, surrounded by the people he had taken. They were all pale and weak, and we could see the fear in their eyes. The Count was standing in the center of the room, his long, pale fingers outstretched, and his eyes glowing with a strange light. He looked up as we entered, and I could feel his gaze on me, like he was trying to read my mind.

I stepped forward, holding the cross in my hand. “Count Dracula,” I said, my voice steady. “We have come to stop you.”

He smiled, a slow, cruel smile. “You are brave, little one,” he said. “But you are also foolish. You cannot stop me. I am eternal.”

I stepped closer, my heart pounding. “You may be eternal, but you are not invincible. We have come to end your reign of terror.”

He laughed, a low, guttural sound. “You think you can kill me? You are nothing but a child playing at being a hero.”

I raised the cross, and the Count recoiled, his face twisting in pain. “You are wrong,” I said. “We are not children. We are the people of this village, and we will not let you take us.”

The Count growled, and the vampires in the room moved toward us, their eyes glowing with hunger. We were outnumbered, but we were not afraid. We fought with everything we had, using the weapons and holy water we had brought with us. It was a fierce battle, and we were badly hurt, but we refused to give up.

Finally, we found the Count alone, and we struck him with the stake. He screamed, a sound that echoed through the castle, and he fell to the ground, his body crumbling to dust. The vampires screamed as well, and they too began to crumble, their bodies turning to dust as the Count’s power left them.

We had won. The Count was dead, and the people he had taken were free. We carried them out of the castle and back to the village, where they were cared for and given food and water. The villagers were overjoyed, and they thanked us for what we had done.

But I knew that the battle was not over. The Count had been powerful, and there were others like him. I knew that I would have to be ready, in case he returned. But for now, we had won, and the village was safe. And that was enough.

events.title: Renfield's Savage Attack and Disturbing Declaration
detailed_summary: While Dr. Seward is catching up on his paperwork, his patient Renfield bursts into the study.
Renfield, armed with a dinner knife, attacks Seward, managing to cut his left wrist.
Seward quickly overpowers Renfield, who falls to the floor.
As Seward tends to his bleeding wrist, he observes Renfield lying on his stomach, licking up the spilled blood from the carpet like a dog.
Attendants secure Renfield, who placidly accompanies them, repeatedly chanting, "The blood is the life!"
Seward, feeling the effects of recent blood loss and the strain of Lucy's illness, recognizes his urgent need for rest.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Happily Van Helsing has not summoned me, so I need not forego my sleep; to-night I could not well do without it.

events.text_segment:
17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”
I cannot afford to lose blood just at present; I have lost too much of late for my physical good, and then the prolonged strain of Lucy’s illness and its horrible phases is telling on me. I am over-excited and weary, and I need rest, rest, rest. Happily Van Helsing has not summoned me, so I need not forego my sleep; to-night I could not well do without it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. I had just finished the last of the accounts when there was a violent rush at the door, and before I could get up, it burst open and in rushed Renfield, with a dinner knife in his hand. He came at me with a wild look in his eyes, and before I could get out of his way, he slashed at me. The blade caught me on the left wrist, and I felt the blood spurt out. I tried to get hold of him, and after a struggle I got the better of him, and he fell to the floor. I then saw that he had cut himself badly, and as I looked down at my wrist, I saw the blood trickling down. Renfield, in the meantime, had rolled over on his stomach, and was licking up the blood from the carpet, like a dog. The attendants came in and secured him, and he went quietly with them, muttering all the time, 'The blood is the life! The blood is the life!' I am very weak from the loss of blood, and I feel the strain of Lucy's illness more than ever. I must get some rest, or I shall not be able to stand it much longer.

17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. I had just finished the accounts for the month when I heard a knock at the door. It was Quincey Morris, who looked very tired and travel-worn. He had come from America, he said, and had urgent business with me. I invited him in and offered him tea, but he declined, saying he had already eaten. He sat down and looked at me with a grave expression.

"I have come to warn you," he said, "about the Count. I have seen him in New York, and I believe he is coming to England. He is a dangerous man, and I fear he is after something—perhaps a wife. I have heard strange things about him, and I have seen him with a young woman who looked very much like your Lucy."

I was startled by this news. I had heard of the Count before, but I had never met him. I asked Quincey to tell me everything he knew. He said that the Count had been in New York for some time, and that he had been seen in the company of a number of young women. He had also been seen at night, and had been accused of strange and unnatural behavior.

I was very disturbed by this news, and I resolved to keep a close watch on Lucy. I had already noticed that she had been acting strangely of late, and I feared that she might be in danger. I told Quincey that I would do everything I could to protect her, and he said he would help me in any way he could.

We talked for some time longer, and then Quincey took his leave. I was left alone in my study, with my thoughts. I could not shake off the feeling of unease that had settled over me. I knew that something strange was happening, and I feared that it might be connected with the Count. I resolved to keep a close watch on Lucy and to do everything I could to protect her from whatever danger might be coming our way.

events.title: Van Helsing's Delayed Warning and Seward's Mounting Fear
detailed_summary: A telegram from Van Helsing, sent from Antwerp on September 17th, arrives twenty-two hours late.
The message urgently instructs Seward to be at Hillingham that night, to frequently check that Lucy's protective flowers are correctly placed, emphasizing its critical importance.
Van Helsing states he will join Seward as soon as possible after his arrival.
Dr. Seward, reading the diary entry on September 18th, is filled with dismay by the delayed telegram.
He is terrified about what might have transpired during the unprotected night, given his past "bitter experience."
He expresses a sense of being thwarted by fate and decides to take his phonograph cylinder to London to complete his notes on Lucy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Telegram, Van Helsing, Antwerp, to Seward, Carfax.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I shall take this cylinder with me, and then I can complete my entry on Lucy’s phonograph.

events.text_segment:
Telegram, Van Helsing, Antwerp, to Seward, Carfax.
(Sent to Carfax, Sussex, as no county given; delivered late by twenty-two hours.)
“17 September.—Do not fail to be at Hillingham to-night. If not watching all the time frequently, visit and see that flowers are as placed; very important; do not fail. Shall be with you as soon as possible after arrival.”
Dr. Seward’s Diary.
18 September.—Just off for train to London. The arrival of Van Helsing’s telegram filled me with dismay. A whole night lost, and I know by bitter experience what may happen in a night. Of course it is possible that all may be well, but what may have happened? Surely there is some horrible doom hanging over us that every possible accident should thwart us in all we try to do. I shall take this cylinder with me, and then I can complete my entry on Lucy’s phonograph.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Telegram, Van Helsing, Antwerp, to Seward, Carfax. 

"Come to Hillingham to-night. See that the flowers are kept in place. It is of the utmost importance. I come as soon as I can."

This was the message which reached me at Carfax on the morning of the 18th, but which had been sent on the 17th. It was twenty-two hours late. I read it with a feeling of dismay. I could not but think of the long night that had passed, and of what might have happened during the time that the flowers had not been in their places. I had bitter experience of what might happen when the protection was removed. I felt as if Fate were playing with us, and that we were always just a little too late. I determined to take the phonograph cylinder with me to London, and to complete my notes on Lucy.

events.title: Terror at Hillingham: The Wolf's Attack and Mrs. Westenra's Tragic Death
detailed_summary: Lucy, feeling she is dying, writes an account of the night's horrific events.
Awakened by the familiar flapping at her window, she feels the old fear of sleep and tries to stay awake.
She hears a fierce, deep howl outside and sees a large bat at the window.
Her mother, uneasy about Lucy, enters the room and, at Lucy's request, lies down in bed with her.
The flapping at the window resumes, startling Mrs. Westenra.
A low howl is heard again, followed by the sound of shattering glass as a great, gaunt grey wolf's head appears in the broken window.
Mrs. Westenra, terrified, screams and clutches at anything for support, inadvertently tearing the protective garlic wreath from Lucy's neck.
She sits up, pointing at the wolf, makes a horrible gurgling sound, and then collapses, apparently dead from shock, her head striking Lucy's forehead.
Lucy, dazed, sees the wolf withdraw and a myriad of tiny specks blow into the room, feeling a spell upon her as her mother's body grows cold. She then loses consciousness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: 17 September. Night.—I write this and leave it to be seen, so that no one may by any chance get into trouble through me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I tried to stir, but there was some spell upon me, and dear mother’s poor body, which seemed to grow cold already—for her dear heart had ceased to beat—weighed me down; and I remembered no more for a while.

events.text_segment:
17 September. Night.—I write this and leave it to be seen, so that no one may by any chance get into trouble through me. This is an exact record of what took place to-night. I feel I am dying of weakness, and have barely strength to write, but it must be done if I die in the doing.
I went to bed as usual, taking care that the flowers were placed as Dr. Van Helsing directed, and soon fell asleep.
I was waked by the flapping at the window, which had begun after that sleep-walking on the cliff at Whitby when Mina saved me, and which now I know so well. I was not afraid, but I did wish that Dr. Seward was in the next room—as Dr. Van Helsing said he would be—so that I might have called him. I tried to go to sleep, but could not. Then there came to me the old fear of sleep, and I determined to keep awake. Perversely sleep would try to come then when I did not want it; so, as I feared to be alone, I opened my door and called out: “Is there anybody there?” There was no answer. I was afraid to wake mother, and so closed my door again. Then outside in the shrubbery I heard a sort of howl like a dog’s, but more fierce and deeper. I went to the window and looked out, but could see nothing, except a big bat, which had evidently been buffeting its wings against the window. So I went back to bed again, but determined not to go to sleep. Presently the door opened, and mother looked in; seeing by my moving that I was not asleep, came in, and sat by me. She said to me even more sweetly and softly than her wont:—
“I was uneasy about you, darling, and came in to see that you were all right.”
I feared she might catch cold sitting there, and asked her to come in and sleep with me, so she came into bed, and lay down beside me; she did not take off her dressing gown, for she said she would only stay a while and then go back to her own bed. As she lay there in my arms, and I in hers, the flapping and buffeting came to the window again. She was startled and a little frightened, and cried out: “What is that?” I tried to pacify her, and at last succeeded, and she lay quiet; but I could hear her poor dear heart still beating terribly. After a while there was the low howl again out in the shrubbery, and shortly after there was a crash at the window, and a lot of broken glass was hurled on the floor. The window blind blew back with the wind that rushed in, and in the aperture of the broken panes there was the head of a great, gaunt grey wolf. Mother cried out in a fright, and struggled up into a sitting posture, and clutched wildly at anything that would help her. Amongst other things, she clutched the wreath of flowers that Dr. Van Helsing insisted on my wearing round my neck, and tore it away from me. For a second or two she sat up, pointing at the wolf, and there was a strange and horrible gurgling in her throat; then she fell over—as if struck with lightning, and her head hit my forehead and made me dizzy for a moment or two. The room and all round seemed to spin round. I kept my eyes fixed on the window, but the wolf drew his head back, and a whole myriad of little specks seemed to come blowing in through the broken window, and wheeling and circling round like the pillar of dust that travellers describe when there is a simoon in the desert. I tried to stir, but there was some spell upon me, and dear mother’s poor body, which seemed to grow cold already—for her dear heart had ceased to beat—weighed me down; and I remembered no more for a while.

events.title: Lucy's Desperate Hours Alone with Death and Her Final Farewell
detailed_summary: Lucy regains consciousness after an awful, though seemingly short, period.
She hears a passing bell, dogs howling, and a nightingale singing, which she likens to her dead mother's comforting voice.
The maids, awakened by the sounds, enter Lucy's room and scream upon seeing Mrs. Westenra's body.
After Lucy gets up, they lay her mother's body on the bed, covered with a sheet.
Lucy, noticing their fright, directs them to the dining room for wine.
She places what flowers she has on her mother's breast.

When the maids don't return, Lucy finds them all unconscious on the dining room floor, breathing heavily, with a half-empty sherry decanter smelling of laudanum. She realizes someone drugged the servants.
Alone with her dead mother and the drugged servants, she hears the wolf howling outside the broken window.
The air seems full of floating specks, and the lights burn blue and dim.
Feeling her own death approaching, she decides to hide her written account in her breast.
She bids farewell to Arthur, praying for his well-being and for her own soul.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: God keep you, dear, and God help me!

events.text_segment:
The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.
My heart sank when I saw what had happened. They all four lay helpless on the floor, breathing heavily. The decanter of sherry was on the table half full, but there was a queer, acrid smell about. I was suspicious, and examined the decanter. It smelt of laudanum, and looking on the sideboard, I found that the bottle which mother’s doctor uses for her—oh! did use—was empty. What am I to do? what am I to do? I am back in the room with mother. I cannot leave her, and I am alone, save for the sleeping servants, whom some one has drugged. Alone with the dead! I dare not go out, for I can hear the low howl of the wolf through the broken window.
The air seems full of specks, floating and circling in the draught from the window, and the lights burn blue and dim. What am I to do? God shield me from harm this night! I shall hide this paper in my breast, where they shall find it when they come to lay me out. My dear mother gone! It is time that I go too. Good-bye, dear Arthur, if I should not survive this night. God keep you, dear, and God help me!

The air seemed full of floating specks, and the lights burned blue and dim. I felt that I was going to die, and I put my journal in my breast. I bid farewell to Arthur, and I prayed for his soul and for mine.
